list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Below shows a Sankey diagram for an LED.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/32db4f78-02b8-43c8-82fb-6de54d482356/images/0cc12eab-6d49-485c-82a5-a201da16c116/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.58.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Which of the following shows the percentage efficiency of the LED and the total power input?Percentage efficiencyTotal power input\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}40%40\%40%444W\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}40%40\%40%202020W\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}60%60\%60%444W\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}60%60\%60%202020W
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Total power unput = total power output =12+8=2012\ +\ 8\ =\ 2012+8=20WFor an LED useful energy is visible light energy:Percentage efficiency =Useful energy outputTotal energy input(100)=820(100)=40%\dfrac{\textrm{ Useful energy output}}{\textrm{ Total energy input}}\ (100)\ =\ \dfrac{8}{20}\ (100)\ =\ 40\%Total energy inputUseful energy output​(100)=208​(100)=40%

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which of the following units is not a unit of power?A.\hspace{1em}WB.\hspace{1em}JC.\hspace{1em}N m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}J s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The SI unit of power is W and it is defined as J s−1^{-1}−1.Additionally, power can be calculated byP=FvP = FvP=FvWhen units of force and speed are substituted in the equation, the units become\hspace{1.5em}N m s−1^{-1}−1But J is the SI unit of energy.Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A builder uses a block and tackle pulley system to lift a bundle of materials of mass 15 kg to the top of a building of height 6 m in 9 s. What is the power delivered to the bundle? Assumeg=10g=10g=10N kg−1^{-1}−1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d1489c-8ba8-4cb6-8d7b-fe039bac7303/images/94315b8c-73e2-407b-bd29-9b312cbeeda6/PH0125.png)

[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0}]}[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0]A.\hspace{1em}10 WB.\hspace{1em}17 WC.\hspace{1em}100 WD.\hspace{1em}900 W
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Power=mght=(15kg)(6m)(10N kg−1)9s=100W\begin{aligned}
\textrm{Power} &= \dfrac{mgh}{t}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&= \dfrac{(15\textrm{ kg})(6\textrm{ m})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})}{9\textrm{ s}}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
 &= 100\textrm{ W}\
 \end{aligned}Power​=tmgh​=9s(15kg)(6m)(10N kg−1)​=100W​

list.title: Question 4
list.content: A spaceship is moving away from a star at a speed of0.2c0.2c0.2c.An observer in the spaceship will measure the speed at which light from the star is received to be:A.\hspace{1em}0.2c0.2c0.2cB.\hspace{1em}0.8c0.8c0.8cC.\hspace{1em}cccD.\hspace{1em}1.2c1.2c1.2c
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​According to the second postulate of special relativity, the speed of light is a constant (ccc) in all inertial frames.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The diagram below shows a tennis ball of massmmmstriking a wall with an initial velocity,uuu, and rebounding with velocityvvv. A second, softer ball of the same mass strikes the wall with the same speed but rebounds with a slower rebound speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bbeffe1-fadb-4f69-a8f6-5a1deb1f20d3/images/a440cac5-43c9-4b14-97ec-4b768f633978/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.33.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following statements is correct about the magnitudes of the impulse and change in momentum applied to the second ball compared to the first?\hspace{1em}Impulse\hspace{1em}Change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}GreaterSmaller\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}SmallerGreater\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}GreaterGreater\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}SmallerSmaller
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The change in momentum and impulse applied to the ball are equal, because the impulse is defined as the change in momentum. Increasing one is the same as increasing the other and vice-versa. The slower rebound speed of the second ball causes a decrease in the magnitude of the impulse since the change in momentum is smaller if the final speedvvvis smaller.J=Δp=m(v−−u)=m(v+u)J = \Delta p = m(v - -u) = m(v + u)J=Δp=m(v−−u)=m(v+u)

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The figure below shows a Sankey diagram for a small thermal plant. What is the efficiency of the system?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59cbaf81-366a-4d3b-84b4-81c19240c4a5/images/2e6829ac-2af0-4764-a71e-8c91dc895927/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%201.58.29%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

A.\hspace{1em}10%B.\hspace{1em}20%C.\hspace{1em}40%D.\hspace{1em}60%
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In Sankey diagrams for energy, useful energy is shown as continuing straight while energy losses point downwards.From the Sankey diagram, subtracting the value of the heat losses givesTo find the useful power:1600−(320+640)=6401600 - (320 + 640) = 6401600−(320+640)=640kWEfficiency can now be calculated:η=Useful power outTotal power in×100=640kW1600kW×100%=40%\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em}\eta &= \frac{\textrm{Useful power out}}{\textrm{Total power in}} \times 100\\
\hspace{1em}\\
&= \frac{640\textrm{ kW}}{1600\textrm{ kW}} \times 100\% \\
\hspace{1em}\\
&= 40\%
\end{aligned}η​=Total power inUseful power out​×100=1600kW640kW​×100%=40%​

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The diagram below shows a car of massmmmdescending a slope. The car, initially at rest, covers a distance of 27 m in 3.0 s.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b5634a7-bfb0-4c45-859f-2684b781580b/images/3d546597-f800-49ad-b760-e4ace00a2c04/PH0123.png)

The magnitude of the acceleration is given byA.\hspace{1em}3.0 m s−2^{-2}−2B.\hspace{1em}6.0 m s−2^{-2}−2C.\hspace{1em}9.0 m s−2^{-2}−2D.\hspace{1em}81 m s−2^{-2}−2
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From the equation of motions=ut+12at2s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=ut+21​at2initially the velocity,uuuis zero givinga=2 st2a = \dfrac{\textrm{2 s}}{t^2} \hspace{1em}a=t22 s​Substitutingt=3t = 3t=3s:a=(2)(27.0 m)(3.0s)2=6.0a=\dfrac{\textrm{(2)(27.0 m)}}{(3.0\ \ce{s})^2} = 6.0a=(3.0s)2(2)(27.0 m)​=6.0m s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 8
list.content: An object moves at constant velocity for a period of time, after which it undergoes uniform deceleration until it comes to rest. A velocity-time graph is plotted for this motion. On the graph, which of the following would represent the displacement of the object?A.\hspace{1em}Gradient of the line connecting the initial and final velocities.B.\hspace{1em}x-interceptC.\hspace{1em}y-interceptD.\hspace{1em}Area under the graph
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For option A, the gradient of the line connecting the starting and ending velocities gives the average acceleration.For option B, x-intercept represents the time of when velocity is zero, therefore is incorrect.For option C, y-intercept represents the velocity when the time is zero, therefore is incorrect.For option D, area under the graph is the displacement, which is the correct answer.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
An object of massMMMon a string moves in a circle of radiusrrrat a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6590a45d-55a7-400f-b7b5-4f31b825e7ad/images/ab24556d-04d2-418a-b7f4-9e1ca037a3f1/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.28.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Below are three statements about the motion of the object:I.\hspace{1.1em}The resultant work done on the object is zero.II.\hspace{0.8em}The velocity of the object is constant.III.\hspace{0.5em}The object is acceleratingWhich of the statements is/are true?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I is correct.The accelerating force is always perpendicular to the direction of motion, therefore no work is done.W=Fscos⁡θW = Fs \cos\thetaW=Fscosθ, andθ\thetaθis always 90°\degree°, andcos⁡90°=0\cos 90 \degree =0cos90°=0Also,W=ΔEkW=\Delta E_kW=ΔEk​and the speed of the object is constant so there is no change in kinetic energy.II is incorrect.Because velocity is a vector quantity and the direction is constantly changing, velocity is not constant.III is correct.Because velocity is constantly changing, the object is always accelerating.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Two identical masses of magnitudemmmare attached to the opposite ends of a solid beam of negligible mass and total lengthlll.The beam is suspended from its centre and rotates about a vertical axis at constant angular speedω\omegaωas shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7097837f-f2c7-411c-aa60-2da2311be6e3/images/ae44f322-e8d7-4dae-872f-8891d75d9147/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.38.50%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following correctly expresses the magnitude of the angular momentum of the system around its axis of rotation?A.\hspace{1em}14ml2ω\dfrac{1}{4}ml^2\omega41​ml2ωB.\hspace{1em}12ml2ω\dfrac{1}{2}ml^2\omega21​ml2ωC.\hspace{1em}ml2ωml^2\omegaml2ωD.\hspace{1em}2ml2ω2ml^2\omega2ml2ω
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The moment of inertia of the system can be expressed as:I=m(l2)2+m(l2)2=12ml2I=m\Bigl(\dfrac{l}{2}\Bigr)^2+m\Bigl(\dfrac{l}{2}\Bigr)^2=\dfrac{1}{2} ml^2I=m(2l​)2+m(2l​)2=21​ml2The magnitude of the angular momentum is then:L=Iω=12ml2ωL=I\omega=\dfrac{1}{2}ml^2\omegaL=Iω=21​ml2ω

list.title: Question 11
list.content: A ball rolls horizontally off the edge of the top of a cliff. It hits the ground at a distance 2.0 m horizontally away from the base of the cliff with a vertical speed of 20 m s−1^{-1}−1. What is the height of the cliff?A.\hspace{1em}20 mB.\hspace{1em}40 mC.\hspace{1em}60 mD.\hspace{1em}80 m
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Only the vertical motion needs to be considered here.v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asThere is initially no vertical velocity sou=0u=0u=0v2=2gsv^2=2gsv2=2gs202=(2)(10)(s)20^2 = (2)(10)(s)202=(2)(10)(s)s=400(2)(10)s = \dfrac{400}{(2)(10)}s=(2)(10)400​s=20s = 20s=20mNote that for multiple choice questions it is normally appropriate to use 10 m s−2^{-2}−2as the acceleration of freefall.

list.title: Question 12
list.content: A basketball is launched at an angle and undergoes projectile motion. Air resistance is negligible. Which of the following is correct for the direction of its velocity vector and its acceleration vector at the highest point of its trajectory?Direction of velocity vectorDirection of acceleration vector\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}horizontalno acceleration\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}no velocityno acceleration\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}no velocitydownward\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}horizontaldownward
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top of its trajectory, vertical velocity will be zero, but the horizontal component of the velocity will maintain the same value throughout the motion, therefore velocity will be horizontal.Acceleration due to gravity is always acting and acts downward.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: A box is pulled by a child with a horizontal force of 5 N. The box moves a horizontal distance of 4 m in a time of 2 s. What is the average power delivered by the child to the box?A.\hspace{1em}2.5 WB.\hspace{1em}5.0 WC.\hspace{1em}10 WD.\hspace{1em}40 W
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Power =ΔWt\dfrac{\Delta W}{t}tΔW​andW=FsW = FsW=FsW=(5N)(4m)=20W = (5\ \ce{ N})(4\ \ce{m}) = 20W=(5N)(4m)=20JP=20J2s=10P=\dfrac{20\textrm{ J}}{2\textrm{ s}} = 10P=2s20J​=10WAlternative:Pav=Fvav=F(st)=5(42)=10P_{av} = Fv_{av} = F\bigg(\dfrac{\textrm{s}}{\textrm{t}}\bigg) = 5\bigg(\dfrac{4}{2}\bigg) = 10Pav​=Fvav​=F(ts​)=5(24​)=10W

list.title: Question 14
list.content: An object moves in a circular path of radius222m with angular displacement ofπ2\dfrac{\pi}{2}2π​rad in555s.What is the average linear speed of the object?A.\hspace{1em}π20\dfrac{\pi}{20}20π​m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}π10\dfrac{\pi}{10}10π​m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}π5\dfrac{\pi}{5}5π​m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}2π5\dfrac{2\pi}{5}52π​m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The linear speed is given byv=rωv=r\omegav=rωandω=ΔθΔt\omega=\dfrac{\Delta \theta }{\Delta t}ω=ΔtΔθ​Then:v=(r)ΔθΔt=(2)(π2)5=π5v = (r) \dfrac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t} = (2) \dfrac{(\frac{\pi}{2})}{5} = \dfrac{\pi}{5}v=(r)ΔtΔθ​=(2)5(2π​)​=5π​m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
A skydiver of weight,WWW, of a skydiver falls through air with a drag forceFdragF_{drag}Fdrag​If the skydiver experiences terminal velocity, which of the following best represents the free body diagram of the skydiver?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/f7d98c67-c67c-413e-b6dc-6ce1eaddd8f0/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.28%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/7e66ac3f-29ca-49cc-965b-4b1ac077eb37/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/c264232f-f4f5-4f65-b6d4-07507de5161f/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.45%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/26ffa821-04f6-4987-8f19-ab4c4a016b76/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At terminal velocity there is no accleration. Forces must be balanced, therefore the drag force is equal and opposite to the weight.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: A car of massmmmand a truck of mass3m3m3mtravelling in opposite directions collide and stick together. The speeds of the car and the truck just before the crash are2v2v2vandvvvrespectively. What is their speed after the collision?A.14v\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{1}{4}v41​vB.45v\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{4}{5}v54​vC.54v\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5}{4}v45​vD.4v\hspace{1em}  	4v4v
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The vehicles move in opposite directions, therefore the total momentum before the collision ism(2v)+(−3m)v=−mvm(2v)+(-3m)v=-mvm(2v)+(−3m)v=−mvBy the principle of conservation of momentum, the momentum of the vehicles after the collision is equal to the total momentum before the collision.−mv=(m+3m)vf-mv=\left(m+3m\right)v_f−mv=(m+3m)vf​wherevfv_fvf​is the velocity of the vehicles after the collisions.vf=−mv4mv_f=\dfrac{-mv}{4m}vf​=4m−mv​vf=−v4v_f=\dfrac{-v}{4}vf​=4−v​Therefore the speed is14v\dfrac{1}{4}v41​v.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
The diagram below shows an object attached to a light inextensible string. The object is travelling in a horizontal circle at a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1407380-c5d8-4cf6-8000-1ed0057396fd/images/86154aae-6a39-4d62-927f-7719e616b6c7/image.png)

What is the direction of the resultant force acting on the object? Select from the labeled arrows on the diagram.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The object is moving in a circle at a constant speed so the resultant force = centripetal force. The centripetal force is directed towards the center of the circular path that the object is following. The answer is D.There are two forces acting on the object. Weight (acting in the direction C) and tension (acting in direction A). The resultant of these two forces in the vertical plane is zero. The resultant force is the horizontal component of the tension (acting in the direction D).

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Which of the following is not appropriate for measuring energy?A.\hspace{1em}JB.\hspace{1em}N mC.\hspace{1em}kg m s−2^{-2}−2D.\hspace{1em}kg m2^{2}2s−2^{-2}−2
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A. J (joule) is an accepted unit of energyB. Can be shown to represent energy using the work formula:W=FsW=FsW=Fs; in terms of units, 1 J = 1  N mC. Can analysed using Newton's Second LawF=maF=maF=ma; in terms of units, 1 N = 1 kg m s−2^{-2}−2. This is a unit of force not a unit of energy and therefore thecorrect‾\underline{\textrm{correct}}correct​answer.D. Can be shown to represent energy using work and Newton's Second Law:W=Fs=masW = Fs = masW=Fs=mas; In terms of units,
J = N m = kg m s−2^{-2}−2m = kg m2^{2}2s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
The graph below shows the variation of the resultant forceFFFacting on a box with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/5df1dc95-d879-42fa-9bf5-f4a182c14b3f/PH0579b.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/10ae312c-2976-4a62-98e5-18a7efeb0dc4/PH0579c.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9fb48b7f-abee-43b9-9d28-76767fb4650b/PH0579d.png)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The area underneath of the force-time graph gives the change in momentum of the box. Since the area increases with time at a constant rate, the momentum should increase at a constant rate. The only graph that satisfies this condition is the graph in A.Therefore, the answer is A.Alternatively, the impulse equation givesΔp=FΔt\Delta p = F \Delta tΔp=FΔt.AsFFFis a constant,Δp\Delta pΔpis directly proportional totttand a straight line through the origin is expected.

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
A point massmmmis attached to the end of a uniform beam with negligible mass and lengthlll. The beam is placed horizontally with its other end hinged from a fixed point .

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/58de076c-06f7-4703-a69d-e4979e09a47c/images/9962388e-34b4-45ae-838c-e1d191f5a8dc/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.40.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The system is released from rest and as it falls it rotates around point A.Which of the following correctly describes the magnitude of the initial angular acceleration of the system?A.\hspace{1em}lg\dfrac{l}{g}gl​B.\hspace{1em}2lg\dfrac{2l}{g}g2l​C.\hspace{1em}gl\dfrac{g}{l}lg​D.\hspace{1em}2gl\dfrac{2g}{l}l2g​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:As it is released, the beam rotates around point A due to the torque exerted by the force of gravity on the mass, a distancelllfrom A .τ=mgl\tau=mglτ=mglThe moment of inertia around point A corresponds to the one of a point mass at a distancelll:I=ml2I=m l^2I=ml2These two expressions can be substituted intoτ=Iα\tau=I\alphaτ=Iαleading to:mgl=ml2αmgl=ml^2\alphamgl=ml2αThen:α=gl\alpha=\dfrac{g}{l}α=lg​Alternatively‾\underline{\text{Alternatively}}Alternatively​:Because the beam is massless, at this instant the point massmmmcan be considered to be in freefall, with accelerationggg.angular accelerationα=ar=gl\alpha = \dfrac{a}{r} = \dfrac{g}{l}α=ra​=lg​

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
A solid sphere with radiusrrrand massmmmis rolling along a horizontal surface without slipping with an angular speedω\omegaωas shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/844bdedd-7b5b-4192-9bbf-7d01de90f21a/images/f5a92c5f-61a6-4b9a-a483-5f4c44ab6e69/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.20.53%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following correctly describes the magnitude of the linear momentum of the sphere?A.\hspace{1em}mωrm\omega rmωrB.\hspace{1em}mω2rm{\omega}^2rmω2rC.\hspace{1em}mωr2m\omega r^2mωr2D.\hspace{1em}mωr\dfrac{m\omega}{r}rmω​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Given that the sphere rolls without slipping, the center of mass is moving with a speed equal to the speed of a point on the circumference of a circle of radiusrrrrotating at an angular speedω\omegaω.vcenter=ωrv_{center}=\omega rvcenter​=ωrThe magnitude of the linear momentum (p=mvp=mvp=mv) is then:p=mωrp=m\omega rp=mωr

list.title: Question 24
list.content: As a truck is brought to rest, the brakes apply a force of5.1×1035.1 \times 10^35.1×103N. Which answer best describes the magnitude of the change in momentum of the truck if the brakes are applied for 3.0 s?A.\hspace{1em}151515kN sB.\hspace{1em}150001500015000N sC.\hspace{1em}15.315.315.3kN sD.\hspace{1em}153001530015300N s
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:NOTEthis question requires students to use their judgement to determine the best answer, using standard scientific conventions.Impulse = change in momentum =FtF \,tFtSo the magnitude of the change in momentum:Δp=(5.1×103\Delta p= (5.1 \times 10^3Δp=(5.1×103)(3.0) = 15300 N sAll responses match this quantity but the number of significant figures needs to be considered. As both of the values used in the calculation have two significant figures, there should be two significant figures in the answer.In the answer150001500015000N s, the number of significant figures is unclear. It could be 2, 3, 4 or 5. The response151515kN s clearly has two significant figures, so it is the best answer.

list.title: Question 25

The Sankey diagram below shows the energy degraded at different stages of a nuclear power plant.Which of the following sections corresponds to the stage with the highest energy degradation?

list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The arrows that turn downwards represent energy degradation. The widths are proportional to the amount of energy in that stage. The widest of these is B.

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
A football player bounced the ball off their head as shown while diving sideways:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db6d3d8f-a4f9-44a6-ac1d-3d502dc3fe03/images/625404da-8e05-4718-839c-665afe99d9b7/PH0146-1.png)

Which of the following gives a Newton's Third Law pair of forces that applies to this situation?Force 1Force 2\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the ball on the playerForce of the ball on the earth\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the player on the earthForce of the ball on the player\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the earth on the ballForce of the ball on the earth\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Force of the earth on the playerForce of the player on the ball
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The only combination of answers which mentions the correct Newton’s Third Law  force pair is C. In Newton’s Third Law force pairs always occur between only the same two objects.In this case, because the ball and Earth are not in contact, it is the gravitational force that is equal and opposite here.

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
A block of wood is placed on a rough inclined surface. Which of the diagrams below correctly represents the forces acting on the block when it is at rest?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/6fd66c35-5858-47b6-b951-7ef859c5bc49/PH0261A.png)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/1efb7d4e-b506-4e9a-b16f-c5b29f42f15e/PH0261B.png)

\hspace{1cm}\hspace{1cm}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/d118c599-94cf-4412-bd58-11ec3f440b08/PH0261C.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/371d44f4-7847-4a00-acd9-301f34fdd9b2/PH0261D.png)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Weight always acts vertically downwardsNormal reaction force is always normal (perpendicular) to the surfaceIn order to remain at rest, friction must act up the incline in order to keep the block from sliding down the incline under the action of the component of weight acting down the incline.In diagram B, friction is acting down the incline. This will result in an acceleration down the incline.In diagram C, the normal reaction is acting opposite to the weight whereas normal reaction must always be perpendicular to the contact surface.In diagram D, weight is shown to act at an angle to the vertical, whereas weight always acts vertically downwards.

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
A uniform solid beam with a length of2.002.002.00m and a weight of800800800N is placed horizontally and hinged at a wall at point O. It is supported by string AB which is attached to the beam at A and to the wall at B.

These two torques must be balanced.τweight=τtension{\tau}_{weight}={\tau}_{tension}τweight​=τtension​(1.00 m)(800 N) = (2.00 m)(Tsin⁡30°)\sin{30\degree})sin30°)T=(1.00m)(800N)(2.00m)(sin⁡30°)T=\dfrac{(1.00\textrm{ m})(800\textrm{ N})}{(2.00\textrm{ m})(\sin{30\degree})}T=(2.00m)(sin30°)(1.00m)(800N)​T=800T=800T=800N

list.title: Question 30
list.content: Observations of muon decay can be used as evidence ofI.Time dilationII.Length contractionIII.Absolute simultaneityWhich of the above statements is true?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Muons have a very short lifetime to reach the earth's surface from the upper atmosphere. But they are abundant on the Earth’s surface. This observation can be explained in two ways: Due to time dilation, from the perspective of muons, time passes more slowly, allowing them to cover more distance during their short lifetime. Alternatively, due to length contraction, the distance that muons need to travel to reach the Earth appears shorter from their perspective.

list.title: Question 32
list.content: A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of1.51.51.5m above the ground. What is the maximum height reachedabove the groundif the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s−1^{-1}−1?  (Takeg=10g=10g=10m s−2^{-2}−2)A.0.45\hspace{1em} 0.450.45mB.1.50\hspace{1em} 1.501.50mC.1.95\hspace{1em} 1.951.95mD.6.00\hspace{1em} 6.006.00m
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Solution 1:Maximum height occurs when the final speedvvvis zero. The height reached above hands=v2−u22as=0−9−20=0.45m\begin{aligned}
\ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
\ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
\ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
\end{aligned}ss​=2av2−u2​=−200−9​=0.45m​To find maximum height above the ground,0.450.450.45m+1.5+\ 1.5+1.5m = 1.95 mSolution 2:Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion12mv2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh21​mv2=mgh12(3)2=10h\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h21​(3)2=10hh=0.45h=0.45h=0.45mTo find maximum height above the ground,0.450.450.45m+1.5+\ 1.5+1.5m = 1.95 m

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
State the law of conservation of momentum.[2]A stationary body explodes into two pieces of mass asm1m_1m1​andm2m_2m2​in opposite directions.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/429bf6fe-dca5-47bd-b7e0-b199cab3baa5/images/eb3d1823-146c-4af3-9a6b-1e4afd9aafe7/PH0463.png)

Just after the explosion, the ratio of the kinetic energy ofm1m_1m1​to the kinetic energy ofm2m_2m2​is found to be 9. Calculate the ratio of massesm1m2\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}m2​m1​​.[2]
list.markScheme: When the net force on a system is zero / the system is isolated✓\checkmark✓The momentum of the system does not change / the total momentum is constant✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of the momentum of the pieces is equal✓\checkmark✓≪p22m1p22m2=9≫\ll \dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9 \gg≪2m2​p2​2m1​p2​​=9≫m1m2=19✓\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}\,\checkmarkm2​m1​​=91​✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Since the body is at rest, the total momentum before the explosion is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, total momentum after the collision must be zero. The two pieces move in the opposite directions. Therefore, the magnitude of momentum they possess must be the same to cancel each other. The ratio of kinetic energies;p22m1p22m2=9\dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 92m2​p2​2m1​p2​​=9m2m1=9\dfrac{m_2}{m_1} = 9m1​m2​​=9Therefore,m1m2=19\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}m2​m1​​=91​

list.title: Question 34
list.content: A ball of massmmmis falling vertically through the air. The drag force acting on the ball is given bykv2kv^2kv2wherekkkis constant andvvvis the speed of the ball. What is the maximum speed reached by the ball?A.kmg\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{k}{mg}mgk​B.mgk\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{mg}{k}kmg​C.kmg\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{\dfrac{k}{mg}}mgk​​D.mgk\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}kmg​​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:While the ball is falling, two opposite forces act on it. These are weight and drag. The speed of the ball increases until the drag force balances the weight. Therefore, the following expression can be written for maximum speedvmaxv_{max}vmax​:k(vmax)2=mgk(v_{max})^2=mgk(vmax​)2=mg(vmax)2=mgk(v_{max})^2=\dfrac{mg}{k}(vmax​)2=kmg​vmax=mgkv_{max}=\sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}vmax​=kmg​​Hence, the correct answer is D.

list.title: Question 35
list.content: The take off speed of a passenger aircraft is 75.0 m s−1^{-1}−1. A plane starts from rest and accelerates at a steady rate of 1.25 m s−2^{-2}−2. Which of the following correctly states the minimum duration of the acceleration, and the minimum length of the runway needed for the take off?Duration of accelerationLength of the runway\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}75.0m s−11.25m s−2\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−275.0m s−1​(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}75.0m s−11.25m s−2\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−275.0m s−1​(75.0m s−1)21.25m s−2\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−2(75.0m s−1)2​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​75.0m s−11.25m s−2\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−275.0m s−1​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:a=v−uta = \dfrac{v-u}{t}a=tv−u​⇒t=v−ua=75.0m s−1−01.25m s−2=75.0m s−11.25m s−2\hspace{2em} \Rightarrow t = \dfrac{v-u}{a} = \dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}-0}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}} = \dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}⇒t=av−u​=1.25m s−275.0m s−1−0​=1.25m s−275.0m s−1​v2=u2+2asv^2 = u^2 + 2asv2=u2+2as⇒s=v2−u22a=(75.0m s−1)2−022(1.25m s−2)=(75.0m s−1)22(1.25m s−2)\hspace{2em} \Rightarrow s = \dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a} = \dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2-0^2}{2(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})} = \dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{2(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}⇒s=2av2−u2​=2(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2−02​=2(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​

list.title: Question 37
list.content: Two eggs of equal mass fall from the same height onto a padded floor. One of them is broken while the other one bounces upwards intact. The time of collision is the same for both. Which of the following correctly describes the egg that exerts a greater averge force on the floor and the reason?Egg with greater average forceReason\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}BrokenGreater change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}BouncesLess change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}BrokenLess change in momentum\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}BouncesGreater change in momentum
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:As the direction of motion of the bouncing egg is changed after the collision, it has a greater change in velocity than the egg that breaks. Therefore, its has a greter change in momentum.The time of collision is the same for both situations. According toF=ΔpΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}F=ΔtΔp​, the force acting on the egg that bounces back is greater. By using Newton’s third law, it can be stated that the average force acting on the floor from the bouncing egg is greater.

list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The wheel starts from restωi=0ω_i=0ωi​=0Each revolution corresponds to angular displacement of2π2\pi2πradThereforeωf=(5)(2)π=10πω_f=(5)(2)π=10\piωf​=(5)(2)π=10πrad s−1^{-1}−1The angular displacement after161616s isΔθ=ωf+ωi2t\Delta \theta=\dfrac{ω_f+ω_i}{2} tΔθ=2ωf​+ωi​​tΔθ=(10π+02)(16)=80π\Delta \theta=  \bigg(\dfrac{10π+0}{2}\bigg) (16)=80\piΔθ=(210π+0​)(16)=80πrad

list.title: Question 39
list.content: An object sits on a rotating horizontal disc of radiusrrr. The disc rotates from rest with uniform angular accelerationα\alphaα. After timetttthe object slides off of the disc.What is the linear speed of the object at this time?A.αt\hspace{1em}  \alpha tαtB.rαt\hspace{1em}  r\alpha trαtC.12αt2\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{2}\alpha t^221​αt2D.12rαt2\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{2}r\alpha t^221​rαt2
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The angular speed after timetttisωf=ωi+αt\omega_f=\omega_i+\alpha tωf​=ωi​+αtωf=αt\omega_f =\alpha tωf​=αtThe linear speed is given byv=ωrv=\omega rv=ωrv=αtr=rαtv=\alpha tr = r\alpha tv=αtr=rαt

list.title: Question 40
list.content: Small marbles with equal mass but different diameters are released in liquids with different densities. Which of the following combinations of marble and the density of the liquid will result in the shortest time for the marble to fall a given height?  Assume that in all cases the marbles sink in the liquid and the viscosity of the liquid is constant.\hspace{1.5em}Diameter of the marble\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}The density of the liquid\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Smaller diameterLower density\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Greater diameterLower density\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Smaller diameterHigher density\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Greater diameterHigher density
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A released marble can cover the same distance in a shorter time when it has greater acceleration. To get greater acceleration, the resultant force downward should be bigger. Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards. Note that because the marbles are stated to have equal masses, the downwards force of gravity on both marbles is the same.The buoyant force:Fb=VρgF_b = V\rho gFb​=VρgWeight:W=mgW=mgW=mgDrag:Fd=6πηrvF_d = 6\pi \eta rvFd​=6πηrvThe resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​:Fnet=mg−(Vρg+6πηrv)F_{net}=mg-(V\rho g+6\pi \eta rv)Fnet​=mg−(Vρg+6πηrv)Based on the equation above, when the drag force or buoyancy is reduced, the resultant force becomes greater. As the density of the liquid decreases, the magnitude of the buoyant force decreases.Moreover, a decrease in diameter directly leads to a decrease in drag force and buoyancy.Alternatively, if we consider the terminal velocity, this results when the net force is zero.ThereforeFg=Fd+FbF_g = F_d+F_bFg​=Fd​+Fb​mg=ρVg+6πηrvmg = \rho V g+6\pi \eta rvmg=ρVg+6πηrvSolving for terminal velocity givesv=mg−ρVg6πηrv = \dfrac{mg-\rho V g}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrmg−ρVg​Substituting the fomula for the volume of a spherev=mg−ρ(43πr3)g6πηrv = \dfrac{mg-\rho (\frac{4}{3} \pi r^3) g}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrmg−ρ(34​πr3)g​We see that asrrrincreases, the numerator will at some point reach zero. This will be the point at which the density of the marble equals the density of the fluid. We are told that the marble always sinks, and so the numerator must remain positive.Looking at the expression, decreasingrrrwill have the effect of both increasing the numerator (thus increasing the velocity) and decreasing the denominator (also increasing the velocity).

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
A spring with spring constantkkkis extended by a distancexxx.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c10d0f-876b-4ad3-8025-7af70691d5b7/images/b7cb87cb-4bf9-4e63-9b30-1a5a397b29ca/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.19.25%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]\small{\textrm{[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]}}[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]The uncertainty ofkkkis 2% and that ofxxxis 3%.What is the uncertainty of the potential energy stored in the spring?A.\hspace{1em}8%B.\hspace{1em}11%C.\hspace{1em}12%D.\hspace{1em}18%
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The formula for potential energy stored isEH=12kx2E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2EH​=21​kx2SinceEHE_HEH​is calculated from multiplyingkkkandx2x^2x2(ignoring the constant12\frac{1}{2}21​as there is no uncertainty for it), then the uncertainty ofEHE_HEH​is calculated by adding the fractional uncertainties ofx2x^2x2andkkk.The fractional uncertainty ofx2x^2x2is double the fractional uncertainty onxxx, which gives2×3%=6%2\times3\% = 6\%2×3%=6%The uncertainty ofEPE_PEP​therefore2% + 6% = 8%

list.title: Question 42

The diagram shows the path of a football kicked from the ground.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/77913ebb-9bae-4e51-930d-46be726c3b93/images/38a80183-388d-4a4e-ba55-7b1ef3d0ed2c/Screenshot%202025-03-24%20at%205.29.42%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Air resistance is negligible. Which of the arrowsAAA,BBB,CCC, orDDDrepresent the direction of the acceleration of the ball at the instant in time shown?
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In the absence of air resistance, gravity is the only force acting on the object so its acceleration acts downwards towards the centre of the Earth.The vertical velocity of the ball is decreasing whilst its horizontal velocity remains the same.

list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:There are two forces acting on the pilot which are the gravitational force (weight) and the normal force of the pilot's chair.The normal force always acts from the chair onto the person. list.title: Question 47
list.content:
The graph below shows the angular momentumLLLof a rotating solid object against time.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/acac60b0-27ab-45d7-8acb-32d84d999a86/images/6ca1d35a-89c8-4311-be89-4a82c85c7486/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2010.49.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Which of the following correctly describes the gradient of the graph?A.\hspace{1em}Angular accelerationB.\hspace{1em}Angular speedC.\hspace{1em}Moment of inertiaD.\hspace{1em}Net torque
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The gradient of the graph corresponds to:gradient=ΔLtime=\dfrac{\Delta L}{\text{time}}=timeΔL​The change in angular momentumΔL\Delta LΔLcan be expressed asIΔωI \Delta \omegaIΔω.gradient=IΔωtime=\dfrac{I\Delta \omega}{\text{time}}=timeIΔω​The ratioΔωtime\dfrac{\Delta \omega}{\text{time}}timeΔω​corresponds to the (average) angular acceleration which in this case, given that the graph is linear, is constant.gradient=Iα=I\alpha=IαThis corresponds to the net torque acting on the object.

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
Two cyclists,AAAandBBB, start riding their bicycles from the same point. CyclistAAAmoves northwards with a speed of4v4v4vrelative to the ground, and cyclistBBBmoves westwards with a speed of3v3v3vrelative to the ground.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bada75c2-c1aa-4148-9fc7-3824f39d839b/images/d5c50ae3-4f09-41f4-93c8-aae1736da3ba/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%209.00.56%E2%80%AFAM.png)

The magnitude of the velocity of the CyclistAAArelative to the CyclistBBBisA.v\hspace{1em}  vvB.4v\hspace{1em}  4v4vC.5v\hspace{1em}  5v5vD.7v\hspace{1em}  7v7v
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Galilean relativity;u′=u−vu^\prime=u-vu′=u−vWhereu′u^\primeu′is the velocity of cyclistAAArelative to theBBB,uuuis velocity of the cyclistAAArelative to the ground andvvvis velocity of the cyclistBBBrelative to the ground. Since velocity is a vector quantity, directions should be considered. By using head to tail method, the following diagram shows the resultant vectoru′u^\primeu′:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bada75c2-c1aa-4148-9fc7-3824f39d839b/images/4be419bd-a727-4f54-8f19-a3ff7db46bd9/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2010.55.15%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

By using Pythagorean theorem:u′=(3v)2+(4v)2=5vu^\prime=\sqrt{{(3v)}^2+{(4v)}^2}=5vu′=(3v)2+(4v)2​=5v

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
A stone attached to one end of a rod rotates in a vertical circle at a constant speed. Two positions of the stone at two different instants, X and Y, are shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d4352f8d-c820-4f4d-bca6-df53ec8d5067/images/791ea751-6d76-46b7-bc0b-d17159b63e87/PH0231-1.png)

In the table below, which row is correct for the centripetal force acting on the stone at X and Y?\hspace{1em}Direction of centripetal force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Magnitude of centripetal force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}SameSame\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}SameDifferent\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}DifferentSame\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}DifferentDifferent
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The centripetal force on an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always towards the centre of the circle therefore the direction is different at the different locations. The magnitude of centripetal force is dependent on the radius of the circular path and the speed of the object. Since both locations have the same radius and speed, the magnitude of centripetal force is constant throughout the motion. Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
A box of massmmmis pulled across a horizontal surface with a forceFFFas shown in the diagram. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the box and the surface isμ\muμ. What is the energy transferred to thermal energy while a box is moved by a distance ofddd?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d68b186d-1f20-40cd-babc-b130ca4c968e/images/195ea83c-ec2e-42af-aa16-8f5e1a02e01e/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.10.31%E2%80%AFAM2.JPEG)

A.\hspace{1em}FdFdFdB.\hspace{1em}(F−μmg)d(F-\mu mg)d(F−μmg)dC.\hspace{1em}μmgd\mu mgdμmgdD.\hspace{1em}mgdmgdmgd
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Energy transferred to thermal energy will be the work done by the frictional force.FF=μFN=μmgF_F=\mu F_N = \mu mgFF​=μFN​=μmg(whereFN=mgF_N=mgFN​=mg)W=Fs=μmgdW = Fs = \mu mgdW=Fs=μmgd

list.title: Question 52
list.content:
The diagram below shows the total upward and downward forces acting on a hot air balloon. The relative magnitudes of the forces are drawn to scale.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df4cb97a-03e0-4bd8-a84c-8dda7444c026/images/3942c2b5-5966-4703-a368-fe8f703caa1a/PH0968Edit.png)

Below are three independent statements about the possible motion of the balloon.I.The balloon is acceleratingII.The balloon is moving upwardsIII.The balloon is moving downwardsWhich of the statements, when considered independently,couldbe true?A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I is correct - The diagram shows that the upward force is greater than the downward force. So, there is a net upward force acting on the balloon.F=maF=maF=maso there is an upward acceleration.II could be correct – Balloon could be moving upwards - acceleration is also upwards so speed of the balloon would be increasing.III could be correct – Balloon could be moving downwards - acceleration is upwards so speed of the balloon would be decreasing (deceleration).For linear motion, acceleration tells us nothing about the speed, just how the speed is changing. The balloon could be moving upwards, moving downwards or stationary.

list.content: An object moves 9 m east, then 12 m north.What is the magnitude of the total displacement of this object?A.\hspace{1em}3 mB.\hspace{1em}15 mC.\hspace{1em}21 mD.\hspace{1em}36 m
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Through vector addition,Displacement =122+92=\sqrt{12^2+9^2}=122+92​=15 m

list.title: Question 54
list.content:
The spacetime diagram below shows the worldline of an objectAAAthat moves at a constant speedvvvwith respect to a fixed reference frame.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f4ed6c7b-a883-4e78-b5e8-93045bdc5598/images/a605f189-ce9d-4f0f-8d52-4f0c6414ff50/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.09.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following best describes the value ofvvv?A.\hspace{1em}1.09×1081.09 \times 10^81.09×108m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}2.10×1082.10  \times 10^82.10×108m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}3.67×1083.67 \times 10^83.67×108m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}6.71×1086.71 \times 10^86.71×108m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The tangent of the angle of the wordline with the ct-axis gives the speed, expressed in units of the speed of light.This is described by the equation below:tan⁡θ=vc\tan{\theta} = \dfrac{v}{c}tanθ=cv​The value ofθ\thetaθthat must be used in this case is20°20\degree20°:v=ctan⁡(20°)v=c\tan{(20\degree)}v=ctan(20°)v=1.09×108v=1.09\times10^8v=1.09×108m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 55
list.content: A car is travelling along a straight line for a total time of 100 s. Throughout this time the driving force provided by the car is 1.2 kN and the total resistive force acting on the car is 500 N.Which row correctly shows the rate of change of momentum and the impulse of the car during the 100 s.Rate of change of momentumImpulse\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}7×102\times 10{^2}×102kg m s−2{^{-2}}−27×100\times 10{^0}×100kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}7×102\times 10{^2}×102kg m s−2{^{-2}}−27×104\times 10{^4}×104kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}1.7×103\times 10{^3}×103kg m s−2{^{-2}}−21.7×101\times 10{^1}×101kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}1.7×103\times 10{^3}×103kg m s−2{^{-2}}−21.7×105\times 10{^5}×105kg m s−1{^{-1}}−1
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Newton's second law states that net force = rate of change of momentum.Therefore, the rate of change of momentum is simply the net force acting on the carΔpΔt=1200\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=1200ΔtΔp​=1200N - 500 N = 700 N = 700 kg m s−2=7×102^{-2}=7 \times 10^2−2=7×102kg m s−2^{-2}−2ImpulseJJJ=FnetΔtF_{net}\Delta tFnet​Δt= (700)(100) = 7×\times×10410{^4}104kg m s−1^{-1}−1

Att=2.0t = 2.0t=2.0s, the ball has travelled a distancexxxin the horizontal direction and a distanceyyyin the vertical direction.What are the horizontal and vertical distances covered att=1.0t = 1.0t=1.0s, in terms ofxxxandyyy?Horizontal distanceVertical distance\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}x2\dfrac{x}{2}2x​y4\dfrac{y}{4}4y​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}x2\dfrac{x}{2}2x​y2\dfrac{y}{2}2y​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}x4\dfrac{x}{4}4x​y2\dfrac{y}{2}2y​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}x4\dfrac{x}{4}4x​y4\dfrac{y}{4}4y​

list.title: Question 58
list.content:
An object of mass 3 kg is traveling at velocity of +10 m s−1^{-1}−1horizontally. The object explodes into two fragments of mass 1 kg and 2 kg. After explosion, the 1 kg fragment has a horizontal velocity of +30 m s−1^{-1}−1and a vertical velocity +20 m s−1^{-1}−1. This is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/726d8f7f-c38d-4f90-846a-264dc5f9390d/images/74ebdb9c-e95a-4274-b0e1-cfcf6b470874/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.20.48%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following correctly shows the horizontal and vertical components of the momentum of the 2 kg fragment after the explosion?Assume no external forces act on the object.Horizontal momentum /kg m s−1\textrm{kg m s}^{-1}kg m s−1Vertical momentum /kg m s−1\textrm{kg m s}^{-1}kg m s−1\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}−30-30−30−10-10−10\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}−30-30−30−20-20−20\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}0−10-10−10\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}0−20-20−20
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Momentum is conserved in an isolated system so here momentum before collision = momentum after collision.Horizontal and vertical directions are independent, momentum is conserved in both.Inthehorizontaldirection\textbf{In the horizontal direction}In the horizontal direction:Initial momentum=mv=(3)(10)=30= mv=(3)(10)=30=mv=(3)(10)=30kg m s−1^{-1}−1Final momentum=30=(1)(30)+= 30 =(1)(30)+=30=(1)(30)+horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragmentHorizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment=0=0=0Intheverticaldirection\textbf{In the vertical direction}In the vertical direction:Initial momentum=0=0=0Final momentum=0=(1)(20)+= 0 =(1)(20)+=0=(1)(20)+horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragmentHorizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment =−20-20−20kg m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 59
list.content:

The block travels through a distance of 16 m and is brought to rest. What is the magnitude of the frictional force that brings the block to rest?A.\hspace{1em}2 NB.\hspace{1em}4 NC.\hspace{1em}8 ND.\hspace{1em}16 N
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The net work done on the block= Change in kinetic energy of the blockWnet=ΔEkFscos⁡(θ)=12m(vf)2−12m(vi)2Fscos⁡(θ)=0−12m(vi)2(F)(16)(cos⁡180o)=−12(16)(2)2(F)(16)(−1)=−32F=2N\begin{aligned}
 W_{net}&=\Delta E_k \\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 Fs \cos(\theta)& = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f)^2 - \frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\Fs\cos(\theta) &= 0 -\frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(\cos\,180^o)&=-\frac{1}{2}(16)(2)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(-1)&=-32 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
F&=2\textrm{ N}\
\end{aligned}Wnet​Fscos(θ)Fscos(θ)(F)(16)(cos180o)(F)(16)(−1)F​=ΔEk​=21​m(vf​)2−21​m(vi​)2=0−21​m(vi​)2=−21​(16)(2)2=−32=2N​Alternative:v2=u2+2as⇒a=v2−u22s=02−222(16)=−0.125v^2 = u^2 + 2as \Rightarrow a = \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2s} = \dfrac{0^2 - 2^2}{2(16)} = -0.125v2=u2+2as⇒a=2sv2−u2​=2(16)02−22​=−0.125m s−2^{-2}−2∣F∣=m∣a∣=16∣−0.125∣=2|F| = m|a| = 16|-0.125| = 2∣F∣=m∣a∣=16∣−0.125∣=2N

list.title: Question 60
list.content: The engine of a racing  car provides a forward thrust of 800 N. The average of the total resistive forces acting on the car is 300 N and the car covers a distance of 1.0 km in 10 s.What is the average power input of the engine?A.5.0×103\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^35.0×103WB.8.0×103\hspace{1em}  	8.0\times{10}^38.0×103WC.5.0×104\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^45.0×104WD.8.0×104\hspace{1em}  8.0\times{10}^48.0×104W
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The distance covered by the car in meters;1km=10001\ \ce{km}=10001km=1000mThe average speedvavv_{av}vav​of the car;vav=st=1000m10s=100v_{av}=\dfrac{s}{t}=\dfrac{1000\textrm{ m}}{10\textrm{ s}}=100vav​=ts​=10s1000m​=100m s−1^{-1}−1The average output powerPavP_{av}Pav​of the engine;Pav=FvavP_{av}=Fv_{av} \hspace{2em}Pav​=Fvav​whereF=800\hspace{2em}F=800F=800N since it is the force of the enginePav=(800)(100)=8.0×104P_{av}=\left(800\right)\left(100\right)=8.0\times{10}^4Pav​=(800)(100)=8.0×104WNote that this power from the engine does not all contribute to the kinetic energy of the car, as some of it is used to overcome the resistive forces.

list.title: Question 61
list.content: An electric motor is used to raise a block of mass 18.0 kg vertically to the top of a building at a constant speed of 1.5 m s−1^{-1}−1. If the power rating of the motor is 297 W, calculate the efficiency of the motor. Assumeg=10g=10g=10N kg−1^{-1}−1.A.\hspace{1em}9%B.\hspace{1em}75%C.\hspace{1em}61%D.\hspace{1em}91%
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Efficiency is the ratio of power output to power input expressed as a percentage.Pinput=297P_{input} = 297Pinput​=297WForce =mg=(18kg)(10N kg−1)=180mg = (18\textrm{ kg})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})= 180mg=(18kg)(10N kg−1)=180NPoutputP_{output}Poutput​= (Force)(Velocity) =(180N)(1.50m)1s\dfrac{(180\textrm{ N})(1.50\textrm{ m})}{1\textrm{ s}}1s(180N)(1.50m)​= 270 WEfficiency=PoweroutputPowerinput×100Efficiency=\dfrac{Power\,output}{Power\,input} \times 100Efficiency=PowerinputPoweroutput​×100η=270W297W×\eta = \dfrac{270\,\ce{W}}{297\,\ce{W}}\,\timesη=297W270W​×100% = 91%

list.title: Question 62
list.content: A cosmic particle passing an observer on Earth spontaneously decays3.0×10−93.0\times10^{-9}3.0×10−9s after passing the observer, as measured in the particle's frame of reference. The particle is travelling at0.800.800.80c in the observer's frame of reference. Calculate the distance, in the particle's frame of reference, that the particle travels between passing the observer and when it decays.[2]Calculate the time between the cosmic particle passing Earth and when it decays, as measured by an observer on Earth.[2]Calculate the distance the cosmic particle travels between passing the observer and decaying, according to an observer on Earth.[1]
list.markScheme: speed=2.4×108=2.4\times10^8=2.4×108m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓distance = (speed)(proper time)=(2.4×108)(3.0×10−9)=0.72m=(2.4\times10^8)(3.0\times10^{-9}) =\ \answer{0.72\ \ce{m}}=(2.4×108)(3.0×10−9)=0.72m​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:We need to find the distance the particle travles in its own frame of reference (the proper time frame), using the formula:distance = speed×\times×proper timeThe particle is travelling at0.80.80.8c. Therefore:speed = 0.8c=(0.8)(3×108)=2.4×108=(0.8)(3\times10^8)=2.4\times10^8=(0.8)(3×108)=2.4×108m s−1^{-1}−1Substituting in the values from the question:distance=(2.4×108)(3.0×10−9)=0.72=(2.4\times10^8)(3.0\times10^{-9})=0.72=(2.4×108)(3.0×10−9)=0.72mγ=11−v2c2=10.6\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}γ=1−c2v2​​1​=0.61​✓\checkmark✓t=γt0=(10.6)(3×10−9)=5×10−9s✓t=\gamma t_0=\left(\dfrac{1}{0.6}\right)(3\times10^{-9})=\answer{5\times10^{-9} \  \ce{s}} \ \checkmarkt=γt0​=(0.61​)(3×10−9)=5×10−9s​✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To calculate the time measured by the observer on Earth, we need to apply time dilation from special relativity.First, calculate the Lorentz factor,γ\gammaγ:γ=11−v2c2=11−0.82c2c2=11−0.64=10.6\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{0.8^2c^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}γ=1−c2v2​​1​=1−c20.82c2​​1​=1−0.64​1​=0.61​Now use the time dilation formula to find the time measured by the observer on Earth:t=γt0=(10.6)(3×10−9)=5×10−9t=\gamma t_0=\left(\dfrac{1}{0.6}\right)(3\times10^{-9})=5\times10^{-9}t=γt0​=(0.61​)(3×10−9)=5×10−9sdistance=(2.4×108)(5×10−9)=\hspace{1.8em}\textrm{distance}=(2.4\times10^8)(5\times10^{-9})=distance=(2.4×108)(5×10−9)=1.2 mFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To find the distance travelled as measured by an observer on Earth, we must use:distance = speed×\times×timewhere time is that measured by the observer on Earth.Therefore:distance=(2.4×108)(5×10−9)=1.2=(2.4\times10^8)(5\times10^{-9})=1.2=(2.4×108)(5×10−9)=1.2m

Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Since the new muon is created in a different vertical position, it should be having a different starting position from the existing muon. Additionally, the gradient shows the reciprocal of the speed. Therefore, the gradient of the new muon's worldline should be more than the gradient of the existing muon's worldline.

Even though observers in different frames may measure different space and time coordinates and are moving at different speeds relative to each other, they will all calculate the same spacetime interval between two events.\hspace{1.8em}(Δs)2=c2Δt2−Δx2=(3×108)2(4×10−6)2−6302(\Delta s)^2=c^2\Delta t^2-\Delta x^2=(3\times10^8)^2(4\times10^{-6})^2-630^2(Δs)2=c2Δt2−Δx2=(3×108)2(4×10−6)2−6302✓\checkmark✓(Δs)2=1.04×106≪(\Delta s)^2= \answer{1.04\times10^6} \ll(Δs)2=1.04×106​≪m2≫^2\gg2≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To calculate the space-time interval, we use the equation:(Δs)2=c2Δt2−Δx2(\Delta s)^2=c^2\Delta t^2-\Delta x^2(Δs)2=c2Δt2−Δx2For the two events:Δt=4×10−6\Delta t=4\times10^{-6}Δt=4×10−6sΔx=xB−xA=750−120=630\Delta x=x_B-x_A=750-120=630Δx=xB​−xA​=750−120=630mSubstituting the values:(Δs)2=(3×108)2(4×10−6)2−6302=1.04×106(\Delta s)^2=(3\times10^8)^2(4\times10^{-6})^2-630^2=1.04\times10^6(Δs)2=(3×108)2(4×10−6)2−6302=1.04×106\hspace{1.8em}ct=(3×108)(4×10−6)=1200ct=(3\times10^8)(4\times10^{-6})=1200ct=(3×108)(4×10−6)=1200m✓\checkmark✓A=(x=120,ct=0)A=(x=120, ct=0)A=(x=120,ct=0)✓\checkmark✓B=(x=750,ct=1200)B=(x=750, ct=1200)B=(x=750,ct=1200)✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To find the y=coordinate for eventBBB, we need to calculatectctct:ct=(3×108)(4×10−6)=1200ct=(3\times10^8)(4\times10^{-6})=1200ct=(3×108)(4×10−6)=1200mTherefore, the correct x- and y=values for eventsAAAandBBBare:A=(x=120,ct=0)A=(x=120, ct=0)A=(x=120,ct=0)B=(x=750,ct=1200)B=(x=750, ct=1200)B=(x=750,ct=1200)

Determine the distance betweenAAAandBBB.[3]It is observed that the force required to start the block moving again is greater than the force required to keep it moving at a constant speed. Explain this observation.[1]

x)^2EH​=21​k(Δx)2Wherekkkis the spring constant andxxxis the extension or compression of the spring.Substituting in our values gives:EH=12k(Δx)2=12(85)(0.08)2=0.272E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(85)(0.08)^2=0.272EH​=21​k(Δx)2=21​(85)(0.08)2=0.272JNow substituting these values into the equation given in part (a)(i) we have:vb=0.2723(0.12)=0.87v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{0.272}{3(0.12)}}=0.87vb​=3(0.12)0.272​​=0.87m s−1^{-1}−1a=≪−≫μdmgm=≪−≫(0.07)(9.81)=≪−≫0.687a=\ll-\gg\dfrac{\mu_dmg}{m}=\ll-\gg(0.07)(9.81)=\ll-\gg0.687a=≪−≫mμd​mg​=≪−≫(0.07)(9.81)=≪−≫0.687m s−2^{-2}−2(3sf)✓\checkmark✓s=v2−u22a=02−0.7122(−0.687)=0.37s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37s=2av2−u2​=2(−0.687)02−0.712​=0.37m✓\checkmark✓ORμdmgs=12mv2\mu_dmgs=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2μd​mgs=21​mv2✓\checkmark✓s=0.7122(0.687)=s=\dfrac{0.71^2}{2(0.687)}=s=2(0.687)0.712​=0.370.370.37m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The net force acting on the block is equal to the frictional force given by:Ff=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​Whereμd\mu_dμd​is the coefficient of dynamic friction andFNF_NFN​is the normal reaction force.The net vertical force is zero so the normal reaction force acting on the block is equal to its weight:FN=mgF_N=mgFN​=mgFf=μdmgF_f=\mu_dmgFf​=μd​mgNet force:Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=maWheremmmis the mass of the block andaaais its acceleration. The net force on the block is negative as it acts in the opposite direction to the block's velocity:ma=−μdmgma=-\mu_dmgma=−μd​mga=−μdga=-\mu_dga=−μd​ga=−(0.07)(9.81)=−0.6867a=-(0.07)(9.81)=-0.6867a=−(0.07)(9.81)=−0.6867m s−2^{-2}−2Now for constant acceleration we have:v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asWherevvvis final velocity,uuuis initial velocity,aaais acceleration andsssis displacement. Rearranging forsssand substituting our values we have:v2−u2=2asv^2-u^2=2asv2−u2=2ass=v2−u22a=02−0.7122(−0.687)=0.37s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37s=2av2−u2​=2(−0.687)02−0.712​=0.37mAlternatively, we can use conservation of energy. The block loses all its kinetic energy due to work done by friction.Work done by friction is given by:W=FsW = FsW=FsAnd the force of friction can be found from:Ff=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​FN=mgF_N=mgFN​=mgFf=μdmgF_f=\mu_dmgFf​=μd​mgEquating the change in kinetic energy to the work done by friction gives:μdmgs=12mv2\mu_dmgs=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2μd​mgs=21​mv2Solving forsssleads to the same equation as the other solution:s=v2−u22a=02−0.7122(−0.687)=0.37s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37s=2av2−u2​=2(−0.687)02−0.712​=0.37mcoefficient of static friction/ maximum static frictional force is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction/dynamic frictional force.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When an object is already in motion, the dynamic frictional force opposes its motion and remains constant. However, when the object is at rest, the static frictional force prevents it from moving.Static friction can take any value up to its maximum limit, which is given by:Ff=μsFNF_f=\mu_sF_NFf​=μs​FN​whereμs\mu_sμs​is the coefficient of static friction andFNF_NFN​is the normal reaction force.The coefficient of static friction is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction, so the maximum static frictional force is also greater than the dynamic frictional force. This means that more force is required to start on object moving from rest than is required to keep it moving at a constant speed against a dynamic frictional force.

list.title: Question 70
list.content: An electron is accelerated up to a speed of4.75×1074.75 \times 10^74.75×107m s−1^{-1}−1. It  then travels through a gap in the accelerator of width8.008.008.00mm, as measured in the frame of reference of the accelerator.EventsAAAandBBBare defined as follows:EventAAA: electron enters the gap;EventBBB: electron exits the gap.Which of the following best describes the proper time between eventsAAAandBBB?A.\hspace{1em}1.26×10−121.26 \times 10^{-12}1.26×10−12sB.\hspace{1em}1.71×10−121.71 \times 10^{-12}1.71×10−12sC.\hspace{1em}1.15×10−101.15 \times 10^{-10}1.15×10−10sD.\hspace{1em}1.66×10−101.66 \times 10^{-10}1.66×10−10s
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The proper time,Δt0\Delta t_0Δt0​, corresponds to the time between events, as seen from the reference frame of the electron, where both events occur at the same point in space.From the data booklet,Δt=γΔt0\Delta t = \gamma \Delta t_0Δt=γΔt0​Solving for proper time givesΔt0=Δtγ\Delta t_0 = \dfrac{\Delta t}{\gamma}Δt0​=γΔt​Δt0=Δt1−v2c2\Delta t_0 = \Delta t \sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}Δt0​=Δt1−c2v2​​As seen from the reference frame of the gap:Δt=8.00×10−3m4.75×107ms−1\Delta t = \dfrac{8.00 \times 10^{-3}\,\ce{m}}{4.75 \times 10^{7}\,\ce{m s}^{-1}}Δt=4.75×107ms−18.00×10−3m​By substituting this expression forΔt\Delta tΔtin the previous equality we get:Δt0=8.00×10−3m4.75×107ms−11−(4.75×107ms−1)2(3.00×108ms−1)2\Delta t_0= \dfrac{8.00 \times 10^{-3}\,\ce{m}}{4.75 \times 10^{7}\,\ce{m s}^{-1}} \sqrt{1 - \dfrac{(4.75 \times 10^7\,\ce{m s}^{-1})^2}{(3.00 \times 10^8\,\ce{m s}^{-1})^2}}Δt0​=4.75×107ms−18.00×10−3m​1−(3.00×108ms−1)2(4.75×107ms−1)2​​Δt0=1.66×10−10\Delta t_0 = 1.66 \times 10^{-10}\,Δt0​=1.66×10−10s

The magnitude of the total of the opposing forces is161616N. What is the force of gravity acting on the box?A.8sin⁡θ\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{8}{\sin\theta}sinθ8​B.16sin⁡θ\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{16}{\sin\theta}sinθ16​C.8cos⁡θ\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{8}{\cos\theta}cosθ8​D.16cos⁡θ\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{16}{\cos\theta}cosθ16​

BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The box is moving at a constant speed. According to Newton’s First Law, the resultant force acting on the box must be zero. The free body diagram of the forces acting on the box:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18595241-7849-4c02-a19c-712cdb369317/images/fb785bfc-58f2-4616-b01f-1014614efe2a/PH0547-1.png)

Weight (FgF_gFg​) has two components (shown in red): perpendicular to the slope and parallel to the slope. From the diagram:Fgcos⁡θ=FNF_g\cos\theta=F_N \hspace{2em}Fg​cosθ=FN​andFgsin⁡θ=16\hspace{2em}F_g\sin\theta=16Fg​sinθ=16ThereforeFg=16sin⁡θF_g=\dfrac{16}{\sin\theta}Fg​=sinθ16​

list.title: Question 72
list.content: A rocket ejects hot gas in space in a direction opposite to its travelling direction. What is correct for the magnitude of the momentum and the kinetic energy of the rocket?MomentumKinetic Energy\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}ConservedConserved\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}IncreasedConserved\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}ConservedIncreased\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}IncreasedIncreased
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The rocket is not a closed system. The reaction force from ejecting hot gas will increasingly accelerate the rocket, hence both momentum and kinetic energy will increase.

list.title: Question 73
list.content:
An object of mass 10 kg is released from rest. The object explodes into three fragments X, Y and Z after falling a distance of 46 m. Show that the momentum of the object just before the explosion is around 300 kg m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Assume air resistance is negligible.Discuss whether mechanical energy is conserved in an explosion.[2]Immediately after the explosion, fragment X has a mass of 2 kg and a velocity of 50 m s−1^{-1}−1to the right. Fragment Y has a mass of 3 kg and velocity of 10 m s−1^{-1}−1vertically upwards. Fragment Z has a velocityvvvat an angleθ\thetaθbelow the horizontal. This is illustrated below.

This collision causes the trolley to move with a velocityVVV. Explain whyVVVindependent ofhhh.[2]Air resistance is negligible.

(v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asor12mv2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2=mgh21​mv2=mgh) andp=mvp=mvp=mv✓\checkmark✓p=mv=10(2)(9.8)(46)=300kg m s−1p=mv=10\sqrt{(2)(9.8)(46)}=\answer{300\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}}p=mv=10(2)(9.8)(46)​=300kg m s−1​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asInitial velocityu=0u=0u=0and accelerationa=9.8m s−2a=9.8\textrm{ m s}^{-2}a=9.8m s−2v=2as=(2)(9.8)(46)=30.02v=\sqrt{2as}=\sqrt{(2)(9.8)(46)}=30.02v=2as​=(2)(9.8)(46)​=30.02p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2kg m s−1p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2kg m s−1Alternatively‾\underline{\textrm{Alternatively}}Alternatively​12mv2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2=mgh21​mv2=mgh12v2=gh\dfrac{1}{2}v^2=gh21​v2=ghv=2gh=(2)(9.8)(46)=30.02v=\sqrt{2gh}=\sqrt{(2)(9.8)(46)}=30.02v=2gh​=(2)(9.8)(46)​=30.02p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2kg m s−1p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2kg m s−1Chemical/potential energy is released from the object / converted to kinetic energy / kinetic energy increases✓\checkmark✓Mechanical energy is sum of kinetic and gravitational potential energy therefore it is not conserved✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Momentum and energy are always conserved.In an explosion momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not. Total energy is still conserved. Chemical or potential energy can be stored inside objects. When a chemical reaction that releases energy takes place inside an object, this energy can be transferred into kinetic energy of the object (or objects if it is split into fragments).Mechanical θ=tan⁡−16620=73.1°\theta = \tan^{-1}{\dfrac{66}{20}} = 73.1\degreeθ=tan−12066​=73.1°The horizontal velocity of the fragment will be independent of height / remain the same because acceleration due to gravity is purely vertical/downwards.✓\checkmark✓(When the fragment collides with the trolley) only horizontal momentum is transferred to the trolley / trolley is unable to move in vertical direction / vertical momentum will be transferred to ground/Earth.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Horizontal and vertical dimensions are independent. The fragment will follow a projectile path. Its vertical velocity will increase, and its horizontal velocity will remain the same.The trolley's motion is restricted in the vertical direction due to the ground, so the vertical momentum of the fragment will be transferred to the Earth and the trolley - relative to the Earth the trolley will not move in the vertical direction. Horizontal momentum of the fragment will be transferred to the trolley causing it to move along the flat ground.

list.title: Question 74
list.content: A table tennis ball of massmmmis dropped on a level surface from a heightHHH. The ball rebounds to a heighth<Hh < Hh<Hafter impact. Air resistance on the ball is negligible. Which of the following is correct about the nature of the collision and magnitude of the change in momentum (Δp\Delta pΔp) of the ball as a result of this impact?Nature of the collisionChange in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Elasticm(2gH−2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​−2gh​)\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Inelasticm(2gH−2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​−2gh​)\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Elasticm(2gH+2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​+2gh​)\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Inelasticm(2gH+2gh)m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})m(2gH​+2gh​)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The height of rebound is less than the height of release. This is evidence that some energy is dissipated at the point of impact. Hence inelastic.We can use conservation of energy to find the velocity upon impact:mgH=12mu2mgH=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2mgH=21​mu2u2=2gHu^2 =2gHu2=2gHu=2gHu=\sqrt{2gH}u=2gH​Similarly, the velocity just after impact is:v=−2ghv=-\sqrt{2gh} \hspace{2em}v=−2gh​Where the negative sign represents the opposite direction touuu(upwards)∴Δp=∣mv−mu∣\therefore \Delta p=|mv-mu|∴Δp=∣mv−mu∣=∣m(v−u)∣=|m(v-u)|=∣m(v−u)∣=m∣(−2gh−2gH)∣=m|(-\sqrt{2gh}-\sqrt{2gH})|=m∣(−2gh​−2gH​)∣Removing the absolute value gives=m(2gH+2gh)=m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})=m(2gH​+2gh​)

list.title: Question 75
list.content:
The graph below shows how the acceleration of an objectaaavaries with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/225978ea-87fb-406a-9dc7-0b898236dcf3/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.16.39%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the change in speed of the object?A.\hspace{1em}7.07.07.0m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}28.028.028.0m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}42.042.042.0m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}56.056.056.0m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in speed is the magnitude of the area under an acceleration-time graph.To find the area under the graph we can split it into two sections.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/7a3ccd6a-bb00-4cc1-bb74-81d58abd51b8/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.17.41%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Section 1 is a rectangle. Area=(4)(7)=28=(4)(7)=28=(4)(7)=28m s−1^{-1}−1Section 2 is a triangle. Area=12(4)(7)=14= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(7)=14=21​(4)(7)=14m s−1^{-1}−1Total area=28+14=42= 28+14=42=28+14=42m s−1^{-1}−1Alternative solution‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}Alternative solution​This can also be done in one step using the area of a trapeziumA=12(8+4)(7)=42A=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+4)(7)=42A=21​(8+4)(7)=42m s−1^{-1}−1

list.content:
Define distance.[1]An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distancedwith timetis shown on the graph below.

Describe the motion of the object betweent=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s andt=1.0t=1.0t=1.0s.[1]Calculate the instantaneous speed of the object att=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s.[2]On the axes below, sketch a possible graph of the variation of velocityvvvof the object with timettt. There is no need to add values to the axes.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/c787d9d0-d867-4d03-980d-27f4c5fbad95/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.50.32%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Determine the direction of the change in momentum of the object during the motion.[2]
list.markScheme:
Length of the path followed✓\checkmark✓Slows down/decelerates✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The slope of the graph gives the speed of the object. The slope decreases betweent=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s andt=1.0t=1.0t=1.0s. Therefore the object slows down.Any evidence for drawing tangent att=0.5st=0.5\, st=0.5s✓\checkmark✓≪28−101−0=≫18±2ms−1\ll\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=\gg18\pm2\, m\,s^{-1}≪1−028−10​=≫18±2ms−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/db214a2c-2e68-4bce-8a9a-e0cd2cc8719c/Screenshoot%202025-07-02%20at%202.52.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The gradient of the tangent line =28−101−0=18\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=181−028−10​=18m s−1^{-1}−1A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient✓\checkmark✓Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis✓\checkmark✓

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/4ba5e265-a440-45f1-81d9-62bf89b670e0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.30.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.The final momentum is less than the initial momentum✓\checkmark✓Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentumpfp_fpf​is less than the initialpip_ipi​momentum. The change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp;Δp=pf−pi\Delta p=p_f-p_iΔp=pf​−pi​sincepip_ipi​>pfp_fpf​, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

list.title: Question 77
list.content: A projectile is fired at an angle above the horizontal on the surface of Moon. Which of the following statements is correct about its motion:A.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the horizontal component of its velocity remains unchanged until it falls on the surface of the moon.B.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the vertical component of its velocity remains unchanged until it falls on the surface of the moon.C.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the horizontal component of its velocity decreases steadily until it falls on the surface of the moon.D.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the vertical component of its velocity decreases steadily until it falls on the surface of the moon.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The moon has no atmosphere. As there is no air drag, there's no change in the horizontal component of velocity. It does not decrease (making option C incorrect, and option A correct).The magnitude of vertical component decreases only while the projectile moves upwards. At its maximum height, the vertical component becomes zero and then starts increasing in the in the downward direction until it hits ground (making D incorrect).Option B is obviously incorrect as moon's gravitation keeps changing the vertical component.

In an amusement park, children enjoy a carousel ride that has a rotating platform and seats in the shape of horses on the platform. Some of the horses are closer to the centre of the platform. A top view of the ride is shown below.

In an instant, the magnitude of the rate of change of moment of inertia due to a child moving towards the centre is242424kg m2^22s−1^{-1}−1. Therefore, the angular momentumLLLof the system must be constant.L=IωL=I\omegaL=IωIf the angular momentum is to remain constant, a decrease in moment of inertia must be compensated with an increase in angular velocity.ωΔIt=(0.035)(24)\dfrac{\omega \Delta I}{t} = (0.035)(24)tωΔI​=(0.035)(24)✓\checkmark✓=0.840.840.84N m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The net torqueτ\tauτacting on the carousel is equal to the rate of change of angular momentumτ=ΔLt=Δ(Iω)t=ωΔIt=(0.035)(24)=0.84\tau = \dfrac{\Delta L}{t} = \dfrac{\Delta (I\omega)}{t} = \omega \dfrac{\Delta I }{t} = (0.035)(24) = 0.84τ=tΔL​=tΔ(Iω)​=ωtΔI​=(0.035)(24)=0.84N m
