The accleration must also therefore be downwards, so the gravitational force must be greater than the upwards normal force.The maximum speed is when the normal force is zero.✓\checkmark✓v=≪rcg≫=(18)(9.81)v=\ll\sqrt{r_cg}\gg=\sqrt{\left(18\right)(9.81)}v=≪rc​g​≫=(18)(9.81)​✓\checkmark✓v=13m s−1✓v=\answer{13\  \textrm{m s}^{-1}}\ \checkmarkv=13m s−1​✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The maximum speed at point C is when the normal force of the track on the car is zero.The normal force at CFN=mg−mv2rcF_N=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_c}FN​=mg−rc​mv2​WhenFN=0F_N = 0FN​=0mg=mv2rcmg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r_c}mg=rc​mv2​Using the given value ofr=18r=18r=18mv=rcg=(18)(9.81)=13.29m s−1v=\sqrt{r_cg}=\sqrt{(18)(9.81)}=13.29\textrm{ m s}^{-1}v=rc​g​=(18)(9.81)​=13.29m s−1

list.title: Question 130
list.content: A spacecraft is moving in a zero gravity zone in space with constant speed. Its pilot decided to accelerate by burning fuel. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed of2.5×1022.5\times{10}^22.5×102m s−1^{-1}−1relative to the rocket at a constant rate of2.0×1022.0\times{10}^22.0×102kg s−1^{-1}−1.Show that the net force on the rocket due to the ejection of burnt fuel is5×1045 \times 10^45×104N.[1]The spacecraft has a mass of4.2×1034.2\times{10}^34.2×103kg at the instant that it starts to burn the fuel. Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft after1.01.01.0s has passed.[2]The spacecraft enters the atmosphere of Mars and slows down due to friction. To decelerate its speed more to reach a safe landing speed, the operator runs a propeller that pushes against the gas in the atmosphere.By referring to Newton's Third Law, outline why there is a force acting on the spacecraft due to the propeller.[2]The average density of the Mars atmosphere is0.0200.0200.020kg m−3^{-3}−3. The radius of the propeller blades is1.21.21.2m.  At a given instant, the average force from the propeller to slow down the spacecraft is1.41.41.4kN.Assuming that the propeller causes all gas that it passes through to come to rest relative to the falling spaceship, estimate the speed of the spaceship at this instant.[4]The landing legs of the spacecraft have springs that can compress as the spacecraft makes contact with the ground. Explain how this decreases the average force acting on the spacecraft as it lands.[3]
list.markScheme:
F=Δ(mv)Δt=ΔmΔtv=(2.0×102)(2.5×102)=5.0×104F=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} v = (2.0\times{10}^2\ \ )(2.5\times{10}^2) = \answer{5.0 \times 10^4}F=ΔtΔ(mv)​=ΔtΔm​v=(2.0×102)(2.5×102)=5.0×104​<< N >>✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:From Newton's 3rd Law, the force of the rocket on the gases is equal to the force of the gases on the rocket.For the gases, the net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum.Substituting in the values will lead the net forceF=Δ(mv)Δt=ΔmΔtv=(2.0×102)(2.5×102)=5.0×104N\begin{aligned}
 F&=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{\Delta t}\\
  &= \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} v \\
  &= (2.0\times{10}^2\ \ )(2.5\times{10}^2) \\
  &= 5.0 \times 10^4\textrm{ N}\\
  \end{aligned}F​=ΔtΔ(mv)​=ΔtΔm​v=(2.0×102)(2.5×102)=5.0×104N​Mass of the rocket att=1t=1t=1s is4200−(2.0×102)(1.0)=4.0×1034200-\left(2.0\times{10}^2\right)\left(1.0\right)=4.0\times{10}^34200−(2.0×102)(1.0)=4.0×103kg✓\checkmark✓a=Fnetm=5×1044.0×103=a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{5\times{10}^4}{4.0\times{10}^3} =a=mFnet​​=4.0×1035×104​=12.512.512.5m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The total massmtm_tmt​of the rocket after111s:mt=4200−(2.0×102)×(1.0)=4.0×103m_t=4200-\left(2.0\times{10}^2\right)\times\left(1.0\right)=4.0\times{10}^3mt​=4200−(2.0×102)×(1.0)=4.0×103kgTo find the acceleration of the rocket:a=Fnetm=5×1044.0×103=12.5a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{5\times{10}^4}{4.0\times{10}^3}=12.5a=mFnet​​=4.0×1035×104​=12.5m s−2^{-2}−2Propellor exerts a force on the gas✓\checkmark✓There is an equal and opposite force from the gas on the propeller✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gas in the atmosphere experiences a force due to the propeller blades. According to Newton's Third Law, a force with the same magnitude and opposite direction acts on the spacecraft.Fav=ΔpΔt=mΔvΔt✓F_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}{} = m\dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}\, \checkmarkFav​=ΔtΔp​=mΔtΔv​✓m=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vt✓m=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vt \, \checkmarkm=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vt✓v=Favρπr2✓v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}\ \, \checkmarkv=ρπr2Fav​​​✓=120120120m s−1^{-1}−1✓\, \checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The distancelllcovered by the spacetime in a short time ofttt:l=vtl=vtl=vtwherevvvis the average speed of the spacecraftThe massmmmof the gas pushed during the time ofttt:m=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vtm=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vtm=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vtwhererrris the radius of the bladesThe mass experiences a change of velocity ofvvv, as relative to the aircraft it is initially moving at speedvvvand comes to rest due to the propellorsThe average forceFavF_{av}Fav​needed from the propeller;Fav=ΔpΔt=mΔvΔt=ρπr2vtΔvΔt=ρπr2v2\begin{aligned}
 F_{av}&=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\\
 \hspace{1.3cm}\\
 &=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}\\
 \hspace{1.3cm}\\
 &= \dfrac{\rhoπr^2vt\Delta v}{\Delta t}\\
 \hspace{1.3cm}\\
 &=\rhoπr^2v^2\\
 \end{aligned}Fav​​=ΔtΔp​=ΔtmΔv​=Δtρπr2vtΔv​=ρπr2v2​Rearranging givesv=Favρπr2=1.4×103(0.020)π(1.2)2=120\hspace{1.12cm}v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{1.4\times{10}^3}{(0.020)\pi{(1.2)}^2}}=120v=ρπr2Fav​​​=(0.020)π(1.2)21.4×103​​=120m s−1^{-1}−1Δp=FavΔt\Delta p=F_{av}\Delta tΔp=Fav​Δt✓\, \checkmark✓duration of the collison is increased✓\, \checkmark✓Change in momentum is the same so the average force is less✓\, \checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The time of collision is increased with using soft material.  By using Newton’s second law;Fav=ΔpΔtF_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}Fav​=ΔtΔp​For the same magnitude of the change in momentum, the average force acting on the object is less when the time of collision is increased.

list.title: Question 131
list.content:
Define momentum.[1]A golf ball of mass 45 g moving with a constant velocity of 2.0 m s−1^{-1}−1undergoes a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 2.0 kg. The line that joins the centres of the balls is along the direction of the velocity of the golf ball.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/a31f1159-d99f-4baa-a497-a3dd8fb09c8a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Use Newton's Third Law and Second Law to deduce why the change in momentum of the golf ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the stationary ball during the collision.[3]The variation of force acting on the golf ballFFFwith the timetttduring the collision is shown in the graph.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/56c450d9-aa69-4205-b5b8-66efcaaa540a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.05.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Show that the magnitude of the change in momentum of the golf ball is approximately 0.09 kg m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Calculate the speed of the golf ball just after the collision.[3]Discuss whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.[4]
list.markScheme:
The product of mass and velocity.✓\checkmark✓According to Newton's third Law, the force acting on the golf ball equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball/Fg=−FsF_g=-F_sFg​=−Fs​✓\checkmark✓According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum/ΔpgΔt=−ΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​=−ΔtΔps​​✓\checkmark✓Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions/ sinceΔt\Delta tΔtfor each ball is equal,Δpg=−Δps\Delta p_g=-\Delta p_sΔpg​=−Δps​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to Newton's third law, the force acting on the golf ballFgF_gFg​equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ballFsF_sFs​during the collision.Fg=−FsF_g=-F_sFg​=−Fs​According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum. Therefore, the rate of change in momentum of the ballΔpgΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​equals and is opposite to the rate of change of momentum in the stationary ballΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔps​​.ΔpgΔt=−ΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​=−ΔtΔps​​Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions.Area under the graph = impulse / change in momentum✓\checkmark✓change in momentum =12(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1\dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3}) = \answer{0.086\ \textrm{kg m s}^{-1}}21​(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1​✓\checkmark✓(extra significant figures must be shown to receive full marks)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The area under the “Force acting on the object” “Time of acting force” graph equals the impulse and also the change in momentum. Therefore, the area of the triangleAtA_tAt​should be calculated to get the change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp;Δp=At=12bh=12(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1\begin{aligned}
 \Delta p &= A_t\\
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}bh\\ 
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3})\\
  &=0.086\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}
  \end{aligned}Δp​=At​=21​bh=21​(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1​Use ofΔp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−mu✓\checkmark✓−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)-0.086=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)✓\checkmark✓(negative sign on change in momentum must be seen)v=≪4×10−345×10−3≫=0.089m s−1v=\ll \dfrac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}\gg= \answer{0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}v=≪45×10−34×10−3​≫=0.089m s−1​✓\checkmark✓Note: Use of 0.09 kg m s−1^{-1}−1gives a final speed of 0 m s−1^{-1}−1. This is accepted if full working is shown.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The force acting on the golf ball during the collision is towards the left. Hence, the change in momentum of the golf ball must be towards the left. When left is chosen as negative and right is chosen as positive for the vectors, the following relationship can be written for change in momentum;Δp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−muwhereΔp=−0.086\Delta p=-0.086Δp=−0.086kg m s−1^{-1}−1,m=45×10−3m=45\times10^{-3}m=45×10−3kg,u=2.0u=2.0u=2.0m s−1^{-1}−1, andv=v=v=final velocity after the collision.−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)(90×10−3)−0.086=(45×10−3)v4×10−3=(45×10−3)v4×10−345×10−3=v0.089m s−1=v\begin{aligned}
 -0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 (90 \times 10^{-3})-0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 4 \times 10^{-3}&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}&=v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v
 \end{aligned}−0.086(90×10−3)−0.0864×10−345×10−34×10−3​0.089m s−1​=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)=(45×10−3)v=(45×10−3)v=v=v​Kinetic energy before the collision =12mgug2=12(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090\dfrac{1}{2}m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.09021​mg​ug2​=21​(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090J✓\checkmark✓Change in momentum of larger ball = 0.086 N sp=mvp = mvp=mv0.086=2.0v0.086=2.0v0.086=2.0vSpeed of the stationary ball after the collision=0.043ms−1=0.043\,\ce{m s}^{-1}=0.043ms−1✓\checkmark✓Correct calculation of final total kinetic energy according to the result of (b)(iii)Etotal=12(45×10−3)(0.089)2+12(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020E_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+ \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2=0.0020Etotal​=21​(45×10−3)(0.089)2+21​(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J0.00200.00200.0020J✓\checkmark✓Kinetic energy after is less so the collision is inelastic.✓\checkmark✓Note: A calculation leading to the kinetic energy after being equal to the kinetic energy before and a statement that the collision is elastic would score only one mark total.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The total kinetic energy of the balls before the collisionEtkbE_{tkb}Etkb​equals the kinetic energy of the golf ball before the collisionEkgbE_{kgb}Ekgb​;Etkb=Ekgb=12mgug2=12(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090E_{tkb}=E_{kgb}=\dfrac{1}{2} m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090Etkb​=Ekgb​=21​mg​ug2​=21​(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090JThe speed of the stationary ball after the collision can be found byΔp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−muwhereΔp=0.086\Delta p=0.086Δp=0.086kg m s−1^{-1}−1,m=2.0m=2.0m=2.0kg,u=0u=0u=0m s−1^{-1}−10.086=2.0v0.0862.0=v0.043m s−1=v\begin{aligned}
 \ 0.086 &=2.0v\\
 \ \frac{0.086}{2.0}&= v\\
 \ 0.043\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v\\
 \end{aligned}0.0862.00.086​0.043m s−1​=2.0v=v=v​The total kinetic energy of the balls after the collisionEtkaE_{tka}Etka​equals the sum of the kinetic energy of the golfEkgaE_{kga}Ekga​and stationary ballsEksaE_{ksa}Eksa​after the collision;Etka=Ekga+Eksa=12mgvg2+12msvs2=12(45×10−3)(0.089)2+12(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J\begin{aligned}
 E_{tka}&=E_{kga}+E_{ksa}\\
 &=\frac{1}{2} m_g v_g^2+\frac{1}{2} m_s v_s^2\\
 &=\frac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+\frac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2\\
 &=0.0020\textrm{ J}
 \end{aligned}Etka​​=Ekga​+Eksa​=21​mg​vg2​+21​ms​vs2​=21​(45×10−3)(0.089)2+21​(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J​Etkb>EtkaE_{tkb}>E_{tka}Etkb​>Etka​, the kinetic energy of the systems is not conserved. Therefore, collision is inelastic.

list.title: Question 132
list.content:
A massmmmis moving on a circular path at the end of a rope of constant length. The centripetal force acting on the mass isFFF.

list.title: Question 133
list.content:
An object is moving in a straight line. The graph shows the variation of the velocityvvvof the object with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9c89cf28-1ed7-42b7-a459-43d3f38fd733/images/346ccd81-3ae2-4296-9d59-33ebd8a889f0/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.18.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Consider the following statements about the graph:I.At point A, the object changes its direction.II.At point C the object is at rest.III.The magnitude of the acceleration at point D is greater than at point B.Which of the statements is/are correct?A. I onlyB. II onlyC. I and II onlyD. II and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The slope of the velocity time graph gives the acceleration of the object. Therefore, at points A and D, there is no acceleration due to zero gradient. At point B, there is a negative acceleration.Additionally, the velocity of the object at point C is as it aligns with the horizontal axis wherev=0v=0v=0.Hence, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 134
list.content: Which of the following postulates has the consequence of time and space not being absolute?A.\hspace{1em}Newton's laws of motion are the same in all reference framesB.\hspace{1em}The relative velocity of two inertial frames of reference is constantC.\hspace{1em}The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference framesD.\hspace{1em}The speed of light in a vacuum is constant in all inertial reference frames
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The speed of light is a fundamental constant according to the postulate in D. It does not change for the observers that move at different velocities. Consequences of this include time dilation and length contraction. This indicates there is no single universal reference frame in which time and space are absolute.

list.title: Question 135
list.content: An object which is initially rotating with a frequency of 2 s−1^{-1}−1. It is acted upon a constant torque which produces an angular deceleration of magnitude 6 rad s−2^{-2}−2.Which of the following best describes the number of complete rotations of the object until it comes to rest?A.\hspace{1em}2B.\hspace{1em}3C.\hspace{1em}4D.\hspace{1em}6
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The angular speed can be expressed in terms of the frequency of rotationfffas:ω=2πf\omega=2\pi fω=2πfThe object is initially rotating with an angular speed equal to:ω=2π(2s−1)\omega = 2\pi (2\textrm{ s}^{-1} )ω=2π(2s−1)ω=4πrads−1\omega = 4\pi \, \text{rad}\textrm{ s}^{-1}ω=4πrads−1Given that the torque is described constant (constant angular acceleration) the following equation from the booklet can be used:ωf2=ωi2+2αθ{\omega}_f^2={\omega}_i^2+2\alpha \thetaωf2​=ωi2​+2αθSubstituting the given values and the fact that as the object comes to a restωfω_fωf​is zero, the equation can be written as:0=(4πrad s−1)2+2(−6rad s−2)θ0=(4\pi \, \text{rad s}^{-1})^2+2(-6\,\text{rad s}^{-2} )\theta0=(4πrad s−1)2+2(−6rad s−2)θSolving forθ\thetaθleads to:θ=(4πrad s−1)212rad s−2=43π2rad\theta=\dfrac{(4\pi \, \text{rad s}^{-1})^2}{12\, \text{rad s}^{-2}}=\dfrac{4}{3}{\pi}^2 \, \text{rad}θ=12rad s−2(4πrad s−1)2​=34​π2radThis value represents the angle through which the object rotates until coming to a rest. It can then be divided by2π2\pi2πleading to the number of complete rotations.#rotations=θ2π=23π=\dfrac{\theta}{2\pi}=\dfrac{2}{3}\pi=2πθ​=32​π#rotations≈2.09\approx 2.09≈2.09

The motion of an object released from a high place in a vacuum is observed. The variation of its velocityvvvwith timetttis recorded and the following graph is obtained.

The mass of the object is8.08.08.0kg and the contact time during the rebound is0.500.500.50s.Calculate the average force acting on the object from the ground.[4]

The speed of the object can be found fromv2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswhereu=0u=0u=0ands=−70s=-70s=−70mv12=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70){v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)v1​2=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70)v12=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70){v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)v1​2=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70)v1=37.06v_1=37.06v1​=37.06m s−1^{-1}−1pbefore=296p_{before} = 296pbefore​=296kg ms−1s^{-1}s−1andpafter=136p_{after}=136pafter​=136kg m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Δp=mv2−mv1=136−(−296)=432\Delta p =mv_2-\ mv_1=136-\left(-296\right)=432Δp=mv2​−mv1​=136−(−296)=432kg m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Fnet=Δpt=4320.50=864F_{net} = \dfrac{\Delta p}{t}\ =\ \dfrac{432}{0.50}\ =\ 864Fnet​=tΔp​=0.50432​=864N✓\checkmark✓FN≪=Fnet+mg=864+(8)(9.81)≫=F_N \ll = F_{net}+mg=864+\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right)\gg=FN​≪=Fnet​+mg=864+(8)(9.81)≫=942 N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The momentum of the object before the collision with the groundpbefore=mv1=(8)(−37)=−296p_{before}=mv_1=\left(8\right)\left(-37\right)=\ -296pbefore​=mv1​=(8)(−37)=−296kg m s−1^{-1}−1The momentum of the object after the collision with the groundpafter=mv2=(8)(17)=136p_{after}=mv_2=\left(8\right)\left(17\right)=136pafter​=mv2​=(8)(17)=136kg m s−1^{-1}−1Change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔpof the objectΔp=mv2−mv1=136−(−296)=432\Delta p=mv_2-\ mv_1=136-\left(-296\right)=432Δp=mv2​−mv1​=136−(−296)=432kg m s−1^{-1}−1The resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​acting on the object during the  reboundFnet=Δpt=4320.50=864F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}\ =\ \dfrac{432}{0.50}\ =\ 864Fnet​=tΔp​=0.50432​=864NDuring the collision, two forces act on the object: contact and weight. They are in opposite directions. Therefore, the resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​;Fnet=864NFN−W=864NFN−mg=864NFN−(8)(9.81)=864NFN=864+(8)(9.81)FN=942N\begin{aligned}
 F_{net} &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
 F_N-W &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
 F_N-mg &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
 F_N-\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right) &=864\textrm{ N}\\
 F_N\ &=864+\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right)\\
 F_N\ &=942\textrm{ N}\\
 \end{aligned}Fnet​FN​−WFN​−mgFN​−(8)(9.81)FN​FN​​=864N=864N=864N=864N=864+(8)(9.81)=942N​Note that the force from the ground accomplishes two things here: it exerts a net force on the ball that causes its change in momentum and it also counteracts the force of gravity that acts downwards on the ball.

list.title: Question 139
list.content:
A spring of spring constant200200200N m−1^{-1}−1is compressed by6.06.06.0cm. A box is placed against the spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3624b206-05d4-4c78-b7ce-8a72357800ac/images/750688b5-572c-4f91-ba5f-bb29977761fa/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.23.34%E2%80%AFPM.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]At the point where the box has moved 4.0 cm, how much work has been done by the spring on the box?A.0.16\hspace{1em}  	0.160.16JB.0.20\hspace{1em}  	0.200.20JC.0.32\hspace{1em}  	0.320.32JD.0.36\hspace{1em}  	0.360.36J
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The work done by the spring on the box equals to decrease in elastic potential energyΔEH\mathrm{\Delta}E_HΔEH​of the spring. The initial compression of the spring is666cm and the final compression of the spring is2.02.02.0cm due to a4.04.04.0cm displacement.ΔEH=ΔEH(initial)−ΔEH(final)ΔEH=12(200)(0.062)−12(200)(0.022)ΔEH=(100)(0.062−0.022)ΔEH=(100)(36−410000)=0.32J\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(initial)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(final\right)}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\frac{1}{2}\left(200\right)\left({0.06}^2\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(200\right)\left({0.02}^2\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=(100)\left({{0.06}^2-\ 0.02}^2\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\left(100\right) \bigg(\frac{36-4}{10000}\bigg)=0.32 \textrm{ J}\ \
\end{aligned}ΔEH​ΔEH​ΔEH​ΔEH​​=ΔEH(initial)​−ΔEH(final)​=21​(200)(0.062)−21​(200)(0.022)=(100)(0.062−0.022)=(100)(1000036−4​)=0.32J​Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 140
list.content:
During a game of pool, a cue ball traveling at a velocityvvvcollides with a stationary ball. After the collision each of the balls move at 45 degrees to the initial velocity of the cue ball as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4e45fdf3-ab76-456e-a437-96f212df97cb/images/173e20c4-e008-4a67-934a-ffae87cc8b5f/Screenshot%202025-02-26%20at%209.21.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The mass of each of the balls ismmm. What is the impulse experienced by either of the balls in the collision?A.\hspace{1em}mv2\dfrac{mv}{2}2mv​B.\hspace{1em}mv2\dfrac{mv}{\sqrt{2}}2​mv​C.\hspace{1em}mvmvmvD.\hspace{1em}2\sqrt{2}2​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Due to symmetry, the final velocitiesVVVof the balls will be the same. We can see this as the masses are the same and the magnitude of the vertical components of the velocity must be the same due to conservation of vertical momentum.Impulse (JJJ) is equal to change in momentum. The simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.J=mΔvJ=m\Delta vJ=mΔvWe can find the horizontal component of this velocityVHV_HVH​using conservation of momentum. Setting the horizontal momentum before the collision equal to the horizontal momentum after the collision:mv+0=mVH+mVHmv+0=mV_H+mV_Hmv+0=mVH​+mVH​mv=2mVHmv=2mV_Hmv=2mVH​VH=v2V_H=\dfrac{v}{2}VH​=2v​After the collision, the balls move at 45° (so the vector triangle is isosceles) so the magnitude of the vertical component of the balls' final velocity is equal to the horizontal componentVV=VH=v2V_V=V_H=\dfrac{v}{2}VV​=VH​=2v​.NowVVVis the vector sum ofVHV_HVH​andVVV_VVV​, which can be calculated using Pythagoras' theorem:V=VH2+VV2=(v2)2+(v2)2=v22=v2V=\sqrt{V_H^2+V_V^2}=\sqrt{\left(\dfrac{v}{2}\right)^2+\left(\dfrac{v}{2}\right)^2}=\sqrt{\dfrac{v^2}{2}}=\dfrac{v}{\sqrt{2}}V=VH2​+VV2​​=(2v​)2+(2v​)2​=2v2​​=2​v​Because the ball was initally stationary, this also represents the change in velocity of the ball. The impulse of the collision is therefore:I=mV=mv2I=mV=\dfrac{mv}{\sqrt2}I=mV=2​mv​

list.title: Question 141
list.content:
The engine of a car exerts a constant driving force as the car accelerates from rest along a straight horizontal road. Friction and air resistance are negligible. Which of the following graphs shows how the power of the enginePPPvaries with distance traveled by the carsss?A.B.

Which of the following gives the speed of the spaceship in terms ofccc?A.\hspace{1em}the shaded areaB.\hspace{1em}1The shaded area\dfrac{1}{\textrm{ The shaded area}}The shaded area1​C.\hspace{1em}tan⁡θ\tan\thetatanθD.\hspace{1em}1tan⁡θ\dfrac{1}{\tan\theta}tanθ1​

list.title: Question 143
list.content:
State what is meant by an inertial frame of reference.[2]Two identical spaceships are moving in opposite directions, both at a speed of0.6c0.6c0.6cas measured by an observer at rest on Earth.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/78c98849-4188-4f58-b702-af9d3cb4d42f/images/f09e9efb-4375-459a-965b-475d6fd889e7/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.41.02%E2%80%AFAM.png)

What is the rate of separation between the two spaceships as measured by the observer on Earth?[1]Explain how your answer to (i) is consistent with special relativity.[2]Calculate the speed of one spaceship relative to an observer in the other spaceship.[3]
list.markScheme: A non-accelerative frame of reference OWTTE.✓\checkmark✓Newton's laws of motion are the same in all inertial frames of reference OWTTE.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:An inertial frame of reference is one that is not accelerating. Since the frame is not accelerating, there is no external force applied to the frame. Therefore, according to Newton's 1st Law, the frame must be at rest or moving with constant velocity and will remain in this state unless acted upon by an external force, i.e. Newton's laws of motion are the same.1.2c\answer{1.2c}1.2c​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The observer sees both spaceships moving away from each other at 0.6c. Therefore, the separation between the spaceships as measured by the observer is equal to the sum of speeds:Rate of separation=0.6c+0.6c=1.2c=0.6c+0.6c=1.2c=0.6c+0.6c=1.2c1.2c1.2c1.2cis not a relative speed, it is a rate of separation as observed from a separate frame at rest OWTTE.✓\checkmark✓No spaceship is moving faster than the speed of light relative to one another OWTTE.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Although the observer on Earth measures the rate of separation between the spaceships as1.2c1.2c1.2c, this does not violate special relativity because no spaceship is moving faster than the speed of light relative to another. The1.2c1.2c1.2cis not a relative speed between the two spaceships but rather a rate of separation from a separate frame at rest. The actual relative speed between the spacecrafts, calculated using the relativistic velocity addition formula, will still be less thanccc.Use ofu′=u−v1−uvc2u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}}u′=1−c2uv​u−v​✓\checkmark✓Correct substitutionu′=(0.6c)−(−0.6c)1−(0.6c)(−0.6c)c2u'=\dfrac{(0.6c)-(-0.6c)}{1-\dfrac{(0.6c)(-0.6c)}{c^2}}u′=1−c2(0.6c)(−0.6c)​(0.6c)−(−0.6c)​✓\checkmark✓u′=0.88cu'=\answer{0.88c}u′=0.88c​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The relative speed between the two spaceships can be calculated using the velocity addition formula:u′=u−v1−uvc2u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}}u′=1−c2uv​u−v​whereu=0.6cu=0.6cu=0.6candv=−0.6cv=-0.6cv=−0.6csince the spaceships are moving in opposite directions.Substituting in the values:u′=(0.6c)−(−0.6c)1−(0.6c)(−0.6c)c2=1.2c1+0.36c2c2=1.2c1+0.36=1.2c1.36=0.88cu'=\dfrac{(0.6c)-(-0.6c)}{1-\dfrac{(0.6c)(-0.6c)}{c^2}}=\dfrac{1.2c}{1+\dfrac{0.36c^2}{c^2}}=\dfrac{1.2c}{1+0.36}=\dfrac{1.2c}{1.36}=0.88cu′=1−c2(0.6c)(−0.6c)​(0.6c)−(−0.6c)​=1+c20.36c2​1.2c​=1+0.361.2c​=1.361.2c​=0.88c

C.D.

list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Even though the instantaneous speed of the body is unknown, average speeds for each interval can be compared by using the distances covered for the same time interval. Initially, its average speed increases then stay constant and finally decreases. Also, the object does not change direction, therefore it does not have negative velocity.  The only graph that satisfies these conditions is C.

list.title: Question 145
list.content: An object is thrown vertically upwards on the surface of the moon. The maximum height that the object can reach ishhh. When the object reaches the height ofh3\dfrac{h}{3}3h​above the surface, what is the ratioKinetic energy of the object ath3Gravitational potential energy of the object ath3\hspace{3cm} \dfrac{\textrm{Kinetic\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }{\textrm{Gravitational\ potential\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }Gravitational potential energy of the object at3h​Kinetic energy of the object at3h​​A.1\hspace{1em} 11B.23\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{2}{3}32​C.32\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3}{2}23​D.2\hspace{1em}  22
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since there is no atmosphere on the moon, energy is not lost to the surroundings due to air resistance. At the highest position of the object, all of the kinetic energy will have been converted to gravitational potential energyEtE_tEt​.Thus the total energy of the object:Et=mghE_t=mghEt​=mghwheremgmgmgis the weight of the object.The total energy ath3\dfrac{h}{3}3h​should be the sum of the kineticEkath3E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}Ekat3h​​and the gravitational potential energy of the objectEpath3E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}Epat3h​​.Et=Ekath3+Epath3E_t=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}Et​=Ekat3h​​+Epat3h​​mgh=Ekath3+mgh3mgh=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+mg\dfrac{h}{3}mgh=Ekat3h​​+mg3h​mg2h3=Ekath3mg\dfrac{2h}{3}=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}mg32h​=Ekat3h​​ThereforeEkath3Epath3=mg2h3mgh3=2\dfrac{E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}{E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}=\dfrac{mg\frac{2h}{3}}{mg\frac{h}{3}}=2Epat3h​​Ekat3h​​​=mg3h​mg32h​​=2

list.title: Question 146
list.content: A tennis ball with mass606060g travels horizontally with constant speeduuu. The ball hits a stationary racket and rebounds in the opposite direction with a horizontal speedvvv. The time for the collision is5.05.05.0ms.What is the magnitude of the average force on the ball?A.\hspace{1em}0.06(u−v)0.06(u-v)0.06(u−v)B.\hspace{1em}0.06(u+v)0.06(u+v)0.06(u+v)C.\hspace{1em}12(u−v)12(u-v)12(u−v)D.\hspace{1em}12(u+v)12(u+v)12(u+v)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:\hspace{1em}FΔt=ΔpF\Delta t=\Delta pFΔt=Δp\hspace{1em}F=m(Δv)Δt=(60×10−3)((−v)−u)5×10−3=−12(u+v)F=\dfrac{m(\Delta v)}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{(60 \times 10^{-3})\left ((-v)-u \right )}{5 \times 10^{-3}}=-12(u+v)F=Δtm(Δv)​=5×10−3(60×10−3)((−v)−u)​=−12(u+v)The magnitude of the force isF=12(u+v)F=12(u+v)F=12(u+v)Note that because there is a change in direction and the velocities are treated as vectors, we add the magnitudes of the starting and finishing velocities to find the change in velocity.

list.title: Question 147
list.content:
A motorised toy car starts from rest, with the motor delivering increasing power to the car over time as shown in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec6c266e-9dfb-4ac7-9e6b-2eb4858fef0e/images/9e9d2002-d57d-423c-b80e-9ad472b32f71/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%209.08.04%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Assuming no energy losses, which of the following gives the kinetic energy of the car after 8.0 seconds?A.\hspace{1em}0.20 JB.\hspace{1em}5.0 JC.\hspace{1em}160 JD.\hspace{1em}320 J
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The energy can be found by calculating the area under the graph.Work done =(Power)(time)2\dfrac{(Power)(time)}{2}2(Power)(time)​W=(40W)(8s)2=160W = \dfrac{(40\textrm{ W})(8\textrm{ s})}{2} = 160W=2(40W)(8s)​=160JAlternative solution:Because Power increases at a constant rate, the average Power (PavP_{av}Pav​) can be found from the average of the starting and ending powers.Pav=0+402=20P_{av} = \dfrac{0+40}{2} = 20Pav​=20+40​=20WE=Pavt=(20)(8)=160E=P_{av}t = (20)(8) = 160E=Pav​t=(20)(8)=160J

list.title: Question 148
list.content: A ball with massmmmis released from a height ofhhhand undergoes free fall. The ball hits the ground and rebounds vertically. On rebound, the ball reaches a maximum height ofh′h'h′. The time taken for the collision isTTT. During the collision, what are the change in kinetic energy of the ball and the magnitude of the average net force on the ball?\hspace{1em}Change in kinetic energy\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Average force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h−h′)mg(h-h')mg(h−h′)m(2gh+2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h′−h)mg(h'-h)mg(h′−h)m(2gh−2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​−2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h′−h)mg(h'-h)mg(h′−h)m(2gh+2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h−h′)mg(h-h')mg(h−h′)m(2gh−2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​−2gh′​)​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in kinetic energy  = Loss of mechanical energy = change in potential energy=mgh′−mgh=mg(h′−h)mgh' - mgh = mg(h'-h)mgh′−mgh=mg(h′−h)We can find the velocity before hitting the ground using conservation of energy12mu2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2=mgh21​mu2=mghgivingu=2ghu = \sqrt{2gh}u=2gh​Similarly, velocity after bouncing from the groundv=−2gh′v = - \sqrt{2gh'}v=−2gh′​Change in momentumΔp=m(v−u)\Delta p = m (v-u)Δp=m(v−u)=m(−2gh′−2gh)m (-\sqrt{2gh'} - \sqrt{2gh})m(−2gh′​−2gh​)Force is rate of change of momentumFav=−m(2gh+2gh′)TF_{av} = \dfrac{-m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Fav​=T−m(2gh​+2gh′​)​Because the question asks for the magnitude of the average force, we can take the positive value.Fav=m(2gh+2gh′)TF_{av} = \dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Fav​=Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​

list.title: Question 149
list.content:
A motor uses a cable to pull a trolley up an inclined plane at a constant velocity.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/03c2e4aa-9eff-4287-8eef-0ae906343fba/images/28f10955-8ba2-42e6-b8d5-59a2eaf0a440/ph0035q.JPEG)

Consider the following statements about the energy changes of the trolley during its motion.I.The work done by the engine has greater magnitude than the work done by friction.II.The total of kinetic and potential energy of the trolley increases.III.The gain in gravitational potential energy of the trolley has the same magnitude as the work done by the engine.Of the statements above, which is/are correct?A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I.	Correct: as the trolley moves up gravitational potential energy increases so work done by the trolley is done against both friction and gravity.II.	Correct: kinetic energy is constant since trolley is moving at constant velocity but gravitational potential energy increases as height of it from ground increases.III.	Incorrect: some amount of work done by the engine is used to increase gravitational potential energy, but some of it wasted as work done by friction.

list.title: Question 150
list.content: An object is thrown vertically upwards at the edge of a cliff at heighthhhabove the ground. When the object passes the edge of the cliff while falling downwards, a second, identical object is released from rest. Air resistance is negligible. What increases for the second object as the two objects fall?A.\hspace{1em}AccelerationB.\hspace{1em}Distance from the groundC.\hspace{1em}Velocity relative to the object released earlierD.\hspace{1em}Distance from the object released earlier
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For options A & C, the accelerations of both objects are gravitational acceleration and constant, therefore the velocity difference is constant and both options are incorrect.For option B, the object released later was released from rest and so the distance from the ground decreases. Therefore, B is incorrect.For option D, the relative velocity of the two objects is constant because the acceleration for both objects is the same, therefore the distance between the two objects will increase and it is the correct option. In other words, the first object will always be moving faster than the second object, so the distance between them will increase.

DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The free body diagram of the object. Note that there is no force pointing down the slope. It is a component of weight (mgmgmg) that acts down the slope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/eb0a8a69-9f1e-4c09-9659-f48ebc327f9e/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.28.53%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Since the object is just about to slide, thenN=mgcos⁡θN=mg\cos\thetaN=mgcosθAndFf=mgsin⁡θF_f=mg\sin\thetaFf​=mgsinθThe static friction force is given byFf=μsFN=μsmgcos⁡θF_f=\mu_sF_N=\mu_smg\cos\thetaFf​=μs​FN​=μs​mgcosθThenmgsin⁡θ=μsmgcos⁡θmg\sin\theta = \mu_smg\cos\thetamgsinθ=μs​mgcosθμs=sin⁡θcos⁡θ\mu_s=\dfrac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}μs​=cosθsinθ​μs=tan⁡θ\mu_s=\tan\thetaμs​=tanθ

list.title: Question 154
list.content:
The variation of displacement of a trolley with timetttis shown on the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/381e52d4-b416-43d1-8298-afc914f8d8d6/images/a3d7bf4b-5d3c-4df4-a4ca-0358b442555b/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.57.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The magnitudes of the instantaneous velocities of the trolley at timest1t_1t1​andt2t_2t2​arev1v_1v1​andv2v_2v2​respectively. Which of the following correctly compares the instantaneous velocities with the magnitude of the average velocity of the trolley for the whole of the motion shown?v1v_1v1​v2v_2v2​A.Greater than the average velocityGreater than the average velocityB.Greater than the average velocityLess than the average velocityC.Less than the average velocityGreater than the average velocityD.Less than the average velocityLess than the average velocity
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The magnitudes of instantaneous velocities can be found from the gradient of the graph at the corresponding points. The average velocity is the total displacement over time and it is mathematically equal to the slope of a straight line that connects points at the start and end of the motion on the graph.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/381e52d4-b416-43d1-8298-afc914f8d8d6/images/b9686814-6527-48ce-afc7-39f12f8517f7/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.02.29%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the slopes of the lines are compared, It can be seen thatv2>v_2>v2​>average velocity>v1>v_1>v1​. Therefore the answer is C.

The coefficient of static friction between the block and the planeμs\mu _sμs​is 0.4.Which of the following gives the angle of inclination at which the block will start to slide?A.\hspace{1em}sin⁡−1(0.4)\sin^{-1}(0.4)sin−1(0.4)B.\hspace{1em}tan⁡−1(0.4)\tan^{-1}(0.4)tan−1(0.4)C.\hspace{1em}cos⁡−1(0.4)\cos^{-1}(0.4)cos−1(0.4)D.\hspace{1em}tan⁡−1(0.6)\tan^{-1}(0.6)tan−1(0.6)
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/1ea450be-a2a5-44f8-aca9-38d06abc4237/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.09.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

FN=mgcos⁡θF_N = mg\cos\thetaFN​=mgcosθF=μsFNF = \mu_sF_NF=μs​FN​F=mgsin⁡θF = mg\sin\thetaF=mgsinθmg(sin⁡θ)=0.4mg(cos⁡θmg(\sin\theta) = 0.4mg(\cos\thetamg(sinθ)=0.4mg(cosθ)sin⁡θcos⁡θ=0.4\dfrac{\sin\theta } {\cos\theta}=0.4cosθsinθ​=0.4tan⁡θ=0.4\tan\theta = 0.4tanθ=0.4θ=tan⁡−1(0.4)\theta=\tan^{-1}(0.4)θ=tan−1(0.4)

list.title: Question 157
list.content:
Two objects of massMMMandmmmare connected via a frictionless pulley. The rope attached to the object of massMMMmakes an angleθ\thetaθwith the horizontal. The objects are at rest.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a39026f-aa75-494c-a20c-39635e9e1fc0/images/155ede1a-26a4-4810-8047-d312bfef3356/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.43.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

For the large mass, which expressions are correct for the force of frictionFf_ff​and the normal forceFN_NN​?\hspace{3em}Ff_ff​\hspace{3em}\hspace{4em}FN_NN​\hspace{4em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}mgcos⁡θmg \cos\thetamgcosθMg−mgsin⁡θMg - mg \sin\thetaMg−mgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}mgsin⁡θmg \sin \thetamgsinθMg−mgsin⁡θMg - mg \sin\thetaMg−mgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}mgsin⁡θmg \sin \thetamgsinθMg−mgcos⁡θMg - mg \cos\thetaMg−mgcosθ\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}mgcos⁡θmg \cos\thetamgcosθMg−mgcos⁡θMg - mg \cos\thetaMg−mgcosθ
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Resolving vertical forces on the large block:Fg=FN+Tsin⁡θF_g = F_N + T\sin \thetaFg​=FN​+TsinθAnd for the large block,Fg=MgF_g = MgFg​=MgSubstituting and solving forFNF_NFN​givesFN=Mg−Tsin⁡θF_N =  Mg - T\sin \thetaFN​=Mg−TsinθResolving horizontal forces on the large block:Ff=Tcos⁡θF_f = T \cos \thetaFf​=TcosθFor the vertical forces small blockT=mgT = mgT=mgSubstituting givesFf=mgcos⁡θF_f = mg \cos \thetaFf​=mgcosθ

list.title: Question 158
list.content: Below are three suggested units for viscocityI.kg m−1^{-1}−1s−1^{-1}−1II.Pa sIII.N s m−1^{-1}−1Which of the unit combinations is/are correct?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and IID.\hspace{1em}II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Drag:Fd=6πηrvF_d=6\pi \eta rvFd​=6πηrvBy making viscosity the subject of the formula:η=Fd6πrv\eta =\dfrac{F_d}{6\pi rv}η=6πrvFd​​Units are substituted:η=N(m)(m s−1)=N(m2s−1)=N s m−2\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m})(\textrm{m s}^{-1})}=\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1})}=\textrm{ N s m}^{-2}η=(m)(m s−1)N​=(m2s−1)N​=N s m−2By replacing N m−2^{-2}−2= Pa:N s m−2^{-2}−2= Pa sBy replacing N = kg m s−2^{-2}−2:Nm2s−1=kg m s−2m2s−1=kg m−1s−1\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\dfrac{\textrm{kg m s}^{-2}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\textrm{kg m}^{-1}\textrm{ s}^{-1}m2s−1N​=m2s−1kg m s−2​=kg m−1s−1

list.title: Question 159
list.content: A ball is released from rest and falls vertically for 3 s on Earth. Air resistance is negligible. What is the average speed of the ball during the motion?A.\hspace{1em}3 m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}10 m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}15 m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}30 m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Solution 1:v=u+at=0+(10)(3)=30v = u + at = 0 + (10)(3) = 30v=u+at=0+(10)(3)=30m s−1^{-1}−1vav=v+u2=30+02=15v_{av} = \dfrac{v+u}{2} = \dfrac{30+0}{2} = 15vav​=2v+u​=230+0​=15m s−1^{-1}−1Solution 2:Distance covered by the ball;s=12at2s = \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=21​at2Due to absence of air resistance;a=ga = ga=gs=(12)(10)(3)2s = \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(10)(3)^2s=(21​)(10)(3)2s=45s = 45s=45maverage speed=total distancetotal time\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{\textrm{total distance}}{\textrm{total\ time}}average speed=total timetotal distance​average speed=453=15\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{45}{3} = 15average speed=345​=15m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 160
list.content:
State the difference between distance and displacement.[2]A dart player throws a dart horizontally with the speed of151515m s−1^{-1}−1to hit a dartboard. The vertical displacement of the dart is0.350.350.35m. Air resistance is negligible.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/cf1e86d8-8c54-4110-8bb5-a459436d1e84/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.49.06%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Show that the time taken for the dart to reach the centre of the dartboard is approximately 0.3 s.[2]Calculate the angle below the horizontal, in degrees, of the velocity of the dart as it hits the dartboard.[3]Determine the displacement of the dart.[2]On the axes below, sketch how the square of the velocityv2v^2v2of the dart varies with the square of timet2t^2t2.[2](no need to add values on the axes)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/78c0e156-6b74-4420-b9b1-ae0f2408d349/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.49.33%E2%80%AFAM.png)
list.markScheme:
Distance is the length of the path followed while displacement is the change in position✓\checkmark✓Distance is a scalar quantity while displacement is a vector quantity✓\checkmark✓Use oft=2sat = \sqrt{\dfrac{2s}{a}}t=a2s​​ORUse ofv=2asv = \sqrt{2as}v=2as​andt=vat = \dfrac{v}{a}t=av​✓\checkmark✓t=(2)(0.35)9.81t =  \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(0.35)}{9.81}}t=9.81(2)(0.35)​​=0.27 s✓\checkmark✓(extra significant figures must be shown for MP2)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The initial velocity of the dart has no vertical component and accelerates due to gravity on the vertical axis. Therefore, the time of motion in the vertical axis can be found by following the suvat equation;s=ut+12at2s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=ut+21​at2whereu=0u=0u=0,a=9.81a=9.81a=9.81m s−2^{-2}−2ands=0.35s=0.35s=0.35mAfter substituting the values;0.35=12(9.81)t20.35 = \dfrac{1}{2} (9.81 )t^20.35=21​(9.81)t2By rearranging;t=(2)(0.35)9.81=0.27t = \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(0.35)}{9.81}} = 0.27t=9.81(2)(0.35)​​=0.27svertical velocity=0+(9.81)(0.27)=2.6= 0 + (9.81)(0.27) =2.6=0+(9.81)(0.27)=2.6m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓horizontal velocity=15= 15=15m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓tan⁡θ=2.615\tan\, \theta = \dfrac{2.6}{15}tanθ=152.6​givingθ\thetaθ= 10°✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The horizontal component of the velocity of the dart is constant. Therefore, the horizontal component of velocity at the instant of reaching the dartboard is151515m s−1^{-1}−1.The vertical component of velocity can be found by the following equation;v=u+atv=u+atv=u+atwhereu=0u=0u=0,a=9.81a=9.81a=9.81m s−2^{-2}−2andt=0.27t=0.27t=0.27sBy substituting known values;v=0+(9.81)(0.27)=2.6v=0+(9.81)(0.27)=2.6v=0+(9.81)(0.27)=2.6m s−1^{-1}−1Hence, the relationship between horizontal, vertical, and resultant velocity in terms of their directions is given as shown

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/a0034b4c-57e2-43e1-9b26-d917b9683c84/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.56.02%E2%80%AFAM.png)

By using geometry;tan⁡θ=2.615\tan\theta=\dfrac{2.6}{15}tanθ=152.6​givingθ=10°\theta=10\degreeθ=10°Horizontal displacement=(15)(0.27)=4.05=(15)(0.27)=4.05=(15)(0.27)=4.05m✓\checkmark✓s=(sh)2+(sv)2=4.052+0.352=4.1s = \sqrt{(s_h)^2 + (s_v)^2} = \sqrt{4.05^2 + 0.35^2}=4.1s=(sh​)2+(sv​)2​=4.052+0.352​=4.1m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The horizontal displacementshs_hsh​;sh=uhts_h=u_htsh​=uh​twhereuh=15u_h=15uh​=15m s−1^{-1}−1andt=0.27t = 0.27t=0.27ssh=(15)(0.27)=4.05s_h=(15)(0.27)=4.05sh​=(15)(0.27)=4.05mThe vertical displacementsvs_vsv​;sv=0.35s_v = 0.35sv​=0.35mThe resultant displacementscan be found by geometry;s=(sh)2+(sv)2=4.052+0.352=4.1s = \sqrt{(s_h)^2 + (s_v)^2} = \sqrt{4.05^2 + 0.35^2} = 4.1s=(sh​)2+(sv​)2​=4.052+0.352​=4.1mStraight line✓\checkmark✓Non-zero y-intercept✓\checkmark✓

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/fa909b24-b19a-42bd-8119-6be319b0cf3a/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.51.44%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The velocity of the dart has two components horizontalvxv_xvx​and verticalvyv_yvy​. Therefore, it is;v=(vx)2+(vy)2v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + (v_y)^2}v=(vx​)2+(vy​)2​Onlyvyv_yvy​changes by the following equation;vy=atv_y = atvy​=atwherea=ga = ga=gBy substitutinga=ga = ga=gin the equation;vy=gtv_y = gtvy​=gtReplacevyv_yvy​withgtgtgtin the previous equation;v=(vx)2+(g2t2)v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + (g^2t^2)}v=(vx​)2+(g2t2)​By taking the square of both sides to find a relationship betweenv2v^2v2andt2t^2t2;v2=(vx)2+g2t2v^2 = (v_x)^2 + g^2t^2v2=(vx​)2+g2t2Sincevx2v^2_xvx2​andg2g^2g2are constant, this relationship can be summarized as;y=mx+by=mx+by=mx+bwhere(vx)2=b=y-intercept(v_x)^2=b=\textrm{y-intercept}(vx​)2=b=y-interceptandg2=m=slopeg^2=m=\textrm{slope}g2=m=slopeBoth of the values are positive. Therefore; the graph should be a straight line with a positive gradient and positive y-intercept.

list.title: Question 161
list.content: A pointPPPis subjected to three simultaneous forces of magnitudesFA>FB>FCF_A > F_B > F_CFA​>FB​>FC​. PointPPPis in equilibrium. Consider of the following statements.I.FA=FB+FCF_A = F_B + F_CFA​=FB​+FC​II.FA≤FB+FCF_A \leq F_B + F_CFA​≤FB​+FC​III.FA>FB−FCF_A > F_B - F_CFA​>FB​−FC​Which of the statements isnot always trueabout the magnitudes of the forces?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Vectors of forces in equilibrium form a triangle or a straight line.The sum of two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third (II is always true).The difference between two sides of a triangle is always less than the third (III is also always true).I is trueonly whenthe three forces are in a straight line andFBF_BFB​andFCF_CFC​are both opposingFAF_AFA​(not always true, as required by the question).

list.title: Question 162
list.content: A box of mass222kg is pushed with an initial speed of 10 m s−1^{-1}−1on a rough horizontal floor. A uniform frictional force of101010N acts on the box. What is the distance travelled by the box at the instant when the kinetic energy of the box is halved?A.\hspace{1em}10 mB.\hspace{1em}5 mC.\hspace{1em}2 mD.\hspace{1em}1 m
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The loss of kinetic energy is equal to half of the orinal kinetic energy:Ek(Lost)=Ek(initial)2E_{k(Lost)}= \dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2}Ek(Lost)​=2Ek(initial)​​Work done by friction is equal to the loss of kinetic energy.Ek(Lost)=W=FfsE_{k(Lost)} = W = F_fsEk(Lost)​=W=Ff​sEk(initial)2=Ffs\dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2} = F_fs2Ek(initial)​​=Ff​sBy substituting given values in the equation usingEk=12mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2Ek​=21​mv2(12)(2)(102)2=10s(12)(100)=10s50=10ss=5\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) \dfrac{(2)(10^2)}{2}  &= 10\,s\\
\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(100) &= 10\,s\\
50 &= 10\,s\\
s &= 5 
\end{aligned}(21​)2(2)(102)​(21​)(100)50s​=10s=10s=10s=5​Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 163
list.content: A toy of massmmmis attached to a rod of lengthLLLand undergoes circular motion in the vertical plane. The radial forceFFFof the rod is constant.What is the ratio of the linear speed at the top to the linear speed at the bottom of its path,vtopvbottom\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}vbottom​vtop​​?A.\hspace{1em}F−mgF+mg\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}F+mgF−mg​B.\hspace{1em}F+mgF−mg\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}F−mgF+mg​C.\hspace{1em}F−mgF+mg\sqrt{\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}}F+mgF−mg​​D.\hspace{1em}F+mgF−mg\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}F−mgF+mg​​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top, the centripetal force isF+mg=m(vtop)2rF+mg=\dfrac{m(v_{top})^2}{r}F+mg=rm(vtop​)2​At the bottom, the centripetal force isF−mg=m(vbottom)2rF-mg=\dfrac{m(v_{bottom})^2}{r}F−mg=rm(vbottom​)2​Rearranging the above equations for the required ratio gives:\hspace{3em}vtopvbottom=F+mgF−mg\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}vbottom​vtop​​=F−mgF+mg​​

list.title: Question 165
list.content:
The diagram below shows a water slide. As a test, an object is released from point A, 6.0 m above the ground level. Point B at the end of the slide is 2.0 m above the ground level.  Location C is the point of contact of the slide with the ground. The slide approximates a circular shape at this point.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/86876d63-7070-4138-84e3-625f77cab51c/images/ac8ba796-8e18-4784-8178-2f7f2de2ab2a/PH0617.png)

Air resistance and friction on the object are negligible.Draw the free-body diagram of the forces acting on the object as it passes point D.[2]

A stone is then launched with a horizontal speed of202020m s−1^{-1}−1from a height of121212m above the ground.

Use the graph to estimate the depth of water in the container.[2]

list.title: Question 168
list.content:
In a game, players try to hit a moving cart by projecting a ball at an angle from a spring-loaded launcher.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5d2f365-cfa8-4f39-a985-deee47a8af8e/images/4a39a38c-689e-4257-bf0e-eadef77b444f/PH0845aaaa.png)

When the spring is fully uncompressed, it extends to the open end of the barrel. The frictional forces acting on the ball are negligible.State the main energy changes taking place when the ball is moving inside the barrel.[2]The following data is available:Mass of the ball:0.0650.0650.065kgThe compression of the spring before release:0.220.220.22mThe spring constant:101010N m−1^{-1}−1Show that the launch speed of the ball at the end of the barrel is approximately2.32.32.3m s−1^{-1}−1.[3]When launching the ball, the spring applies a force for0.0220.0220.022s.  Determine the average net force acting on the ball during this time interval.[2]One competitor aligned the launcher at30°30\degree30°above the horizontal. At the instant the ball left the launcher, it was1.251.251.25m directly above the front of a moving cart which was moving at a steady speed of2.12.12.1m s−1^{-1}−1directly away from the launcher.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5d2f365-cfa8-4f39-a985-deee47a8af8e/images/786965a2-e660-4483-abe7-61bf392ab47f/PH0845aaa1.png)

Show that the time taken for the ball to displace1.251.251.25m vertically downward after leaving the barrel is around0.640.640.64s.[3]The length of the cart is353535cmDeduce whether or not the ball will hit the top of the cart.[3]

Upon releasing the ball, both its speed and altitude experience an increase. Consequently, this energy is converted into the ball's gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy.\hspace{1.8em}Δh=(Δx)(sin30)=0.222=\Delta h = \left ( \Delta x \right ) \left(sin30 \right) = \dfrac{0.22}{2} =Δh=(Δx)(sin30)=20.22​=:0.11 m✓\checkmark✓(10)(0.222)2=0.065(v)22+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2)}{2} = \dfrac{0.065(v)^2}{2} + (0.065)(9.8)(0.11)2(10)(0.222)​=20.065(v)2​+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)✓\checkmark✓v=(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)0.065=2.3≪ms−1≫v = \sqrt{\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2) - (2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)}{0.065}} = \answer{2.3} \ll \ce{m s}^{-1} \ggv=0.065(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)​​=2.3​≪ms−1≫Allow two marks if gravitational potential energy is not considered and the answer 2.7 is obtained.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The increase in vertical positionΔh\Delta hΔhof the ball during the launch:Δh=(Δx)(sin⁡30)=0.222=0.11\Delta h = (\Delta x)(\sin30) = \dfrac{0.22}{2} = 0.11Δh=(Δx)(sin30)=20.22​=0.11mDuring the launch, the elastic potential energy lost is equal to the gains in gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy:ΔEH=ΔEk+ΔEp\Delta E_{H} = \Delta E_k + \Delta E_pΔEH​=ΔEk​+ΔEp​kΔx22=mv22+mgΔx2\dfrac{k \Delta x^2}{2} = \dfrac{mv^2}{2} + mg \dfrac{\Delta x}{2}2kΔx2​=2mv2​+mg2Δx​By substituting given values:(10)(0.222)2=0.065(v)22+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2)}{2} = \dfrac{0.065(v)^2}{2} + (0.065)(9.8)(0.11)2(10)(0.222)​=20.065(v)2​+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)v=(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)0.065=2.3v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2) - (2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)}{0.065}}=2.3v=0.065(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)​​=2.3m s−1^{-1}−1The magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball=mΔv=0.150= m \Delta v= 0.150=mΔv=0.150kg m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓ΔpΔt=0.150.022=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{0.15}{0.022}=ΔtΔp​=0.0220.15​=6.86.86.8N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔpof the ball:Δp=mv=(0.065)(2.3)=0.150\Delta p = mv = (0.065)(2.3)=0.150Δp=mv=(0.065)(2.3)=0.150kg m s−1^{-1}−1Using impulse, we can find the average forceFFFacting on the ball during the interval:F=ΔpΔt=0.1500.022=6.79F = \dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{0.150}{0.022} = 6.79F=ΔtΔp​=0.0220.150​=6.79NThe magnitude of the vertical component of the initial velocity=1.15= 1.15=1.15m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Vertical velocity at the level of the cart=5.1= 5.1=5.1m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓t=v−ua=(−5.1−1.15)−9.81=t=\dfrac{v-u}{a}=\dfrac{(-5.1-1.15)}{-9.81}=t=av−u​=−9.81(−5.1−1.15)​=0.640.640.64s✓\checkmark✓OR−1.25=1.15t+12(−9.81)t2=-1.25=1.15t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.81)t^2=−1.25=1.15t+21​(−9.81)t2=0.640.640.64s✓\checkmark✓Accept alternative usage of uniform acceleration equationsFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The magnitude of the vertical component of the initial velocityv0vv_{0v}v0v​:v0v=2.3sin⁡30=1.15v_{0v} = 2.3\ \sin30 = 1.15v0v​=2.3sin30=1.15m s−1^{-1}−1Using the uniform acceleration equations in multiple steps:The velocityvfv_fvf​of the ball when it is displaced at1.251.251.25m downwards.vf2=vi2+2asv_f ^2 = v_i ^2 + 2asvf2​=vi2​+2asvf2=1.152+(2)(−9.81)(−1.25)=−5.1v_f ^2 = 1.15^2 + (2)(-9.81)(-1.25) = -5.1vf2​=1.152+(2)(−9.81)(−1.25)=−5.1m s−1^{-1}−1vf=−5.1v_f = -5.1vf​=−5.1m s−1^{-1}−1The timetttof the motion:v=u+atv = u + atv=u+att=v−ua=−5.1−1.15−9.81=0.64t = \dfrac{v - u}{a} = \dfrac{-5.1 - 1.15}{-9.81} = 0.64t=av−u​=−9.81−5.1−1.15​=0.64sAlternative method:s=v0vt+12at2s = v_{0v}t + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=v0v​t+21​at2wheresssis−1.25-1.25−1.25m,aaais−9.81-9.81−9.81m s−2^{-2}−2andv0vv_{0v}v0v​is1.151.151.15m s−1^{-1}−1−1.25=1.15t+12(−9.81)t2-1.25 = 1.15t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.81)t^2−1.25=1.15t+21​(−9.81)t2Solving using the quadratic formula gives the positive roott=0.64t = 0.64t=0.64sHorizontal displacement of the ball =vht=(2.3cos⁡(30°))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64)=1.27v_h t=(2.3\cos(30\degree))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64) =1.27vh​t=(2.3cos(30°))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64)=1.27m✓\checkmark✓Front of the cart movess=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35s = vt = (2.1)(0.64) =1.35s=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35m✓\checkmark✓The front of the cart moves0.070.070.07m further than the ball and the cart is353535cm long, so the ball hits the cart✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The magnitude of the horizontal component of the initial velocityv0hv_{0_h}v0h​​:v0h=2.3cos⁡30=1.99v_{0_h}=2.3\cos30=1.99v0h​​=2.3cos30=1.99m s−1^{-1}−1The horizontal displacementshs_hsh​of the ball as it displaced1.251.251.25m vertically downward:\hspace{1em}sh=v0ht=(1.99)(0.64)=1.28s_h = v_{0_h}t = (1.99)(0.64) = 1.28sh​=v0h​​t=(1.99)(0.64)=1.28mThe horizontal displacementshcs_{hc}shc​of any part of the cart:shc=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35s_{h_c} = vt =(2.1)(0.64) = 1.35shc​​=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35mComparing the numbers and knowing that the cart is0.350.350.35m long, the ball with hit the cart,1.35−1.28=0.071.35 - 1.28 = 0.071.35−1.28=0.07m behind the front of the cart.

list.title: Question 169
list.content:
A uniform rod of massMMMand lengthLLLrotates around a vertical axis through its center. Two equal forces act on the rod as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc8552b-f2af-406e-9782-98ecc856ffa9/images/643b69ac-8b0a-4838-b20d-66e33be9978b/Screenshot%202023-08-07%20at%202.12.35%20PM.png)

The moment of inertia of the rod when rotating about its centre is112ML2\dfrac{1}{12} ML^2121​ML2.Which of the following gives the angular acceleration of the rod?A.0\hspace{1em}  00B.6FML\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{6F}{ML}ML6F​C.12FML\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{12F}{ML}ML12F​D.24FML\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{24F}{ML}ML24F​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The net torque of the two forces isτ=2Fr\tau =2Frτ=2FrSincer=L2r=\dfrac{L}{2}r=2L​Thenτ=2FL2=FL\tau =2F\dfrac{L}{2}=FLτ=2F2L​=FLThe torque is related to angular acceleration byτ=Iα\tau =I\alphaτ=IαFL=112ML2αFL=  \dfrac{1}{12} ML^2 \alphaFL=121​ML2αα=12FML\alpha=\dfrac{12F}{ML}α=ML12F​

list.title: Question 170
list.content:
A projectile is launched horizontally on Earth with initial speed of3.03.03.0m s−1^{-1}−1from a height of5.05.05.0m above the ground.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/adca8fcd-c774-446b-a421-eb944e4ddd54/images/51e584df-f2d9-4096-bc80-662140961015/PH0851aaaa.png)

What is the magnitude of the displacement of the stone when it reaches the ground?A.\hspace{1em}5.05.05.0mB.\hspace{1em}8.08.08.0mC.\hspace{1em}34\sqrt{34}34​mD.\hspace{1em}51\sqrt{51}51​m
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For the time, analyzing the vertical direction\hspace{1em}s=12at2s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=21​at2\hspace{1em}5=12(10)t25 = \dfrac{1}{2}(10)t^25=21​(10)t2\hspace{1em}t=1t = 1t=1sThe horizonal displacement is\hspace{1em}Δx=uxt=(3)(1)=3\Delta x = u_x t = (3)(1) = 3Δx=ux​t=(3)(1)=3mThe vertical displacement from the diagram is555m.The net displacement isDisplacement=52+32=34=\sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{34}=52+32​=34​m

list.title: Question 171
list.content:
A car enters a horizontal circular roundabout as shown with a speed of 35 km h−1^{-1}−1. The radius of the roundabout is 15 m.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae5d5d2c-d886-4aa8-875e-97c202da73d1/images/678c565e-beaf-419e-8ae6-5608f15c2ecf/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.32.11%E2%80%AFPM.png)

State the force which provides the centripetal force for the circular motion of the car.[1]Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction between the tyres of the car and the road for the car to safely complete its motion around the roundabout.[3]State and explain any change in your answer to part (b) if:The mass of the car increases.[2]The road is banked at an angle so that the car is tilted towards the center of the roundabout.[2]The speed of the car increases.[2]
list.markScheme: Frictionalforce (between the road and the car tyres)✓\checkmark✓Weight is not accepted as a response here.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:It is the force of friction between the road and the tires that provides the force towards the centre of the roundabout. Without friction, the car would not be able to make the turn.The speed of the car is (35km h−135\textrm{ km h}^{-1}35km h−1, which is35000m3600s)=\dfrac{35000\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}})=3600s35000m​)=9.72 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Frictional force provides the centripetal force, thereforemv2r=mgμ\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\murmv2​=mgμRearranging givesμ=v2rg\mu=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}μ=rgv2​✓\checkmark✓ORThe substitution:μ=9.722(15)(9.8)\mu=\dfrac{9.72^2}{(15)(9.8)}μ=(15)(9.8)9.722​=0.64✓\checkmark✓(2 marks max if speed is not converted to m s−1^{-1}−1. This gives 8.33)No change✓\checkmark✓The mass of the car impacts the calculation of the frictional force and centripetal force equally/cancels in the calculation.✓\checkmark✓Decrease✓\checkmark✓The normal force would contribute to the centripetal force, therefore less frictional force would be sufficient.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:On a banked turn, the normal force will have a component that points towards the centre of the circle. As the centripetal force required is the same as on a non-banked turn, less frictional force is required and therefore a lower coefficient of friction is sufficient.Increase✓\checkmark✓At a higher speed, a larger centripetal force would be necessary to maintain the circular motion.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:A higher speed will increase the value ofmv2r\dfrac{mv^2}{r}rmv2​, resulting in the need for a higher value for the coefficient of frictionμ\muμ.

list.title: Question 172
list.content:
Two electrons are accelerated inside a particle accelerator up to a speed0.8c0.8c0.8crelative to the accelerator. Both are moving in opposite directions towards a head-on collision.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4a31759-5774-443f-82e1-5dd13a56b92f/images/1fa5c54d-7d31-4a39-8932-1652c0248e9d/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.40.37%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following best describes the speed of each electron as observed from the reference frame of the other electron?A.\hspace{1em}0.82c0.82c0.82cB.\hspace{1em}0.98c0.98c0.98cC.\hspace{1em}1.24c1.24c1.24cD.\hspace{1em}1.60c1.60c1.60c
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Let's first consider the reference frame in which the electron moving to the left is at rest (frameSSS). Within this frame, the particle accelerator moves to the right with a velocity of0.8c0.8c0.8c. This is the speed of the reference frame that we transforming out of, which isvvvin our transformation equation. Using the direction to the right as positive, we setv=0.8cv=0.8cv=0.8c.Within the reference frame of the particle accelerator (frameS′S'S′), the electron moving towards the right moves with a velocityu′=0.8cu'=0.8cu′=0.8c.We can use the expression foru′u'u′:u′=u−v1−uvc2u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\frac{uv}{c^2}}u′=1−c2uv​u−v​That can be solved foruuu, leading to:u=u′+v1+u′vc2u=\dfrac{u'+v}{1+\frac{u'v}{c^2}}u=1+c2u′v​u′+v​We can now substitute our values forvvvandu′u'u′:u=0.8c+0.8c1+(0.8c)(0.8c)c2u=\dfrac{0.8c+0.8c}{1+\frac{(0.8c)(0.8c)}{c^2}}u=1+c2(0.8c)(0.8c)​0.8c+0.8c​u≈0.976cu\approx0.976cu≈0.976c

list.content:
In an experiment, the free-fall of a ball bearing is used to measure the acceleration due to gravity. The ball bearing is suspended with an electromagnet. Then it is released from a height ofhhhabove a table.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/b0277bbd-a6fc-4971-907d-53ec8cd7191f/PH0511_A.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]The timetneeded for the ball bearing to reach the ground after release is measured. The experiment is repeated for different values ofhhh. The theoretically predicted relationship between timetandhist2=2hgt^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}t2=g2h​State why there is a need to collect data for a range of values ofhhhto verify this relationship.[1]The experimental data fort2t^2t2andhare plotted on the graph below.

Draw the line of best fit for the plotted data on the graph.[1]Suggest whether the data is consistent with the theoretical prediction.[2]By using the line of best fit, determine a value forgand state the units.[4]The theoretical relationship is for an object falling in a vacuum.Compare the experimental result to the accepted value ofgand suggest a reason for the discrepancy.[2]State and explain whether the source of error in (c)(i) is a systematic or random error.[2]
list.markScheme:
To prove the relationship betweent2t^2t2andhdifferent values are needed to find a trendORto reduce random error✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To prove a relationship, one piece of data is not enough. The relationship can be generalized by using a graph where multiple points can reveal a trend. More data allows for drawing a graph that can support the relationship. Additionally, using more data and taking the average of them reduces the amount of random error.A straight line with roughly equal numbers of points above and below the line✓\checkmark✓

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/e907ca39-4906-4c19-acce-6de827b937d7/Screenshot%202025-04-16%20at%209.01.10%E2%80%AFAM.png)

≪\ll≪According to the theory≫\gg≫t2t^2t2is proportional tohhhORt2∝h{t^2}\propto\ ht2∝h✓\checkmark✓A best-fit line that is a straight line that passes through the origin can be drawn✓\checkmark✓≪\ll≪Yes≫\gg≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to the predicted relationship;t2∝ht^2\propto ht2∝hThis relationship suggests that the graph should be a straight line which passes through the origin. According to plotted data, that kind of straight line can be drawn.Rearrangement of the formula to solve forgggg=2ht2g=2\dfrac{h}{t^2}g=2t2h​✓\checkmark✓Using a correct  data point on the lineORCorrect calculation of  the gradient✓\checkmark✓gis between9.0 and 9.5✓\checkmark✓ms−2\ce{m s}^{-2}ms−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The given formula ist2=2hgt^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}t2=g2h​The gradient is therefore equal to2g\dfrac{2}{g}g2​.Finding the gradient givesgradient =0.190.9=0.21\dfrac{0.19}{0.9}=0.210.90.19​=0.21Solving forggg:0.21=2g0.21 = \dfrac{2}{g}0.21=g2​g=20.21=9.5ms−2g=\dfrac{2}{0.21}=9.5\ \ce{m s}^{-2}g=0.212​=9.5ms−2Experimental result is lower✓\checkmark✓There is air resistance which≪\ll≪will result in using exaggerated value of time in the equation≫\gg≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The timetshould be smaller than the measured value under the frictionless environment. According to the equation,g=2(ht2)g=2\bigg(\dfrac{h}{t^2}\bigg)g=2(t2h​)Therefore in the absence of air resistance, the experimental value forht2\dfrac{h}{t^2}t2h​would be greater than the values obtained in this experiment. Therefore, the calculated value is lower than the accepted value.Systematic✓\checkmark✓The result of the experiment is always less than the actual value/results are biased in one direction only✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The error is the result of the design of the experiment and leads to the results always being less than the actual value. Therefore, it is systematic.

list.content:
In an Atwood machine, two blocks of masses2.02.02.0kg and4.04.04.0kg are connected with a massless string that passes over a pulley. The pulley has a radiusrrrof0.250.250.25m.

The masses are released from rest and the tensions created on the strings attached to the masses of2.02.02.0kg and4.04.04.0kg areT1T_1T1​andT2T_2T2​respectively. The acceleration of the mass of2.02.02.0kg is2.32.32.3m s−2^{-2}−2.Determine the values forT1T_1T1​andT2T_2T2​.[3]Show that the angular acceleration of the pulley is approximately999rad s−2^{-2}−2.[2]Calculate the angular speed of the pulley after3.03.03.0s.[2]By using the answer in (i) and the information in (ii), calculate the moment of inertiaIIIof the pulley.[3]Discuss whether the pulley is in rotational equilibrium or translational equilibrium.[3]On another occasion, the same pulley's rotation is controlled by a motor. The variation of the pulley's angular velocity with time is shown on the graph below.

Identify the quantities that are represented by the area under the graph and the gradient of the graph.[2]On the graph below, sketch the variation of torqueΓ\GammaΓon the pulley with time. (There is no need to add values to the axes.)[2]

The system starts from rest and the angular velocity of the pulley att=4.0t=4.0t=4.0s is4.04.04.0rad s−1^{-1}−1. Calculate the number of revolutions made by the pulley betweent=0t=0t=0s andt=4.0t=4.0t=4.0s.[3]
list.markScheme:
Correct usage of Newton's 2nd law✓\checkmark✓T1=(2.0)(2.3)+(2.0)(9.81)=T_1=\left(2.0\right)\left(2.3\right)+\left(2.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=T1​=(2.0)(2.3)+(2.0)(9.81)=24 N✓\checkmark✓T2=(4.0)(−2.3)+(4.0)(9.81)=T_2=\left(4.0\right)\left(-2.3\right)+\left(4.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=T2​=(4.0)(−2.3)+(4.0)(9.81)=30 N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Two forces are acting on the mass of2.02.02.0kg as tensionT1T_1T1​and weightW1W_1W1​. By using Newton's second law:T1−W1=maT_1-W_1=maT1​−W1​=mawheremmmis 2.0 kg andaaais2.32.32.3m s−2^{-2}−2T1−(2.0)(9.81)=(2.0)(2.3)T_1-(2.0)(9.81)=(2.0)(2.3)T1​−(2.0)(9.81)=(2.0)(2.3)T1=(2.0)(2.3)+(2.0)(9.81)=24.2T_1=\left(2.0\right)\left(2.3\right)+\left(2.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=24.2T1​=(2.0)(2.3)+(2.0)(9.81)=24.2NSince the two masses are connected, they should have the same magnitude of acceleration. There are two forces acting on the mass of4.04.04.0kg as tensionT3T_3T3​and weightW1W_1W1​. By using Newton's second law and a sign convention where upwards is positive:T2−W1=m(−a)T_2-W_1=m(-a)T2​−W1​=m(−a)wheremmmis4.04.04.0kgT2−(4.0)(9.81)=(4.0)(−2.3)T_2-(4.0)(9.81)=(4.0)(-2.3)T2​−(4.0)(9.81)=(4.0)(−2.3)T2=(4.0)(−2.3)+(4.0)(9.81)=30.0T_2=\left(4.0\right)\left(-2.3\right)+\left(4.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=30.0T2​=(4.0)(−2.3)+(4.0)(9.81)=30.0Nα=ar=2.30.25\alpha=\dfrac{a}{r}=\dfrac{2.3}{0.25}α=ra​=0.252.3​✓\checkmark✓α=\alpha=α=9.29.29.2rad s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓An extra significant figure should be shown to obtain the second marking point.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The relationship between angular accelerationα\alphaαand linear accelerationaaa:α=ar=2.30.25\alpha=\dfrac{a}{r}=\dfrac{2.3}{0.25}α=ra​=0.252.3​α=9.2rads−2\alpha=9.2{\ rad\,s}^{-2}α=9.2rads−2ωf=0+(9.2)(3.0)\omega_f=0+\left(9.2\right)\left(3.0\right)ωf​=0+(9.2)(3.0)✓\checkmark✓\hspace{1.5em}=282828rad s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular speedωf\omega_fωf​at an instant under the constant angular accelerationα\alphaα:ωf=ωi+αt\omega_f=\omega_i+\alpha\ tωf​=ωi​+αtwhereωi\omega_iωi​is the initial angular speedωf=0+(9.2)(3.0)=27.6\omega_f=0+\left(9.2\right)\left(3.0\right)=27.6ωf​=0+(9.2)(3.0)=27.6rad s−1^{-1}−1Torque=(30−24)(0.25)=1.5=\left(30-24\right)\left(0.25\right)=1.5=(30−24)(0.25)=1.5N m✓\checkmark✓I=1.59.2I=\dfrac{1.5}{9.2}I=9.21.5​✓\checkmark✓=\hspace{1em} ==0.160.160.16kg m2^22✓\checkmark✓Accept different answers due to error carried forward from (i)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The net torqueτ\tauτacting on the pulley:τ=(T2−T1)r\tau  = (T_2 - T_1)rτ=(T2​−T1​)rτ=(30−24)(0.25)=1.5\tau  = (30 - 24)(0.25) = 1.5τ=(30−24)(0.25)=1.5N mThe relationship between the torque and the moment of inertia I of the pulley:τ=Iα\tau  = I \alphaτ=IαI=τα=1.59.2=0.16I = \dfrac{\tau}{\alpha}  = \dfrac{1.5}{9.2} = 0.16I=ατ​=9.21.5​=0.16kg m2^22Non-zero torque/non-zero angular accelerationNot in rotational equilibrium✓\checkmark✓Zero resultant force/ zero acceleration (✓\checkmark✓) in translational equilibrium (✓\checkmark✓).Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Rotational equilibrium occurs when the resultant torque is zero or angular acceleration is zero. Due to the existence of non-zero resultant torque and non-zero rotational acceleration, the pulley is not in rotational equilibrium.Since the pulley is fixed in place, the upwards force supporting the pulley must be equal to the sum of the downwards forces from tensions in the strings. Since this is true, the acceleration of the pulley is zero and it is in translational equilibrium.Area underneath the graph =angulardisplacement✓\checkmark✓Gradient =angularacceleration✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular accelerationα\alphaα:α=ΔωΔt\alpha =\dfrac{\Delta \omega}{\Delta t}α=ΔtΔω​= gradient of the graphThe angular displacementθ\thetaθ:θ=ωt\theta = \omega tθ=ωt= area underneath the graphHorizontal line✓\checkmark✓A non-zero y-intercept✓\checkmark✓

Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular accelerationα\alphaα:α=Δωt\alpha = \dfrac{\Delta \omega}{t}α=tΔω​= gradient of the graphSince the angular velocity against the time graph is a straight line, the gradient of the graph is constant. Therefore, the angular acceleration is constant.Torqueτ\tauτacting on the pulley:τ=Iα\tau =I \alphaτ=Iαsince the moment of inertia and angular acceleration are constant, torque does not change.α=Δωt=ωf−ωit=4.0−04=1.0\alpha = \dfrac{\Delta \omega}{t} = \dfrac{\omega_f - \omega_i}{t} = \dfrac{4.0-0}{4} = 1.0α=tΔω​=tωf​−ωi​​=44.0−0​=1.0rad s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓θ=ωit+12αt2=0+(12)(1.0)(4)2=8.0\theta=\omega_it+\dfrac{1}{2}\alpha\ t^2=0+\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(1.0\right)\left(4\right)^2=8.0θ=ωi​t+21​αt2=0+(21​)(1.0)(4)2=8.0rad✓\checkmark✓The number of revolutions=82π== \dfrac{8}{2\pi}==2π8​=1.31.31.3✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular accelerationα\alphaα:α=Δωt=ωf−ωit=4.0−04=1.0\alpha = \dfrac{\Delta \omega}{t} = \dfrac{\omega_f - \omega_i}{t} = \dfrac{4.0-0}{4} = 1.0α=tΔω​=tωf​−ωi​​=44.0−0​=1.0rad s−1^{-1}−1The angular displacementθ\thetaθ:θ=ωit+12αt2=0+(12)(1.0)(4)2=8.0rad\begin{aligned}
\theta&=\omega_it+\frac{1}{2}\alpha\ t^2\\
&=0+\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(1.0\right)\left(4\right)^2\\
&=8.0\textrm{ rad}
\end{aligned}θ​=ωi​t+21​αt2=0+(21​)(1.0)(4)2=8.0rad​The number of revolutionsnnn:n=82π=1.27n=\dfrac{8}{2\pi}=1.27n=2π8​=1.27

list.title: Question 175
list.content:
In a distant future, an area on Earth with dimensions of2.02.02.0ly and5.05.05.0ly, as measured by a stationary observer on Earth, is reserved for a spaceship road. The diagram illustrates the area and the direction of motion for a spaceship moving at a speed of0.6c0.6c0.6c.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e2f4cb87-adf9-4570-b763-3840e1a3f0c8/images/af135792-1b90-4339-acd6-bf2466bac6c3/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.44.53%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the area of the road from the perspective of the observer in the spaceship?A.6.4\hspace{1em}  	6.46.4ly2^22B.8.0\hspace{1em}  	8.08.0ly2^22C.10\hspace{1em}  	1010ly2^22D.13\hspace{1em}  	1313ly2^22
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Proper length (measured at rest relative to the road)L0:L_0:L0​:L0=5.0L_0=5.0L0​=5.0lyLorentz factor for the situation:γ=11−v2c2=11−(0.6c)2c2=54\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{{(0.6c)}^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{5}{4}γ=1−c2v2​​1​=1−c2(0.6c)2​​1​=45​The lengthLLLof the road measured by the observer in the spaceship:L=L0γ=5.054=4.0L=\dfrac{L_0}{\gamma}=\dfrac{5.0}{\frac{5}{4}}=4.0L=γL0​​=45​5.0​=4.0lyThe velocity of the spaceship does not have any component along the width of the road. Hence, the width of the road is measured as the same as a stationary observer on earth.The area A:A=(4.0)(2.0)=8.0A=\left(4.0\right)\left(2.0\right)=8.0A=(4.0)(2.0)=8.0ly2^22

s}^{-1}0.055kg s−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The forceFFFapplied to the box;F=Δpt=Δ(mv)tF=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}F=tΔp​=tΔ(mv)​Sincevvvis constant;F=vΔmtF=\dfrac{v\Delta m}{t}F=tvΔm​WhenΔmt\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}tΔm​is replaced withσ\sigmaσ;F=vσF=v\sigmaF=vσFv=σ\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigmavF​=σwhereF=0.11F=0.11F=0.11N andv=2.0v=2.0v=2.0m s−1^{-1}−1σ=0.112.0=0.055\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}=0.055σ=2.00.11​=0.055kg s−1^{-1}−1Useful power \gg=≪75%0.22​×100%=≫0.29 W✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The useful power outputPoP_oPo​of the
