list.title: Question 177
list.content:
Two bodies of masses 2 kg and 3 kg are connected by a thread and pulled in the upward direction with an acceleration ofgggdue to an upward forceFFF.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb9106b9-d99e-4523-b2e9-efa16a2c17a6/images/cbe0daf4-7e77-4429-a129-869ae3fb9bb1/PH0245q.JPEG)

The thread between the masses is cut. Which of the following is correct for the bodies just after the cut?Acceleration of 3 kg massAcceleration of 2 kg mass\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}gggggg\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}4g4g4gggg\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}4g4g4g4g4g4g\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}ggg4g4g4g
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:F=maF = maF=maBefore the thread is cut,F−W=maF - W = maF−W=mafor the systemW=mg=5gW = mg = 5gW=mg=5gandma=5g\ ma=5gma=5gThereforeF=5g+5g=10gF = 5g + 5g = 10gF=5g+5g=10gJust after the cut, the 3 kg mass is only under the influence of gravity, so its accleration is equal togggThe net force on the 2 kg mass isF−2g=10g−2g=8gF - 2g = 10g - 2g= 8gF−2g=10g−2g=8gAcceleration of the 3 kg mass =gggAcceleration of 2 kg mass =8g2=4g\dfrac{8g}{2} = 4g28g​=4g

list.title: Question 178
list.content:
An object of massmmmand initial velocityvvvcollides with a stationary object of mass2m2m2m.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f1971e54-30eb-442a-aa50-607973aad940/images/3fb732f1-87a9-449f-b833-c4c911243712/Screenshot%202025-03-25%20at%207.24.54%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

After the collision the object of mass2m2m2mmoves with velocity2v3\dfrac{2v}{3}32v​.  What is the final velocity of the object of massmmmand the magnitude of impulse of the collision?Final velocity of mass\textrm{Final velocity of mass}Final velocity of massmmm\hspace{1.5em}Impulse\textrm{Impulse}Impulse\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}−v3\dfrac{-v}{3}3−v​2mv3\dfrac{2mv}{3}32mv​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}−v3\dfrac{-v}{3}3−v​4mv3\dfrac{4mv}{3}34mv​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​2mv3\dfrac{2mv}{3}32mv​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​4mv3\dfrac{4mv}{3}34mv​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using conservation of momentum, we set the initial momentum equal of the system equal to the final momentum. We can represent the final velocity of the object of massmmmasvfmv_{fm}vfm​. Applying the law of conservation of momentum givesmv=mvfm+2m(2v3)mv=mv_{fm}+2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)mv=mvfm​+2m(32v​)v=vfm+2(2v3)v=v_{fm}+2\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)v=vfm​+2(32v​)vfm=v−4v3=−v3v_{fm}=v-\dfrac{4v}{3}=\dfrac{-v}{3}vfm​=v−34v​=3−v​The negative sign represents the fact that the smaller mass will bounce backwards in the collision.ImpulseJJJis equal to change in momentum.J=mΔvJ=m\Delta vJ=mΔvThe simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.J=mΔv=2m(2v3−0)=4mv3J=m\Delta v=2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}-0\right)=\dfrac{4mv}{3}J=mΔv=2m(32v​−0)=34mv​

list.title: Question 179
list.content: A spherical raindrop falls at a terminal speed ofvvv. Its density isρ\rhoρand its radius isrrrWhich of the following expressions is correct forvvv? (Buoyancy acting on the raindrop is insignificant)A.v=2gρr29η\hspace{1em}  		v=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{9\eta}v=9η2gρr2​B.v=2gρr3η\hspace{1em}  		v=\dfrac{2g\rho r}{3\eta}v=3η2gρr​C.v=24π2gηρr43\hspace{1em}  	v=\dfrac{24\pi^2g\eta\rho r^4}{3}v=324π2gηρr4​D.v=2gρr23η\hspace{1em}  	v=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{3\eta}v=3η2gρr2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The massmmmof the raindrop can be expressed asm=ρV=ρ43πr3m=\rho V=\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3m=ρV=ρ34​πr3When the weight of the raindrop is balanced with the drag force, it falls at a constant speed:mg=6πηrvmg=6\pi\eta rvmg=6πηrvWhenmmmis replaced with the expression above:ρ43πr3g=6πηrv\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3g=6\pi\eta rvρ34​πr3g=6πηrvSolving forvvvgivesv=ρ43πr3g6πηr=2gρr29ηv=\dfrac{\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3g}{6\pi\eta r}=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{9\eta}v=6πηrρ34​πr3g​=9η2gρr2​

list.title: Question 180
list.content: A spherical object of radiusrrris released from rest inside a fluid, after some time it reaches a terminal velocityvvv. The density of the fluid isρf\rho_fρf​and the density of the object is negligible compared toρf\rho_fρf​. Which of the following is a correct expression for the viscosity of the fluid?A.\hspace{1em}2ρfr2g9v\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}9v2ρf​r2g​B.\hspace{1em}4ρfr3g9v\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3g}{9v}9v4ρf​r3g​C.\hspace{1em}2ρfr2gv9\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2gv}{9}92ρf​r2gv​D.\hspace{1em}4ρfr3gv9\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3gv}{9}94ρf​r3gv​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Because of the very low density of the object, in this situation it will be rising upwards through the fluid and the drag force will be directed downwards. The forces acting on the object are represented in the diagram below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fd1b8088-49d6-4cf0-a32e-2f667b767317/images/54c6d222-8e3b-49ea-a0d9-c1152711872e/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.35.15%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Weight is negligible due to the negligible object density.ρobject≪ρf\rho_{\textrm{object}}\ll\rho_fρobject​≪ρf​(weight=ρobjectVg≪ρobjectVg=buoyancy)(\textrm{weight}=\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg\ll\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg=\textrm{buoyancy})(weight=ρobject​Vg≪ρobject​Vg=buoyancy)When the object is at terminal velocity the net force acting on it is zero so we have:weight=drag force\textrm{weight}=\textrm{drag force}weight=drag forceWhere:Buoyancy=ρfVg=\rho_fVg=ρf​VgDrag=6πηrv=6\pi\eta rv=6πηrvWheregggis acceleration due to gravity,VVVis the volume of the ball, andη\etaηis the viscosity of the liquid.ρfVg=6πηrv\rho_fVg=6\pi\eta rvρf​Vg=6πηrvNow substituting the volume of a sphereV=43πr3V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3V=34​πr3and rearranging forη\etaηwe have:ρf43r3g=6πηrv\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^3g=6\pi\eta rvρf​34​r3g=6πηrvρf43r2g=6ηv\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^2g=6\eta vρf​34​r2g=6ηvη=2ρfr2g9v\eta=\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}η=9v2ρf​r2g​

list.title: Question 181
list.content:
A stationary object explodes and splits into two parts of massesmmmand2m2m2m. Massmmmmoves north with a velocity of2v2v2vand mass2m2m2mmoves south with a velocity ofvvv. Calculate the total change in linear momentum of the system as a result of the explosion.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff2acbba-2403-4a67-b180-9dbd6ab500fe/images/84602be2-5f8f-4366-be5d-8b3dd6c7f170/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.56.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

A.\hspace{1em}ZeroB.\hspace{1em}1.5mv1.5mv1.5mvC.\hspace{1em}4mv4mv4mvD.\hspace{1em}6mv6mv6mv
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The change in the momentum of the system in the explosion is zero, as the system is isolated and therefore momentum is conserved.

list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:FΔt=ΔpF\Delta t=\Delta pFΔt=Δpso the amount of momentum added increases linearly with time.However the total momentum is the vector sum (not the algebraic sum) of the momenta. Initial momentump0p_0p0​and added momentumFtFtFtare perpendicular.Refer to the diagram below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/975a1976-eca9-4d1d-8c22-3678a3326559/images/2c1efa10-931e-4f50-8b4a-3599850a1dd4/image.png)

WhenFtFtFtis much smaller thanp0p_0p0​:p≈p0p\approx p_0p≈p0​- graph will be flat close tot=0t=0t=0.WhenFtFtFtis much larger thanp0p_0p0​, the effect ofp0p_0p0​on the total momentum will become insignificant:p≈Ftp\approx Ftp≈Ft- the shape of graph will tend towards a straight line with gradient ofFFF.Answer is B.A is incorrect - This graph tends towards a constant value, but momentum will continue to increase.C is incorrect - momentum will not increase linearly.p2=p02+(Ft)2p^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2p2=p02​+(Ft)2D is incorrect - There is no reason to think momentum will increase, plateau and then increase again.Alternative solution‾\underline{\text{Alternative solution}}Alternative solution​using Pythagoras, we can see thatp2=p02+(Ft)2p^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2p2=p02​+(Ft)2Whent=0t=0t=0:p=p0p=p_0p=p0​Let us findtttsuch thatp=2p0p=2p_0p=2p0​(the time at which momentum has doubled).(2p0)2=p02+(Ft)2(2p_0 )^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2(2p0​)2=p02​+(Ft)24p02=p02+(Ft)24p_0^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^24p02​=p02​+(Ft)23p02=(Ft)23p_0^2=(Ft)^23p02​=(Ft)23p0=Ft\sqrt{3p_0}=Ft3p0​​=Ftt=3p0Ft=\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{F}t=F3p0​​​Now if we consider the momentum at half this timet=3p02Ft=\dfrac{\sqrt{3p_0}}{2F}t=2F3p0​​​p2=p02+(F3p02F)2p^2=p_0^2+\Bigl(F \dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{2F}\Bigr)^2p2=p02​+(F2F3p0​​​)2p2=p02+(3p02)2p^2=p_0^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{2}\Bigr)^2p2=p02​+(23p0​​​)2p2=p02+34p02p^2=p_0^2+\dfrac{3}{4} p_0^2p2=p02​+43​p02​p2=1.75p02p^2=1.75p_0^2p2=1.75p02​p=1.75p0<1.5p0p=\sqrt{1.75}p_0 < 1.5p_0p=1.75​p0​<1.5p0​Whent=0t=0t=0:p=p0p=p_0p=p0​Whent=3p02Ft=\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{2F}t=2F3p0​​​:p<1.5p0p<1.5p_0p<1.5p0​Whent=3p0Ft=\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{F}t=F3p0​​​:p<2p0p<2p_0p<2p0​So curve must be B.

list.title: Question 183
list.content: A firecracker is at rest just before exploding. Upon exploding, the firecracker splits into two unequal parts which are projected in exactly opposite directions. Which of the following must be true?A.\hspace{1em}The total kinetic energy of the firecracker remains unchanged before and after the explosion.B.\hspace{1em}The kinetic energy of the two parts after the explosion is identical.C.\hspace{1em}The total momentum of the firecracker is unchanged after the explosion.D.\hspace{1em}The velocities of the two parts are exactly equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A. Incorrect. BecauseEkE_kEk​changed from zero to non-zero because the chemical potential energy in the firecracker is converted into kinetic energy which is divided between the two parts after the explosion.B. Incorrect. BecauseEk=(p22m)E_k=\left(\dfrac{p^2}{2m}\right)Ek​=(2mp2​)and the momenta must be equal, the kinetic energies must be unequal as the masses are not equal.C. Correct. Momentum is always conserved in any process for an isolated system.D. Incorrect. Because since momentum is conserved, unequal parts must have unequal velocities.

list.title: Question 184
list.content:
An object of massmmmrests on a rough surface. Another object of massMMMis connected to it via a frictionless pulley. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the surface and the object of massmmmisμ\muμ.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05d91a08-8de6-402e-8cdc-523e298b8e9e/images/3cc24a0e-924d-46a5-9506-bc8a67c37f66/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%201.47.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

When the object of massMMMis released, the objects accelerate. What is the acceleration of the system?A.\hspace{1em}gMM+m\dfrac{gM}{M+m}M+mgM​B.\hspace{1em}gmM+m\dfrac{gm}{M+m}M+mgm​C.\hspace{1em}g(M−μm)M+m\dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}M+mg(M−μm)​D.\hspace{1em}g(μm−M)M+m\dfrac{g(\mu m-M)}{M+m}M+mg(μm−M)​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The resultant force is the difference between the weight of the object of massMMMand the force of friction between the object of massmmmand the rough surface.Fnet=Fg−Ff=mtotalaF_{net} = F_g - F_f =m_{total}aFnet​=Fg​−Ff​=mtotal​aWeight of the objectFg=MgF_g= MgFg​=MgFriction on massmmmFf=μmgF_f= \mu mgFf​=μmgMtotal=M+mM_{total}=M+mMtotal​=M+mSubstituting into the first equation,Mg−μmg=(M+m)aMg - \mu mg = (M+m)aMg−μmg=(M+m)aBy rearranging;a=g(M−μm)M+ma = \dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}a=M+mg(M−μm)​Therefore, The answer is C.

list.title: Question 185
list.content:
A cannonball is fired horizontally from a cannon positioned at the edge of a cliff.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/075709d5-6b82-4c14-84e3-4e295554dd8f/images/a8bab8c2-0aad-4a4d-8b10-7371910c8ac9/PH0562zzz.png)

In the context of Newton's Laws, explain why the cannon recoils to the left when the cannonball is fired.[2]The initial recoil speed of the cannon is1.01.01.0m s−1^{-1}−1and its mass is 1200 kg.After the ball is fired, the cannon rolls to the left and experiences a resistive force of8.08.08.0kN as it rolls. Determine the distance covered by the cannon.[2]The mass of the cannonball is9.09.09.0kg. Show that the magnitude of the velocity of the ball after being fired is approximately133133133m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Calculate the magnitude of the displacement of the cannonball after5.05.05.0s.  Air resistance can be ignored.[3]
list.markScheme: By Newton's 3rd law, there is a force to the right acting on the cannonball✓\checkmark✓There is an equal and opposite force (to the left) on the cannon✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There is a force acting on the cannonball during the firing. According to Newton's third law, there must be an equal and opposite force on the cannon.a=Fm=80001200=6.7a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7a=mF​=12008000​=6.7m s−2^{-2}−2s=v22a=1(2)(6.7)=s=\dfrac{v^2}{2a}=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=s=2av2​=(2)(6.7)1​=0.074 mFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The decelerationaof the cannon is:a=Fm=80001200=6.7a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7a=mF​=12008000​=6.7m s−2^{-2}−2The distancescan be calculated using the uniform acceleration equationsv2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswherev=0v=0v=0u=1u=1u=1m s−1^{-1}−1a=−6.7a=-6.7a=−6.7m s−2^{-2}−20=12+(2)(−6.7)s0=1^2+(2)(-6.7)s0=12+(2)(−6.7)ss=1(2)(6.7)=0.074s=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=0.074s=(2)(6.7)1​=0.074mAny reference to the conservation of momentum✓\checkmark✓v2=(−m1)(v1)m2=−(1200)(1.0)9.0=≪v_2 = \dfrac{(-m_1)(v_1)}{m_2} = \dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0} = \llv2​=m2​(−m1​)(v1​)​=9.0−(1200)(1.0)​=≪-133 m s−1≫^{-1} \gg−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Due to the conservation of momentum, the total momentum of the objects before the firing should be equal to the total momentum of the objects after the firing.The total momentum of the objects before the firing is zero due to the absence of motion. Therefore there total momentum of the objects after firing is also zero0=m1v1+m2v20=m_1v_1+m_2v_20=m1​v1​+m2​v2​wherem1=1200m_1=1200m1​=1200kgv1=1v_1=1v1​=1m s−1^{-1}−1m2=9.0m_2=9.0m2​=9.0kgv2=−m1v1m2=−(1200)(1.0)9.0=−133v_2=\dfrac{{-m}_1v_1}{m_2}=\dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0}=-133v2​=m2​−m1​v1​​=9.0−(1200)(1.0)​=−133m s−1^{-1}−1The negative sign represents the direction of the velocity. Therefore it is opposite to the direction of the motion of the cannon.Horizontal displacement=vt=(133)(5.0)=666=vt=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666=vt=(133)(5.0)=666m✓\checkmark✓Vertical displacement=ut+\fdrac12at2=12(9.81)(52)=122ut+\fdrac{1}{2}at^2=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122ut+\fdrac12at2=21​(9.81)(52)=122m✓\checkmark✓Displacement of the cannonball=6662+1222==\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}==6662+1222​=677 m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Due to the absence of air resistance, the horizontal velocity of the ball is constant and vertical velocity increases with the acceleration of free fall. The horizontal displacementxof the cannonballx=vtx=vtx=vtwherev=133v=133v=133m s−1^{-1}−1andt=3.0t=3.0t=3.0sx=(133)(5.0)=666x=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666x=(133)(5.0)=666mThe vertical displacementyof the cannonbally=ut+12at2y=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2y=ut+21​at2whereu=0u=0u=0a=9.81a=9.81a=9.81m s−1^{-1}−1t=5.0st=5.0\, st=5.0sy=12(9.81)(52)=122y=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122\,y=21​(9.81)(52)=122mThe magnitude of the displacementscan be found by using Pythagoras's theorem;s=x2+y2s=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}s=x2+y2​s=6662+1222=677s=\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}=677s=6662+1222​=677m

list.title: Question 186
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of speedvvvof a ball with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13b5c41f-9e6b-4937-8397-65c5b2d2336e/images/5281444d-ae8d-4868-83f7-f80dd8085194/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.10.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The initial speed of the ball is very high. Which of the following statements could be true for the ball?A. It is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance.B. It is thrown vertically upward in the absence of air resistance.C. It is thrown vertically downward in the presence of air resistance.D. It is thrown vertically downward in the absence of air resistance.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the graph, the ball has a decreasing deceleration and reaches terminal velocity. Since the acceleration of the ball is not constant, air resistance must be acting on the ball. Air resistance always acts in the direction opposite to the velocity.In an upward motion, air friction and gravity are in the same direction. Therefore, it is not possible for them to cancel each other so that the ball reaches terminal velocity. It should be moving in the downward direction. Hence, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 187
list.content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energyEpE_pEp​when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]In terms ofEpE_pEp​, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?A.\hspace{1em}2EpE_pEp​B.\hspace{1em}EpE_pEp​C.\hspace{1em}0.5EpE_pEp​D.\hspace{1em}0.25EpE_pEp​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using Hooke's law,F=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔxthe elastic potential energy isEp=12kΔx2=12FΔxE_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta xEp​=21​kΔx2=21​FΔx.In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equationF=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔx.When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

list.title: Question 188
list.content:
Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/b43aec29-c2a0-4524-b402-66e35e1e23b1/PH0559MS.png)

State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction[2]Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface.[3]The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40.[2]Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m.[2]
list.markScheme:
Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forcesORstatic friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value✓\checkmark✓Component of weight parallel to the incline =≪mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫and tension in threadT=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39N✓\checkmark✓Static friction =≪39−15=≫24≪N≫\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪39−15=≫24≪N≫✓\checkmark✓coefficient of static friction =≪24(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=≫\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg≪(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)24​=≫0.96✓\checkmark✓(0.94 to 0.96 accepted)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weightWWW, tensionTTTstatic frictionFfF_fFf​and normal forceNNN;

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)

Weight has two components parallel to the inclineWhW_hWh​and perpendicular to the inclineWvW_vWv​;Wh=mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15Wh​=mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15N down to the slopeThe tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39NThe forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;Wh+Ff=T15+Ff=39Ff=24N\begin{aligned}
 W_h+F_f&=T\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 15+F_f&=39\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
 \end{aligned}Wh​+Ff​15+Ff​Ff​​=T=39=24N​By using the equation of static friction;Ff=μRμ(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=24μ=0.96\begin{aligned}
 F_f&=\mu R\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu&=0.96\\
 \end{aligned}Ff​μ(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)μ​=μR=24=0.96​The dynamic friction =≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡30°=≫10≪N≫\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos30°=≫10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓aaa=≪14.7−10.23=≫\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg≪314.7−10.2​=≫1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weightWhW_hWh​down to the slope and dynamic frictionFfF_fFf​up the slope. The dynamic friction;Ff=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=10F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10Ff​=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)=10NFnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma14.7−10.2=3.0a14.7-10.2=3.0a14.7−10.2=3.0aa=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2displacement of the mass =≪1.0sin⁡(30o)=≫2.0≪m≫\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg≪sin(30o)1.0​=≫2.0≪m≫✓\checkmark✓v=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)=≫2.4≪m s−1≫v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\ggv=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)​=≫2.4≪m s−1≫✓\checkmark✓ORHeat lost due to friction =≪Ffd=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg≪Ff​d=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫✓\checkmark✓vvv=≪(2)(9.0)(3.0)=≫\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg≪(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=≫2.4 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;s=1.0sin⁡(30o)=2.0s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0s=sin(30o)1.0​=2.0mBy using a suvat equation;v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswhileu=0u=0u=0,a=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2, ands=2.0s=2.0s=2.0mv2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v=2.4v=2.4v=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;The energy dissipated due to friction isQ=Ffd=(10)(2)=20Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20Q=Ff​d=(10)(2)=20Jand the change in gravitational potential energy can be found byΔEp=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29ΔEp​=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29JThe gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore29=ΔEk+2029=\Delta E_k+2029=ΔEk​+20ΔEk=9.0\Delta E_k=9.0ΔEk​=9.0JSolving for speed givesΔEk=12mv2\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2ΔEk​=21​mv2v=2ΔEkmv=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}v=m2ΔEk​​​v=(2)(9.0)(3.0)=2.4v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4v=(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 189
list.content:
An object is launched with an angle ofθ\thetaθfrom the ground and an initial velocity ofvvv.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/dbd07e55-801c-4572-895f-a7f3311a2d78/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.52.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which graph shows the variation of the horizontal componentvhv_hvh​of the velocity of the object with timettt? (Air resistance is not ignored)A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/122016ee-f9f7-45c0-b47a-29aae3f83c0d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.45.57%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/155655a5-993f-4307-84fe-c81857607d5d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.44.36%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/aeb0b614-67b2-47e5-82a0-d6f7ab903960/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.44.41%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b159bc3-967f-4a39-b366-5f3a36a20744/images/ed045a0d-bd03-4dac-a6d1-352058b23b1e/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2011.44.46%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The object starts its motion with non-zero horizontal velocity. Due to air resistance, It experiences negative acceleration (opposite to the direction of motion). The force from air resistance is proportional to the speed of the object. Since a decrease in speed results in a decrease in air resistance, the magnitude of negative acceleration should decrease over time. The gradient of thev−tv-tv−tgraphs indicates acceleration. The only graph that has a decreasing negative gradient is B.
Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 190
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since the tangential speed is constant for all tracks, then the angular speed is different for each track.The angular speed of the first track:ω1=vr1\omega_1=\dfrac{v}{r_1}ω1​=r1​v​ω1=1.525×10−3\omega_1=\dfrac{1.5}{25\times{10}^{-3}}ω1​=25×10−31.5​\hspace{2.9em}=60=60=60rad s−1^{-1}−1The angular speed of the last track will be less than that of the first track since the angular speed is inversely proportional to the radius of rotation.

list.title: Question 191
list.content:
The rotor ride in the amusement park consists of a vertical cylinder that rotates around its axis. Its floor drops down when it rotates fast enough, so that a person inside it is held against its walls. The walls are made of rubberized material such that the coefficient of static frictionμ<1\mu <1μ<1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/281ae2f3-a2fa-4ee9-a300-6c714b1e0255/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.40.27%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by  Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]}}[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]Explain in terms of forces how a person can remain suspended against the wall without falling when the floor is dropped.[3]Show that the maximum period of rotation for the person to remain at rest relative to the wall is given by\hspace{1em}T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​Whererrr= radius of the cylinderμ\muμ= coefficient of static friction between the wall and the person[3]The radius of the rotor is 4.5 m and the coefficient of static friction of the walls is 0.40.Calculate the angular speed of the cylinder necessary for this situation.[3]To make the ride more exciting, an idea of tilting the axis of the rotor by an angleθ\thetaθis discussed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/a0617516-bba2-4b35-88e7-31ebb403eb3d/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.38.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Draw and label the free body diagram of a person at pointAwhen the ride is in operation.[1]The cylinder is tilted a full 90°\degree°so that its axis of rotation is now horizontal. Deduce whether the minimum speed of rotation for this orientation is greater than or less than the minimum speed for the original situation with a vertical axis of rotation.[3]
list.markScheme:
The normal force provides the centripetal force,✓\checkmark✓Minimum speed is required / relation between normal force and linear speed.✓\checkmark✓Friction balances the weight.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The friction force of the wall on the person is affected by the normal force\hspace{1em}Ff=μFNF_f=\mu\ F_NFf​=μFN​The normal force of the walls in this situation is the centripetal force, which means it is affected by the linear velocity\hspace{1em}FN=Fc=mv2rF_N=F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}FN​=Fc​=rmv2​This means that, there's a minimum speed at which the magnitude of the normal force will be enough so that the friction force of the walls will balance the weight of the person and keep it at rest without falling.The person's weight is in equilibrium with the friction force of the wall.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/e2ca7f98-5e73-47f7-bb08-885c0300b78c/PH0651aaaa.png)

\hspace{1.5em}Ff=μFN=μmv2rF_f=\mu\ F_N=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Ff​=μFN​=μrmv2​✓\checkmark✓Ff=mgF_f\ = mgFf​=mgthereforev2=rgμv^2=\dfrac{rg}{\mu}v2=μrg​✓\checkmark✓T=2πrvv2r=4π2rT2T=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v} \dfrac{v^2}{r} = \dfrac{4 \pi^{2r}}{T^2}T=v2πr​rv2​=T24π2r​✓\checkmark✓substitute and solve to get answer≪T=4π2μrg≫\ll\ T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}\gg≪T=g4π2μr​​≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The normal force is the centripetal forceFN=mv2rF_N=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}FN​=rmv2​And the friction force is given byFf=μFNF_f=\mu\ F_NFf​=μFN​ThenFf=μmv2rF_f=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Ff​=μrmv2​Since the friction force is in equilibrium with the weightFf=mgF_f=mgFf​=mgThen\hspace{1em}μmv2r=mgμv2r=gv2=rgμv=rgμ\begin{aligned}
\mu\frac{mv^2}{r}\ &=mg\\
\mu\frac{v^2}{r}\ &=g\\
v^2\ &=\frac{rg}{\mu}\\
v\ &=\sqrt{\frac{rg}{\mu}}\\
\end{aligned}μrmv2​μrv2​v2v​=mg=g=μrg​=μrg​​​Since the linear speed is given byv=2πrTv=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}v=T2πr​ThenT=2πrv=2πrμrgT=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v}=2\pi\ r\sqrt{\dfrac{\mu}{rg}}T=v2πr​=2πrrgμ​​T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​ORSincev2r=4π2rT2\dfrac{v^2}{r}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}rv2​=T24π2r​ThenT2=4π2r2v2=4π2r2μrgT^2=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2}{v^2}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2\mu}{rg}T2=v24π2r2​=rg4π2r2μ​T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​T=≪(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)(9.8)≫=2.69≪s≫T=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}\gg=2.69\ \ll\textrm{ s}\ggT=≪(9.8)(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)​​≫=2.69≪s≫✓\checkmark✓ω=≪2πT≫\omega=\ll\dfrac{2\pi}{T}\ggω=≪T2π​≫ω=2π2.69\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}ω=2.692π​✓\checkmark✓ω=2.33≪rad s−1≫\omega=2.33\ \ll\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}\ggω=2.33≪rad s−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular speed is related to the linear speed byv=ωrv=\omega\ rv=ωrAndv=2πrTv=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}v=T2πr​Thenω=2πT\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{T}ω=T2π​SinceT=4π2μrg=(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)(9.8)=2.69T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}=2.69T=g4π2μr​​=(9.8)(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)​​=2.69sThenω=2π2.69=2.33\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}=2.33ω=2.692π​=2.33rad s−1^{-1}−1Correct orientationANDlabelling of vectors.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/d79f0d1d-d21c-4838-8097-f4b718e5ff44/PH0651c_MS.png)

Horizontal axis of rotation:v2=rgv^2  = rgv2=rg✓\checkmark✓Vertical axis of rotation:v2=(rg)μv^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}v2=μ(rg)​✓\checkmark✓μ<1\mu < 1μ<1,
therefore vertical minimum speed is greater than the horizontal minimum speed of rotation.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:For the horizontal axis of rotation, the minimum speed occurs when the centripetal acceleration at the top of the motion is equal to the acceleration due to gravity, resulting in a normal force of zero.v2r=g\dfrac{v^2}{r} = grv2​=gv2=rgv^2  = rgv2=rgFor the vertical axis,mv2r=FN\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = F_Nrmv2​=FN​FF=μFN=mgF_F = \mu F_N = mgFF​=μFN​=mgthereforeFN=mgμF_N= \dfrac{mg}{\mu}FN​=μmg​Which givesmv2r=mgμ\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = \dfrac{mg}{\mu}rmv2​=μmg​v2=(rg)μv^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}v2=μ(rg)​Because the question states thatμ<1\mu < 1μ<1The minimum speed for the vertical rotational axis is greater than the minimum speed for the horizontal axis of rotation.

list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To solve this, we should resolve the weight into componentsalong the slopeComponent of weight along the slope =mgsin⁡θmg\sin \thetamgsinθNormal reaction force (FNF_NFN​) is given bymgcos⁡θmg\cos\thetamgcosθDynamic friction =μdFN=μdmgcos⁡θ\mu_dF_N = \mu_d\,mg\cos \thetaμd​FN​=μd​mgcosθApply Newton's second law:Fnet=mgsin⁡θ−μdmgcos⁡θ=maF_{net}=mg\sin\theta - \mu_d\,mg\cos\theta =maFnet​=mgsinθ−μd​mgcosθ=maDividing both sides by mass givesa=gsin⁡θ−μdgcos⁡θa=g\sin\theta - \mu_d\,g\cos\thetaa=gsinθ−μd​gcosθ

Three identical cylinders sit inside a cup. Their radius of each is 5 cm and their centres of mass are marked in the diagram. The lines connecting the centres of the masses pass through the contact points between the cylinders.

Draw and label the free-body diagram for the cylinderM3M_3M3​[2]

Correct direction and labeling of the forces✓\checkmark✓The reaction force of the ground is greater than the other forces✓\checkmark✓Interactions  between the cylinders can be ignored/it allows only external forces to be analyzed✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Every cylinder experiences forces due to their weights and forces from the other cylinders and the container walls. To decrease complexity in representing forces on the objects, the cylinders are simplified as combined to form one object so that forces between the cylinders can be ignored and only external forces can be considered.Total weight of the cylinder = reaction of the ground onM3M_3M3​Weight of each cylinder =303=10≪N≫\dfrac{30}{3}=10\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg330​=10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓m=≪109.81=≫m=\ll\dfrac{10}{9.81}=\ggm=≪9.8110​=≫1.02≪kg≫1.02\ \ll\textrm{kg}\gg1.02≪kg≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When the three cylinders are considered as a single mass, the forces between the cylinders can be ignored. The vertical forces acting on the combined  masses are the weightWtW_tWt​of all discs and theRreaction force of the ground on theM3M_3M3​.Wt=RW_t=RWt​=RWt=30W_t=30Wt​=30NTherefore, the weight of one discWWWW=303=10W=\dfrac{30}{3}=10W=330​=10NSo, the massmmmof one discm=109.81=1.02m=\dfrac{10}{9.81}=1.02m=9.8110​=1.02kgThe weight of theM1M_1M1​is balanced by the vertical component of the force fromM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​✓\checkmark✓The reaction ofM3M_3M3​onM1=≪Wcos⁡θ=100.87=≫M_1=\ll\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=\ggM1​=≪cosθW​=0.8710​=≫11.5 N✓\checkmark✓ORReaction of theM3M_3M3​on theM1M_1M1​= Reaction of theM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​ANDReaction of theM2M_2M2​on theM3M_3M3​= Reaction of theM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​Reaction=≪N−W2(cos⁡θ)=30−10(2)(0.87)=≫11.5≪N≫\ll\dfrac{N-W}{2(\cos\theta)}=\dfrac{30-10\ }{\left(2\right)\left(0.87\right)}=\gg11.5\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪2(cosθ)N−W​=(2)(0.87)30−10​=≫11.5≪N≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The weight ofM1M_1M1​is supported by the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​. ThereforeW(cos⁡θ)=R31W(\cos\theta)=R_{31}W(cosθ)=R31​whereθ\thetaθis the angle shown on the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8759817a-d2cf-403b-9d88-6f93199347be/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The lengthLcan be found with the Pythagoras theoremL=102−52=8.7L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7L=102−52​=8.7cmFindingcos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθcos⁡θ=8.6710=0.87\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87cosθ=108.67​=0.87R31=Wcos⁡θR_{31}=\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}R31​=cosθW​R31=100.87=11.5R_{31}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=11.5R31​=0.8710​=11.5NAlternative solution‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}Alternative solution​:According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​equals the force of the reactionR13R_{13}R13​of theM1M_1M1​onM3M_3M3​. The vertical component of theR13R_{13}R13​can be found with the help of geometry

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/9338dc86-1aa1-47bc-9412-01f90ad79a7c/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The lengthLcan be found with the Pythagorean theoremL=102−52=8.7L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7L=102−52​=8.7cmFindingcos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθcos⁡θ=8.6710=0.87\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87cosθ=108.67​=0.87According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​equals the force of the reactionR13R_{13}R13​of theM1M_1M1​onM3M_3M3​. The vertical component of theR13R_{13}R13​can be found with the help of geometry

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/fd3e2f7a-53c9-48d7-a7ce-91d39a71b611/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.34.36%E2%80%AF0AM.JPEG)

The reaction ofM2M_2M2​on theM3M_3M3​and the reaction ofM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​must be equal to each other to cancel each other's horizontal components.M3M_3M3​is in equilibrium and vertical forces acting on cancel each other2(R13)(cosθ)+W=N2(R_{13})(cos\theta)+W=N2(R13​)(cosθ)+W=NR13=N−W2(cosθ)=30−10(2)(0.87)=11.5NR_{13}=\dfrac{N-W}{2(cos\theta)}=\dfrac{30-10\ }{(2)(0.87)}=11.5\ NR13​=2(cosθ)N−W​=(2)(0.87)30−10​=11.5N

list.content:
BlockAAAof massmA=3.0m_A=3.0mA​=3.0kg rests above the flat horizontal surface of blockBBBof massmB=6.0m_B=6.0mB​=6.0kg, which in turn rests on a smooth horizontal surface as shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/916d5984-df39-4104-8ae4-f0b1bc8e95d8/images/95a83caf-67bf-4f98-b1f3-d2746f45ddb2/Screensh0ot%202025-05-27%20at%201.33.09%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The coefficients of static and kinetic friction betweenAAAandBBBareμs=0.2\mu_s=0.2μs​=0.2andμk=0.1\mu_k=0.1μk​=0.1respectively. A horizontal force ofF=7.0F=7.0F=7.0N is applied towards the right on blockAAA. Assuming acceleration due to gravityg≈10g \approx 10g≈10m s−2^{-2}−2, the direction and magnitude of accelerationaBa_BaB​of blockBBBare:\hspace{1em}Direction ofaB\bf{a_B}aB​\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Magnitude ofaB\bf{a_B}aB​\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}To the left1.01.01.0m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}To the left0.50.50.5m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}To the right1.01.01.0m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}To the right0.50.50.5m s−2^{-2}−2
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The normal contact force onAAA,RA=mAg=(3.0R_A=m_A g=(3.0RA​=mA​g=(3.0kg) (10 m s−2)=30^{-2})=30−2)=30N(Contact force fromBBBsupports the weight ofAAA).The maximum friction on betweenAAAandBBBisFs=μsRA=(0.2)(30F_{s}=\mu_s R_A=(0.2)(30Fs​=μs​RA​=(0.2)(30N) = 6.0 N.The applied forceF=7.0N>fs,max=6.0F = 7.0\,N > f_{s,max}=6.0F=7.0N>fs,max​=6.0N.Therefore, blockAAAslides on blockBBB, reducing the final frictional force between the blocks to kinetic friction,Fk=μkRA=0.1×30F_k=\mu_k R_A=0.1 \times 30Fk​=μk​RA​=0.1×30N=3.0 N.OnAAA, this friction will be to the left (as it is being pulled to the right).Since friction onBBBis a reaction to friction onAAA, it will be to the right, and equal to3.03.03.0N. (Newton's third law).Using Newton's second law, the acceleration ofBBB,aB=FnetmB=fkmB=3.0N6.0kg=0.5a_B=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m_B} = \dfrac{f_k}{m_B} = \dfrac{3.0\textrm{ N}}{6.0\textrm{ kg}}=0.5aB​=mB​Fnet​​=mB​fk​​=6.0kg3.0N​=0.5m s−2^{-2}−2.Note:Friction is to the left on A. On B it is to the right.Acceleration will be 1.0 m s−2^{-2}−2if you use maximum static friction. Kinetic friction kicks in, sinceF(=7.0N)>Fs,max=μsmAg=6.0F(=7.0\textrm{ N}) > F_{s,max}=\mu_s m_A g=6.0F(=7.0N)>Fs,max​=μs​mA​g=6.0N.

list.title: Question 196
list.content: A ball is falling vertically in a liquid. The overall density of the ball and the density of the liquid are the same. Which of the following is correct for the change in speed of the ball and and the direction of the acceleration?\hspace{1.5em}The motion of the ball\hspace{1.5em}Acceleration\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Speeding upUpwards\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Slowing downUpwards\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Speeding upDownwards\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Slowing down\hspace{1.5em}Downwards\hspace{1.5em}
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards.The buoyancy :FB=ρliquidVgF_B = {\rho}_{liquid}VgFB​=ρliquid​VgWeight:W=mg=ρballVgW=mg={\rho}_{ball}VgW=mg=ρball​VgSince the density of the ball and the liquid are the same, weight and buoyancy cancel each other and the net force acting on the ball is the drag force. Due to having upward net force while moving downwards, the ball must be slowing down. Moreover, if the initial speed was zero at the time of contact with the water, the ball would experience zero net force. The drag force provides a net upwards force, so the acceleration of the ball is upwards.

list.title: Question 198
list.content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a07393e2-13b6-4cef-b722-c8894c128a01/images/c42117b3-7ee7-46c1-b4b9-bd159e6e5cb7/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.01.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)

A cart of massmmmenters a smooth vertical loop the loop of radiusRRRwith a horizontal speeduuuat the bottom of the track, as shown. The cart just manages to stay in contact with the track at the top most point of its path.Its speed at the bottom of the loopuuu, is given by:A.\hspace{1em}u=5gRu=\sqrt{5gR}u=5gR​B.\hspace{1em}u=4gRu=\sqrt{4gR}u=4gR​C.\hspace{1em}u=gRu=\sqrt{gR}u=gR​D.\hspace{1em}u=2gRu=\sqrt{2gR}u=2gR​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Conservation of energy:Ek+EpE_k + E_pEk​+Ep​at the bottom of the circle =Ek+EpE_k + E_pEk​+Ep​at the top of the circle.(I)\hspace{0.8em}12mu2+0=12mv2+mg(2R)\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2+0=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mg(2R)21​mu2+0=21​mv2+mg(2R)u2=v2+4gR\hspace{2.2em}u^2=v^2+4gRu2=v2+4gRCentripetal force at the top of the loop comes from the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force from the track which both point downwards, towards the centre of the circle at that point. Because the question states that the car just keeps contact with the the track, we can assume that the normal reaction force is effectively zero.Writing Newton’s second law at that point gives:mg+N=m(v2R)mg+0=m(v2R)v2=gR\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.7cm} mg+N &=m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
mg+0 &= m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
{v^2}&= gR \\
\end{aligned}mg+Nmg+0v2​=m(Rv2​)=m(Rv2​)=gR​Substituting this result into (I) givesu2=gR+4gRu^2=gR+4gRu2=gR+4gRu=5gRu=\sqrt{5gR}u=5gR​

CarAand CarBare travelling in the same direction along a straight line. In the reference frame of a stationary observer on the ground, CarAhas a speed of 24 m s−1^{-1}−1and CarBhas a speed of 36 m s−1^{-1}−1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a1dcef90-8b23-47fe-9a38-e1cf2ae1e509/images/4c9cd774-c4af-4390-b052-12d052beefc9/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.03.33%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Explain what is meant by a frame of reference.[2]Calculate the velocity of CarBrelative to the  observer in CarA.[2]The distance travelled by CarBrelative to CarAis 60 m in a time interval of 5.0 s. Use the galilean transformation equation to calculate the distance travelled by CarBrelative to the stationary observer on the ground for the same time interval.[2]Now consider two spaceships,CandD, traveling through space towards a planet.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a1dcef90-8b23-47fe-9a38-e1cf2ae1e509/images/f33ebdf8-036b-4962-8ad0-cbcac58dc83c/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.04.42%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Both of the spaceships turn on their lights. The turning on of the lights of spaceshipCand the turning of the lights of spaceshipDare defined as EventsCandDrespectively. EventChas coordinatesxC=3.456×105x_C = 3.456 \times {10}^5xC​=3.456×105m,tC=0t_C=0tC​=0s and eventDhas coordinatesxD=3.443×105x_D = 3.443 \times {10}^5xD​=3.443×105m,tD=1.1×10−3t_D = 1.1 \times {10}^{-3}tD​=1.1×10−3s according to a stationary observer on the planet.A rocket flies towards the two spaceships at a speed of0.85c0.85\ c0.85caccording to the same observer.According to the frame of reference of the rocket, determine the space differences between eventsCandD.[3]According to the frame of reference of the rocket, determine the space-time interval between eventsCandD.[3]Discuss whether EventCand EventDcan occur at the same time according to some other inertial frame.[2]

\left(0.85\right)\left(3.0\times10^8\right)\left(1.1\times10^{-3}\right))=Δx′=1.9(1.3×103−(0.85)(3.0×108)(1.1×10−3))=−5.3×105-5.3\times {10}^5−5.3×105m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The Lorentz factorγ\gammaγ:γ=11−v2c2=11−(0.85)2c2c2=1.9\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{{(0.85)}^2c^2}{c^2}}}=1.9γ=1−c2v2​​1​=1−c2(0.85)2c2​​1​=1.9Relative to the ground, space differenceΔx\Delta xΔx:Δx=(3.456×105)−(3.443×105)=0.013×105=1.3×103\Delta x = (3.456 \times 10^5)-(3.443 \times {10}^{5})=0.013 \times {10}^{5} = 1.3 \times  10^3Δx=(3.456×105)−(3.443×105)=0.013×105=1.3×103mSpace DifferenceΔx′\Delta x^\primeΔx′can be calculated by Lorentz's transformation:Δx′=γ(Δx−vΔt)\Delta x^\prime=\gamma(\Delta x-v\Delta t)Δx′=γ(Δx−vΔt)Δx′=1.9(1.3×103−(0.85)(3.0×108)(1.1×10−3))\Delta x^\prime=1.9(1.3\times 10^3-\left(0.85\right)\left(3.0\times10^{8}\right)\left(1.1\times{10^{-3}}\right))Δx′=1.9(1.3×103−(0.85)(3.0×108)(1.1×10−3))Δx′=−5.3×105\Delta x^\prime=-5.3\times 10^5Δx′=−5.3×105m\hspace{1.8em}Δt′=1.9(1.1×10−3−(0.85)(1.3×1033.0×108))=Δt′=2.1×10−3\Delta t^\prime =1.9\left(1.1\times{10}^{-3}-\left(0.85\right)\left(\dfrac{1.3\times10^3}{3.0\times10^8}\right)\right)=\Delta t^\prime=2.1\times {10}^{^{-3}}Δt′=1.9(1.1×10−3−(0.85)(3.0×1081.3×103​))=Δt′=2.1×10−3s✓\checkmark✓(Δs)2=(3.0×108)(2.1×10−3))2−(−5.3×105)2(\Delta s)^2 = (3.0 \times 10^8)(2.1 \times 10^{-3}))^2 - v \dfrac{\Delta x}{c^2})Δt′=γ(Δt−vc2Δx​)Δt′=1.9(1.1×10−3−(0.85)(1.3×103(3.0×108)2))\Delta t^\prime = 1.9\left(1.1 \times 10^{-3} - (0.85)(\dfrac{1.3 \times 10^3}{(3.0 \times 10^8)^2})\right)Δt′=1.9(1.1×10−3−(0.85)((3.0×108)21.3×103​))Δt′=2.1×10−3\Delta t^\prime = 2.1 \times 10^{-3}Δt′=2.1×10−3sThe space-time intervalΔs′\Delta s^\primeΔs′(Δs′)2=(cΔt)2−(Δx)2(\Delta s^\prime)^2 = (c\Delta t)^2 - (\Delta x)^2 = -(\Delta x)^2(Δs)2=02−(Δx)2=−(Δx)2✓\checkmark✓(Δs)2(\Delta s)^2(Δs)2is not negativeandno✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:(Δs)2=02−(Δx)2=−(Δx)2(\Delta s)^2 = 0^2 - list.title: Question 200
list.content:
A ball of massmmmstrikes a vertical wall with a speed ofvvv. It bounces back with the same speed. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the incoming ball isθ1\theta_1θ1​. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the ball after the bounce isθ2\theta_2θ2​. During the collision, the only force that acts on the ball is normal to the wall.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ad019d36-8753-4d72-a8aa-514000db4270/images/15fb46e9-c502-4194-ac44-81c73f291932/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.42.17%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

What is the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball?A.2mv(cos⁡θ1)\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos\,\theta_1)2mv(cosθ1​)B.2mv(sin⁡θ1)\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin\,\theta_1)2mv(sinθ1​)C.2mv(sin⁡(θ1+θ2))\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin(\theta_1+\theta_2))2mv(sin(θ1​+θ2​))D.2mv(cos⁡(θ1+θ2))\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos(\theta_1+\theta_2))2mv(cos(θ1​+θ2​))
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The question states that the only force from the wall on the ball during the collision is perpendicular to the surface. Due to the absence of a vertical force, there will be no change in the vertical component of the momentum of the ball, and all of the momentum change is in the horizontal direction.Because the collision is elastic, the speed of the ball is unchanged in the collision. As the vertical component of the velocity is unchanged, it follows that the magnitude of the horizontal component of the velocity is also unchanged.Given that the magnitudes of the components are both unchanged, the anglesθ1\theta_1\θ1​andθ2\theta_2θ2​must be equal.It has been determined that the only change in momentum is in the horizontal direction.Therefore,∆ph=pfh−pih∆p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}∆ph​=pfh​−pih​pih=mv(sin⁡θ1)p_{ih}=mv\,(\sin\,\theta_1)pih​=mv(sinθ1​)andpfh=−mv(sin⁡θ2)p_{fh}=-mv(\sin\,\theta_2)pfh​=−mv(sinθ2​)Δph=pfh−pih=−mvsin⁡θ2−mvsin⁡θ1\Delta p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}=-mv\sin\,θ_2-mv\sin\,θ_1Δph​=pfh​−pih​=−mvsinθ2​−mvsinθ1​Butθ1=θ2\theta_1=\theta_2θ1​=θ2​ThereforeΔph=−2mv(sin⁡θ1)\Delta p_h=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)Δph​=−2mv(sinθ1​)ThusΔp=−2mv(sin⁡θ1)\Delta p=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)Δp=−2mv(sinθ1​)

list.title: Question 201
list.content:
A mass,mmm, is attached to a spring (of negligible mass) of spring constantkkkon a smooth horizontal surface. The mass is initially pulled a distance,xxx, from its equilibrium position on the surface and released. At the point where the mass has moved a distancex3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​from its starting point, the speed of the mass isvvv.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b62c54b1-8f15-4ea7-ab55-a6675f1dc82c/images/e7a41f5e-ccae-4876-b0f5-a8c7b6679199/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.22.20%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which expression is equal tokkk?A.\hspace{1em}9mv25x2\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}5x29mv2​B.\hspace{1em}5x29mv2\dfrac{5x^2}{9mv^2}9mv25x2​C.\hspace{1em}9mv28x2\dfrac{9mv^2}{8x^2}8x29mv2​D.\hspace{1em}8x29mv2\dfrac{8x^2}{9mv^2}9mv28x2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since there is no energy loss due to friction or external forces, the mechanical energy of the system remains constant. After the release of the mass, some of the elastic potential energy of the system is transferred to the kinetic energy of the mass. The extension of the spring at the moment the mass covers the distance ofx3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​:x−x3=2x3x-\dfrac{x}{3}=\dfrac{2x}{3}x−3x​=32x​The energy elastic potential energy decreasedΔEH\Delta E_HΔEH​after release to the point where the mass covers the distance ofx3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​:ΔEH=12kx2−12k(2x3)2=12k5x29\Delta E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2-\dfrac{1}{2}k\Bigl(\dfrac{2x}{3}\Bigr)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}ΔEH​=21​kx2−21​k(32x​)2=21​k95x2​The energy is transferred to kinetic energyEKE_KEK​:EK=12mv2=12k5x29E_K=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}EK​=21​mv2=21​k95x2​k=9mv25x2k=\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}k=5x29mv2​

Therefore, the total area A or displacement:A=(625)(0.2)=125A=(625)(0.2)=125A=(625)(0.2)=125mNote that displacement is a vector quantity and so a direction should be stated. In this case, the ball is falling so the direction of the displacement is downwards.Reference to use of the gradient of the graph to find instantaneous acceleration.✓\checkmark✓2.8±0.52.8\ \pm\ 0.52.8±0.5≪m s−2≫\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg≪m s−2≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the graph at a given time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.

mg−ma=mg-ma=mg−ma=air resistance✓\checkmark✓(1.6)(9.81)−(1.6)(2.8)=(1.6)(9.81)-(1.6)(2.8)=(1.6)(9.81)−(1.6)(2.8)=air  resistance✓\checkmark✓11≪N≫\ll\textrm{N}\gg≪N≫✓\checkmark✓ECF for the use of the answer of (c) (i) to determine the accelerationFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The vertical resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​acting on the mass:FnetF_{net}Fnet​= Weight - Air ResistanceorFnet=Fg−FdF_{net} = F_g - F_dFnet​=Fg​−Fd​andFnetF_{net}Fnet​=mamamaThereforema=Fg−Fdma = F_g - F_dma=Fg​−Fd​Fd=mg−maF_d = mg - maFd​=mg−maFd=(1.6)(9.81)−(1.6)(2.8)F_d=(1.6)(9.81)-(1.6)(2.8)Fd​=(1.6)(9.81)−(1.6)(2.8)Fd=11.3F_d = 11.3Fd​=11.3N

list.title: Question 203
list.content:
A stream flows east with a speedvsv_svs​. A boat points due south and moves with a speedvov_ovo​relative to the water.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dca64207-6693-4704-9450-d31d76555a76/images/6777c4c8-7f29-491c-b3cb-82e8d91b9132/Screensho0t%202024-10-26%20at%203.57.21%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The ratiovovs=12\dfrac{v_o}{v_s} = \dfrac{1}{2}vs​vo​​=21​Which of the following is correct about the magnitude in m s−1^{-1}−1and the angleθ\thetaθbetween the velocity of the boat and the side of the stream?\hspace{1em}Magnitude\hspace{1em}\hspace{2.5em}θ\thetaθ\hspace{2.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}3vo\sqrt{3}\,v_o3​vo​sin⁡−1(12)\sin^{-1}\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)sin−1(21​)\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}3vo\sqrt{3}\,v_o3​vo​cos⁡−1(12)\cos^{-1}\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)cos−1(21​)\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}5vo\sqrt{5}\,v_o5​vo​tan⁡−1(2)\tan^{-1}(2)tan−1(2)\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}5vo\sqrt{5}\,v_o5​vo​tan⁡−1(12)\tan^{-1}\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)tan−1(21​)

DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sincevs=2vov_s = 2\,v_ovs​=2vo​The magnitude of the net velocityvnet=vo2+(2vo)2=5vov_{net}=\sqrt{v_o\textrm{}^2 +(2v_o)^2} = \sqrt{5} v_ovnet​=vo​2+(2vo​)2​=5​vo​The direction is determined by the angle it makes with the side of the river

tanθ=vo2vo=12tan \theta = \dfrac{v_o}{2v_o} =\dfrac{1}{2}tanθ=2vo​vo​​=21​θ=tan⁡−1(12)\theta = \tan^{-1}(\dfrac{1}{2})θ=tan−1(21​)Thus the previous answer of5vo\sqrt{5} v_o5​vo​combined withθ=tan⁡−1(12)\theta = \tan^{-1}(\dfrac{1}{2})θ=tan−1(21​)corresponds to answer D.

list.title: Question 204
list.content: A spaceship is moving at a speed of0.80c0.80 c0.80crelative to a stationary observer on Earth. An event occurring in the spaceship is measured by an observer in the spaceship to have a duration of121212s. What is the duration of the event as measured by the stationary observer on Earth?A.7.2\hspace{1em}  	7.27.2sB.12\hspace{1em}  	1212sC.15\hspace{1em}  	1515sD.20\hspace{1em}  	2020s
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Lorentz factor for the situation:γ=11−v2c2=11−(0.8c)2c2\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{{(0.8c)}^2}{c^2}}}γ=1−c2v2​​1​=1−c2(0.8c)2​​1​=11−0.64=10.6=53\hspace{1em} =\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}=\dfrac{5}{3}=1−0.64​1​=0.61​=35​Time measured by stationary observer=γt=(53)(12)=20=\gamma t=\left(\dfrac{5}{3}\right)\left(12\right)=20=γt=(35​)(12)=20s

list.title: Question 205
list.content: The tip of the seconds hand of a clock moves from the“\text{\textquotedblleft}“12”\text{\textquotedblright}”marking to the“\text{\textquotedblleft}“6”\text{\textquotedblright}”marking with a tangential speed of222cm s−1^{-1}−1.Which of the following is correct about the angular speed and the centripetal acceleration?\hspace{1em}Angular speed\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Centripetal acceleration\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}π60rad s−1\dfrac{\pi}{60} \textrm{ rad s}^{-1}60π​rad s−1π30cm s−2\dfrac{\pi}{30} \textrm{ cm s}^{-2}30π​cm s−2\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}π60rad s−1\dfrac{\pi}{60} \textrm{ rad s}^{-1}60π​rad s−1π15cm s−2\dfrac{\pi}{15} \textrm{ cm s}^{-2}15π​cm s−2\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}π30rad s−1\dfrac{\pi}{30} \textrm{ rad s}^{-1}30π​rad s−1π30cm s−2\dfrac{\pi}{30} \textrm{ cm s}^{-2}30π​cm s−2\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}π30rad s−1\dfrac{\pi}{30} \textrm{ rad s}^{-1}30π​rad s−1π15cm s−2\dfrac{\pi}{15} \textrm{ cm s}^{-2}15π​cm s−2
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The seconds hand of a clock makes a complete rotation in 60 s.The angular speedω=ΔθΔt\omega=\dfrac{\Delta \theta }{\Delta t}ω=ΔtΔθ​ω=2πT=2π60=π30\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{T}=\dfrac{2\pi}{60}=\dfrac{\pi}{30}ω=T2π​=602π​=30π​rad s−1^{-1}−1To find the centripetal acceleration we need to calculate the radius of the circular path.v=ωrv=\omega\ rv=ωrr=2π30=60πr=\dfrac{2}{\frac{\pi}{30}}=\dfrac{60}{\pi}r=30π​2​=π60​cmThen the centripetal accelerationa=v2ra=\dfrac{v^2}{r}a=rv2​a=460π=π15a=\dfrac{4}{\frac{60}{\pi}}=\dfrac{\pi}{15}a=π60​4​=15π​cm s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 206
list.content:
A massmmmattached to a string is moving in a horizontal circular motion as shown. The tension on the string isTTT, and the angle with the vertical isθ\thetaθ.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f897e16-36d2-4eba-9082-d03dcb67e4bf/images/a13df1c4-6075-41b6-b663-837340c74c7f/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.29.13%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Below are three statements about this motion:I.\hspace{1em}Centripetal force =mgmgmgtan⁡(θ)\tan(\theta)tan(θ).II.\hspace{0.8em}Total gravitational and kinetic energy of the mass is constant.III.\hspace{0.4em}If the rope is cut, the mass will fall downwards with a straight line trajectory.Which of the statements are correct?A.\hspace{1em}Only IB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is correct:\hspace{3em}TTTcos⁡(θ)\cos(\theta)cos(θ)=mgmgmg,  which givesT=mgcos⁡(θ)T = \dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}T=cos(θ)mg​\hspace{3em}centripetal force (FcF_cFc​) =TTTsin⁡(θ)\sin(\theta)sin(θ)Substitutingmgcos⁡(θ)\dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}cos(θ)mg​forTTTin the second equation:\hspace{3em}Fc=mgF_c=mgFc​=mgsin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ)\dfrac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}cos(θ)sin(θ)​=mgmgmgtan⁡(θ)\tan(\theta)tan(θ).Statement II is correct:The path is a horizontal plane, therefore gravitational potential energy is constant. No work is done, therefore kinetic energy is constant. Total mechanical energy is constant.Statement III is false:The mass has a horizontal velocity during this motion. When the rope is cut, the only force will be the weight, therefore it will move in a projectile motion starting with a horizontal velocity, following a vertical parabolic path (not fall directly downwards).

list.title: Question 207
list.content:
A massYYYattached to a rope is moving in uniform circular motion on a frictionless table as shown on the diagram. The circular path of constant radiusrrris shown with the dotted line. The massXXXis hanging from the lower end of the rope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a40671b-b837-40f6-a740-2d3097378023/images/b246b165-344f-45e4-b1c6-9c5afe234227/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.44.48%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The masses ofXXXandYYYcan be adjusted. What independent adjustments to either massXXXor massYYYcould produce uniform circular motion at a lower speedvvv, but with the same radiusrrr?\hspace{2em}MassYYY\hspace{2em}\hspace{2em}MassXXX\hspace{2em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}increaseincrease\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}decreaseincrease\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}increasedecrease\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}decreasedecrease
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Centripetal force is provided by the weight of the hanging massXXX. We can substituteXXXin to the equationFg=mgF_g= mgFg​=mgandYYYinto the centripetal force equation:mg=mv2rmg = \dfrac{mv^2}{r}mg=rmv2​Xg=Yv2rXg=\dfrac{Yv^2}{r}Xg=rYv2​To maintain the same radius with a decrease invvv, this equation should hold.
When the linear speed decreases, therefore to keep the equation balanced, the massYYYshould increase, orXXXshould decrease.

After the collision, ballAAAmoves off at a speed of 1.8 m s−1^{-1}−1, at an angle of27°27\degree27°from its original direction of motion as shown below.

\hspace{1.8em}m(3)=m(1.8cos⁡27°)+m(vB∥)m(3)=m(1.8\cos27\degree)+m(v_{B\parallel})m(3)=m(1.8cos27°)+m(vB∥​)AND0=(1.8sin⁡27°)+m(vB⊥)0=(1.8\sin27\degree)+m(v_{B\perp})0=(1.8sin27°)+m(vB⊥​)OR≪vB∥=≫1.4\ll v_{B\parallel}=\gg1.4≪vB∥​=≫1.4m s−1^{-1}−1seenOR≪vB⊥=−≫0.82\ll v_{B\perp}=-\gg0.82≪vB⊥​=−≫0.82m s−1^{-1}−1seen✓\checkmark✓≪vB∥=≫1.4\ll v_{B\parallel}=\gg1.4≪vB∥​=≫1.4m s−1^{-1}−1AND≪vB⊥=−≫0.82\ll v_{B\perp}=-\gg0.82≪vB⊥​=−≫0.82m s−1^{-1}−1seen✓\checkmark✓speed =1.42+0.822=1.6ms−1\sqrt{1.4^2+0.82^2}= \answer{1.6\ \ce{m s}^{-1}}1.42+0.822​=1.6ms−1​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:This is a 2D collision where ballAAAis deflected at an angle, and ballBBBstarts at rest. Since there are no external forces, we apply conservation of momentum directions parallel and perpendicular to the initial motion of the ball.Resolving the velocities after into parallel and perpendicular components (note that the angleθ\thetaθis unknown)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7d760ea6-21c8-472e-a179-872ea8743c87/images/e203463c-506d-4625-83c0-37cb917df155/Screenshot%202025-09-24%20at%209.58.07%E2%80%AFAM.png)

In the direction parallel to the initial motion, we have:pbefore=pafterp_\textrm{before}=p_\textrm{after}pbefore​=pafter​(0.058)(3)=(0.058)(1.8cos⁡27°)+(0.058)(vB∥)(0.058)(3)=(0.058)(1.8\cos27\degree)+(0.058)(v_{B\parallel})(0.058)(3)=(0.058)(1.8cos27°)+(0.058)(vB∥​)(3)=(1.8cos⁡27°)+(vB∥)(3)=(1.8\cos27\degree)+(v_{B\parallel})(3)=(1.8cos27°)+(vB∥​)vB∥=3−1.8cos⁡27°=1.4v_{B\parallel}=3-1.8\cos27\degree=1.4vB∥​=3−1.8cos27°=1.4m s−1^{-1}−1In the direction perpendicular to the initial motion, we have:pbefore=pafterp_\textrm{before}=p_\textrm{after}pbefore​=pafter​(0.058)(0)=(0.058)(1.8sin⁡27°)+(0.058)(vB⊥)(0.058)(0)=(0.058)(1.8\sin27\degree)+(0.058)(v_{B\perp})(0.058)(0)=(0.058)(1.8sin27°)+(0.058)(vB⊥​)(0)=(1.8sin⁡27°)+(vB⊥)(0)=(1.8\sin27\degree)+(v_{B\perp})(0)=(1.8sin27°)+(vB⊥​)vB⊥=−1.8sin⁡27°=−0.82v_{B\perp}=-1.8\sin27\degree=-0.82vB⊥​=−1.8sin27°=−0.82m s−1^{-1}−1The speed ofBBBis the vector sum of the parallel and perpendicular components given by:speed=1.42+0.822=1.6=\sqrt{1.4^2+0.82^2}=1.6=1.42+0.822​=1.6m s−1^{-1}−1KE before=12(0.058)(32)=0.26≪J≫=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(3^2)=0.26\ll\textrm{J}\gg=21​(0.058)(32)=0.26≪J≫(2sf)KE after=12(0.058)(1.62)+12(0.058)(1.82)=0.17≪J≫=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(1.6^2)+\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(1.8^2)=0.17\ll\textrm{J}\gg=21​(0.058)(1.62)+21​(0.058)(1.82)=0.17≪J≫(2sf)✓\checkmark✓0.26≠0.170.26\ne0.170.26=0.17therefore the collision is not elastic✓\checkmark✓Allow0.26>0.170.26\gt0.170.26>0.17Allow any units or energy values in terms ofmmmFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:An elastic collision is one in which kinetic energy is conserved.The total kinetic energy before the collision is given by:KE before=12(0.058)(32)+12(0.058)(02)=0.261=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(3^2)+\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(0^2)=0.261=21​(0.058)(32)+21​(0.058)(02)=0.261J (3sf)The total kinetic energy after the collision is given by:KE list.title: Question 210
list.content:
A mass moving with a constant speeduuuencounters a rough surface and comes to a stop. The mass takes a timetttto stop after encountering the rough surface.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b39534bd-d7cb-4a8d-b23e-28aa458816db/images/37cb5cf0-1f11-43ce-af51-ed8a25184738/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.43.46%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The coefficient of dynamic friction between the rough surface and the mass is 0.40. Which of the following expressions gives the initial speeduuu?A.0.2gt\hspace{1em}  	0.2gt0.2gtB.0.4gt\hspace{1em}  	0.4gt0.4gtC.gt\hspace{1em}  	gtgtD.2.5gt\hspace{1em}  	2.5gt2.5gt
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the mass is moving on the rough surface, the only horizontal force acting on it is dynamic friction. Due to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:Ff=maF_f = maFf​=mausingFf=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​anda=v−uta=\dfrac{v-u}{t}a=tv−u​;μdFN=mv−ut\mu_dF_N=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}μd​FN​=mtv−u​FN=mgF_N=mgFN​=mg,  thereforeμdmg=mv−ut\mu_dmg=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}μd​mg=mtv−u​μdg=v−ut\mu_dg=\dfrac{v-u}{t}μd​g=tv−u​μdgt=v−u\mu_dgt=v-uμd​gt=v−uu=v−μdgtu=v-\mu_dgtu=v−μd​gtBy substituting the given valuesu=0−0.4gtu=0-0.4gtu=0−0.4gtu=−0.4gtu=-0.4gtu=−0.4gtBecause we are asked for the speed, we can remove the negative sign to getu=0.4gtu=0.4gtu=0.4gt

list.title: Question 211
list.content:
A race car starts to race on a straight horizontal race track from rest. The car's engine has a constant power output and the car experiences a resistive force that increases proportionally with its speed.Which graph represents the variation with distancesssof the powerPPPrequired by the engine to overcome the resistive force?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e181572b-0067-44df-b66a-5b47ae57facb/images/5c86fe75-dc74-4f8b-8ace-f4a8dacc9f2e/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.43.13%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e181572b-0067-44df-b66a-5b47ae57facb/images/0e3b01a6-12ec-476a-bc5a-7fa3de1b51e2/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.43.20%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e181572b-0067-44df-b66a-5b47ae57facb/images/d3f1ff93-c969-4bc7-a273-166a6e0c4c49/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.43.27%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e181572b-0067-44df-b66a-5b47ae57facb/images/16e4fc70-5030-4221-b643-8987cfde7073/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.43.42%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The power from the engine to overcome the resistive forceFresF_{res}Fres​at any given instant is found from the formulaPres=FresvP_{res} = F_{res}vPres​=Fres​vWherevvvis the speed of the car.At the start of the motion, both the resistive force and speed are zero, and both of these increase with time. Because of the increasing resistive force, however, eventually a terminal speed will be reached whereFresF_{res}Fres​andvvv, and thereforePresP_{res}Pres​, are all constant.

list.title: Question 212
list.content:
A small ball of massmmmis attached to a string and moves in a vertical circular path of radiusrrr.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6a188747-1392-42b0-ac39-2dd62e548fe1/images/467e28b4-d9f5-4434-b96a-c3bc44003cdd/PH0358-1.png)

What is the minimum velocityvvvat the lowest point of the path for the ball to continue moving in a circular path at top of the circle?A.\hspace{1em}2mgr2mgr2mgrB.\hspace{1em}mgr2\dfrac{mgr}{2}2mgr​C.\hspace{1em}2gr\sqrt{2gr}2gr​D.\hspace{1em}5gr\sqrt{5gr}5gr​
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6a188747-1392-42b0-ac39-2dd62e548fe1/images/414637ea-ccfa-4155-8c44-f38f9db344d1/PH0358_2.png)

To calculate the minimum value of velocity at the lowest point, we need to calculate the minimum kinetic energy.At the lowest point, the total energy is only kinetic energy and the potential energy is zero.From the law of conservation of energy,Total energy at the top = Total energy at the lowest pointAt the top the minimum speed for a circular path to be maintained occurs when the centripetal force = weight of the ballmv2r=mg\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg \hspace{2em}rmv2​=mggivingv2=gr\hspace{2em} v^2=grv2=grTotal energy at the top = kinetic energy + gravitational potential energyET=12mv2+mghE_T=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mghET​=21​mv2+mghWhereh=2rh=2rh=2rbecause it is equal to the diameter of the circular path.ET=12mgr+mg(2r)=52mgrE_T=\dfrac{1}{2}mgr+mg\left(2r\right)=\dfrac{5}{2}mgrET​=21​mgr+mg(2r)=25​mgrAt the lowest point,ET=EK=12mv252mgr=12mv2v2=5grv=5gr\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em}E_T=E_K&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\hspace{1em}\\
\frac{5}{2}mgr&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\hspace{1em}\\
v^2&=5gr\\
\hspace{1em}\\
v&=\sqrt{5gr}
\end{aligned}ET​=EK​25​mgrv2v​=21​mv2=21​mv2=5gr=5gr​​

In a tricks competition, a snooker ball of radiusr=r=r=2.5 cm is hit horizontally with a cue and rolls without slipping and then rolls up a slope. The mass of the ball ism=m=m=0.16 kg and the moment of inertia of the snooker ball is25mr2\dfrac{2}{5} m r^252​mr2.

The average acceleration of the ball during the strike is 150 m s−2^{-2}−2. Show that the average net torque applied on the ball during the strike is around 0.24 N m.[3]The contact time of the cue to the ball is 2.5 ms. Show the total kinetic energy of the ball after 2.5 ms is approximately1.6×10−21.6 \times{10}^{-2}1.6×10−2J.[4]When the cue stops applying force on the ball, the ball starts to roll up an incline placed in front of the ball. Calculate the maximum vertical height reached by the ball. Ignore friction and air resistance.[3]The angle of the incline is 25°\degree°to the horizontal. What is the minimum coefficient of static friction between the surface and the ball for it to roll down the incline without slipping?[5]
