list.title: Question 214
list.content:
In the diagram above, there are two pulleys with radii2r2r2rand3r3r3r, and massesmmmand3m3m3mrespectively. Two blocks with masses8m8m8mandMMMare suspended and the system is in equilibrium. The pulleys are fixed so that they rotate together and the system can rotate around a fixed axis without friction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13f8dabc-5149-492b-a8e2-90a44db4e750/images/0ab8662d-7ef2-4584-8b48-202191b315e7/Screenshot%202025-09-23%20at%204.00.27%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Define torque and state the relationship between torque and angular acceleration.[2]The system is in equilibrium. Deduce the mass ofMMMin terms ofmmm.[2]The string supporting the block ofMMMis then cut.Show that the acceleration of the block with mass8m8m8mimmediately after the string is cut is approximately 8 m s−2^{-2}−2.(Ipulley=12mR2)\left(I_{pulley}=\dfrac{1}{2}mR^2\right)(Ipulley​=21​mR2)[4]If the distancerrris 7 cm, find the number of revolutions completed by the pulley system the during the first 2 seconds.[2]
list.markScheme: Torque is a measure of the rotational force/effect acting on an object.✓\checkmark✓ORτ=Frsin⁡θ\tau=Fr\sin\thetaτ=Frsinθwith all terms defined.The greater the torque, the greater the angular acceleration of the object.✓\checkmark✓ORτ=Iα\tau=I\alphaτ=Iαwith all terms defined.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Torque is defined as the product of the forceFFFapplied and the distance r from the pivot point (axis of rotation) to the point where the force is applied, in the direction perpendicular to the line of action of the force.Torque is responsible for causing an object to rotate about an axis. The greater the torque, the greater the angular acceleration of the object, which is related by the rotational version of Newton's second law.\hspace{1.8em}Στ=0\Sigma\tau=0Στ=0T1=8mgT_1=8mgT1​=8mgandτ1=8mg(3r)\tau_1=8mg(3r)τ1​=8mg(3r)(counterclockwise)ANDT2=MgT_2=MgT2​=Mgandτ2=Mg(2r)\tau_2=Mg(2r)τ2​=Mg(2r)(clockwise)✓\checkmark✓24mgr=2Mgr24mgr=2Mgr24mgr=2MgrgivesM=M=M=12m12m12m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Since the system is in equilibrium, the sum of the torques acting on the system must be zero.In each string the tension is equal to the force of gravity, soT1=8mgT_1=8mgT1​=8mgandT2=MgT_2=MgT2​=MgSubstituting each tension distance of application into the torque formulaGives a counterclockwise torque ofτ1=8mg(3r)\tau_1=8mg(3r)τ1​=8mg(3r)And a clockwise torque ofτ2=Mg(2r)\tau_2=Mg(2r)τ2​=Mg(2r)Setting the opposing torques equal to one another and solving forMMMgives24mgr=2Mgr24mgr=2Mgr24mgr=2MgrM=12mM=12mM=12m\hspace{1.8em}Fnet=8ma=8mg−T1F_{net}=8ma=8mg-T_1Fnet​=8ma=8mg−T1​andτnet=T13r=Iα\tau_{net}=T_13r=I\alphaτnet​=T1​3r=Iα✓\checkmark✓Itotal=12m(2r)2+12(3m)(3r)2=2mr2+272mr2=312mr2I_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}m(2r)^2+\dfrac{1}{2}(3m)(3r)^2=2mr^2+\dfrac{27}{2}mr^2=\dfrac{31}{2}mr^2Itotal​=21​m(2r)2+21​(3m)(3r)2=2mr2+227​mr2=231​mr2andα=a3r\alpha=\dfrac{a}{3r}α=3ra​✓\checkmark✓T1(3r)=(312mr2)a3rT_1(3r)=\left(\dfrac{31}{2}mr^2\right)\dfrac{a}{3r}T1​(3r)=(231​mr2)3ra​T1=31mr2a18r2=3118maT_1=\dfrac{31mr^2a}{18r^2}=\dfrac{31}{18}maT1​=18r231mr2a​=1831​ma✓\checkmark✓8ma=8mg−3118ma8ma=8mg-\dfrac{31}{18}ma8ma=8mg−1831​ma9.7a=8g9.7a=8g9.7a=8ga=≪8g9.7≫=a=\ll\dfrac{8g}{9.7}\gg=a=≪9.78g​≫=8.1 m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When the string supporting the block with massMMMis cut, the block with mass8m8m8mbegins to move under the influence of gravity but its acceleration is slowed by the tension from the rope attached to the pulley. The net force on the block is given byFnet=8ma=8mg−T1F_{net}=8ma=8mg-T_1Fnet​=8ma=8mg−T1​The net torque on the pulley is from the tension of the rope and this can be expressed in the rotational Newton's second law equationτnet=T1(3r)=Iα\tau_{net}=T_1(3r)=I\alphaτnet​=T1​(3r)=IαThe combined moment of inertia of the two pulleys is given byItotal=12m(2r)2+12(3m)(3r)2=2mr2+272mr2=312mr2I_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}m(2r)^2+\dfrac{1}{2}(3m)(3r)^2=2mr^2+\dfrac{27}{2}mr^2=\dfrac{31}{2}mr^2Itotal​=21​m(2r)2+21​(3m)(3r)2=2mr2+227​mr2=231​mr2The linear/tangential acceleration and the angular acceleration are related throughα=a3r\alpha=\dfrac{a}{3r}α=3ra​Substituting the expressions and solving for the tension givesT1(3r)=(312mr2)a3rT_1(3r)=\left(\dfrac{31}{2}mr^2\right)\dfrac{a}{3r}T1​(3r)=(231​mr2)3ra​T1=31mr2a18r2=3118maT_1=\dfrac{31mr^2a}{18r^2}=\dfrac{31}{18}maT1​=18r231mr2a​=1831​maSubstituting the tension value into the net force equation for the block gives8ma=8mg−3118ma8ma=8mg-\dfrac{31}{18}ma8ma=8mg−1831​maSolving for acceleration9.7a=8g9.7a=8g9.7a=8ga=≪8g9.7≫=8.1a=\ll\dfrac{8g}{9.7}\gg=8.1a=≪9.78g​≫=8.1m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.8em}θf=ω1t+12αt2\theta_f=\omega_1 t+\dfrac{1}{2}\alpha t^2θf​=ω1​t+21​αt2ω1=0\omega_1=0ω1​=0, andα=8.1(3)(0.07)=38.6\alpha=\dfrac{8.1}{(3)(0.07)}=38.6α=(3)(0.07)8.1​=38.6rad s−2^{-2}−2θf=≪38.6222≫=77\theta_f=\ll\dfrac{38.6}{2}2^2\gg=77θf​=≪238.6​22≫=77radiansnumber of revolutions=772π==\dfrac{77}{2\pi}==2π77​=12.2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Using the kinematic equation, the angular displacement is found by considering the angular acceleration and the time. (ECF from (c)(i))θf=ω1t+12αt2\theta_f=\omega_1 t+\dfrac{1}{2}\alpha t^2θf​=ω1​t+21​αt2The starting angular velocity is zero and the angular acceleration can be found from the linear acceration from the previous question part.α=8.1(3)(0.07)=38.6\alpha=\dfrac{8.1}{(3)(0.07)}=38.6α=(3)(0.07)8.1​=38.6rad s−2^{-2}−2Substituting into the angular acceleration formula gives the total angular displacement.θf=38.62(22)=77\theta_f=\dfrac{38.6}{2}(2^2)=77θf​=238.6​(22)=77radiansOne full revolution is2π2\pi2πradians, so the number of revolutions is given bynumber of revolutions=772π=12.2=\dfrac{77}{2\pi}=12.2=2π77​=12.2

list.title: Question 215
list.content:
A disc of massmmmand radiusrrrrolls without slipping from rest down an inclined plane. A static frictional force ofFfF_fFf​acts up the slope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1da77eb1-1085-4158-9dc1-cc5ea5cbe474/images/a3032d03-f373-43e4-babd-c42da46175d0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.02.39%E2%80%AFAM.png)

The moment of inertia of the disc is12mr2\dfrac{1}{2}mr^221​mr2.Which of the following is correct about the linear acceleration of the disc and the net torque?Linear AccelerationNet Torque\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}23gsin⁡θ\dfrac{2}{3}g\sin \theta32​gsinθFfrF_frFf​r\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}23gsin⁡θ\dfrac{2}{3}g\sin \theta32​gsinθmgsin⁡θmg\sin \thetamgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}gsin⁡θg\sin \thetagsinθFfrF_frFf​r\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}gsin⁡θg\sin \thetagsinθmgsin⁡θmg\sin \thetamgsinθ
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1da77eb1-1085-4158-9dc1-cc5ea5cbe474/images/efb99855-3ab8-44a3-980c-86cf415a7d7e/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.26.04%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The net torque is due to the friction force only.τ=Ffr\tau=F_frτ=Ff​rAccording to Newton’s second law for rotationτ=Iα\tau=I\alphaτ=IαThenFfr=12mr2αF_fr=\dfrac{1}{2}mr^2\alphaFf​r=21​mr2αFf=12mrαF_f=\dfrac{1}{2}mr\alphaFf​=21​mrαSincea=rαa=r\alphaa=rαThenFf=12mrarF_f=\dfrac{1}{2}mr\dfrac{a}{r}Ff​=21​mrra​Ff=12maF_f=\dfrac{1}{2}maFf​=21​maAccording to Newton's second law, the net force on the disc along the incline is given by∑F=ma\sum F=ma∑F=mamgsin⁡θ−Ff=mamg\sin\, \theta\ -F_f=mamgsinθ−Ff​=maThenmgsin⁡θ−12ma=mamg\sin\, \theta\ -\dfrac{1}{2}ma=mamgsinθ−21​ma=magsin⁡θ=32ag\sin\, \theta = \dfrac{3}{2}agsinθ=23​aa=23gsin⁡θa=\dfrac{2}{3}g\sin\, \theta\a=32​gsinθ

list.title: Question 216
list.content: A body is moving in a straight line with a constant acceleration ofaaa. Its speed increases fromuuutovvvin a time ofttt. Consider the following expressions:I.ut+(v−u)t2ut+\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}ut+2(v−u)t​\hspace{1em}II.vt−12at2vt-\dfrac{1}{2} at^2vt−21​at2\hspace{1em}III.(v−u)t2\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}2(v−u)t​Which expression(s) can be used to determine the displacement of the body during the time intervalttt?A. I onlyB. II onlyC. I and II onlyD. II, and III only
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the expression in I is simplified, it is equal to;(v+u)t2\dfrac{(v+u)t}{2}2(v+u)t​This is a uniform acceleration formula for displacement, where the average velocity is multiplied by the time taken.This is included in the data booklet as the formula of displacement.Comparing expression III to expression I, it can be seen that expression III will give a lower value than expression I. Therefore, It does not give displacement.For expression II:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1eaa9bbe-f2f8-4aec-98be-a12855120b47/images/b5c4fc0d-f50e-49a3-a2c4-636e71ca5341/PH0540.png)

Using the above graph to analyze expression II. The area under the sloping line will give the displacement. The area of this trapezoid can be found by subtracting the area of trianglevXuvXuvXufrom the area of rectangleOvXtOvXtOvXt.The area ofOvXtOvXtOvXtisvtvtvt.The area ofvXuvXuvXuis12(v−u)t\frac{1}{2}(v-u)t21​(v−u)tWe know thatv−u=atv - u = atv−u=at, thereforen after substitution, the areavXuvXuvXuis equal to12at2\frac{1}{2}at^221​at2.Subtracting the two areas gives the expressionvt−12at2vt - \frac{1}{2}at^2vt−21​at2, which is the same as expression II.Therefore the correct answer is C

list.title: Question 217
list.content:
Three identical masses are connected as shown with a string that passes over an ideal pulley. The tension in the string connectingm1m_1m1​andm2m_2m2​isT1T_1T1​. The tension of the string attached tom3m_3m3​isT2T_2T2​.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d40768-7d77-4ea9-8484-933e7732fbe0/images/a0a1b313-a16d-4619-920a-428e20554518/PH0546.png)

Which of the following is correct forT2T_2T2​and the acceleration ofm1m_1m1​?T2\hspace{1.5em} \bf{T_2} \hspace{1.5em}T2​Acceleration ofm1\bf{m_1}m1​\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}2T12T_12T1​g3\dfrac{g}{3}3g​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}2T12T_12T1​g2\dfrac{g}{2}2g​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}3T12\dfrac{3T_1}{2}23T1​​g3\dfrac{g}{3}3g​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}3T12\dfrac{3T_1}{2}23T1​​g2\dfrac{g}{2}2g​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Let all masses be equal tommm.For the acceleration, we can assume all masses to be one system. There is a force of gravity of2mg2mg2mgpulling the system one direction, and a force of gravity ofmgmgmgpulling the other direction.Fnet=2mg−mg=mgF_{net}=2mg-mg=mgFnet​=2mg−mg=mgThe total mass of the system is3m3m3m.Therefore the acceleration of the system is the total mass of the system divided by the net force.a=Fnetm=mg3m=g3a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{mg}{3m}=\dfrac{g}{3}a=mFnet​​=3mmg​=3g​When Newton's second law is applied tom1m_1m1​;ma=Fnetm(g3)=mg−T1T1=(23)mg\begin{aligned}
ma&=F_{net}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
m \left( \dfrac{g}{3} \right) &=mg-T_1\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_1&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}mam(3g​)T1​​=Fnet​=mg−T1​=(32​)mg​When Newton's second law is applied tom3m_3m3​T2−mg=m(g3)T2=(43)mg\begin{aligned}
T_2-mg&=m\left(\frac{g}{3}\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_2&=\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}T2​−mgT2​​=m(3g​)=(34​)mg​ThereforeT2=2T1\hspace{2cm} T_2=2T_1T2​=2T1​

list.title: Question 218
list.content:
An object of massmmmwith a speed of3.03.03.0m s−1^{-1}−1collides horizontally with a stationary box of mass2m2m2m. After the collision, the object and the box move together.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cf2be14-0daf-4355-93ab-e26bc35e2097/images/2d97cc7f-9cc9-48f4-bbbe-7367adb6bfac/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.46.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The friction acting on the box and the object is6.06.06.0N.Which expression gives total distance travelled by the combined objects before coming to rest after the collision?A.m16\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{16}16m​B.m12\hspace{1em}  		\dfrac{m}{12}12m​C.m8\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{8}8m​D.m4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{4}4m​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:By using the principle of conservation of momentum, the combined velocityvvvof the object and the box can be found.The total momentum of the object and the box before the collision =3m3m3mThe total momentum of the object and the box after the collision =(2m+m)v=3mv(2m+m)v=3mv(2m+m)v=3mv3m=3mv3m=3mv3m=3mv1.0ms−1=v1.0\ \ce{m s}^{-1}=v1.0ms−1=vUsing conservation of energyInitial kinetic energy of the system =12mv2=12(3m)12=1.5m\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(3m)1^2 = 1.5m21​mv2=21​(3m)12=1.5mFinal kinetic energy of the system = 0Therefore work doen by friction isW=3m2W =\dfrac{3m}{2}W=23m​W=FsW = FsW=Fs3m2=6s\dfrac{3m}{2} = 6 s23m​=6ss=m4s = \dfrac{m}{4}s=4m​

list.title: Question 219
list.content:
Two massesMMMandmmmare connected by a rod of negligible mass. They rotate around a vertical axis as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/49a16cd9-97b1-47c1-89b4-613703577497/images/9ac1e239-268a-4d89-a71b-9bbd88185789/PH0702.png)

The ratioDistance between M and the axisDistance between m and the axis=12\hspace{5em}\dfrac{\textrm{Distance\ between\ M\ and\ the\ axis}}{\textrm{Distance\ between\ m\ and\ the\ axis} }=\dfrac{1}{2}Distance between m and the axisDistance between M and the axis​=21​What is the moment of inertia?A.L2(M+m)4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{L^2 (M+m)}{4}4L2(M+m)​B.L2(M+4m)9\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{L^2 (M+4m)}{9}9L2(M+4m)​C.L2(M+m)\hspace{1em}  L^2 (M+m)L2(M+m)D.L2(M+4m)\hspace{1em}  L^2 (M+4m)L2(M+4m)
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:SinceDistance between M and the axisDistance between m and the axis=12\dfrac{\textrm{Distance\ between\ M\ and\ the\ axis}}{\textrm{Distance\ between\ m\ and\ the\ axis} }=
\dfrac{1}{2}Distance between m and the axisDistance between M and the axis​=21​ThenDistance betweenMMMand the axis =L3\dfrac{L}{3}3L​andDistance betweenmmmand the axis =2L3\dfrac{2L}{3}32L​The moment of inertia is given byI=Σmr2I=\Sigma mr^2I=Σmr2I=ML29+m4L29I=M\dfrac{L^2}{9} + m\dfrac{4L^2}{9}I=M9L2​+m94L2​L2(M+4m)9\dfrac{L^2(M+4m)}{9}9L2(M+4m)​

list.title: Question 220
list.content:
A trapeze artist is swinging from positionAto positionCas shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59fccbf9-fd3e-4471-9a50-940ba5f27060/images/c0aaf0a7-fc7e-4d09-a5db-088c89da3945/PH0634a.png)

[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]The combined mass of the artist and the swing is 70 kg, the length of the rope of the swing isLLLand the tension in the rope at positionBisTTT.Which expression gives the kinetic energy at positionB?A.L(T−700)2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}2L(T−700)​B.LT2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{LT}{2}2LT​C.LT\hspace{1em} \ LTLTD.L(T+700)2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T+700\right)}{2}2L(T+700)​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At positionB, at the bottom of the circular path, the net force is\hspace{2em}∑F=T−mg=mv2r\sum F=T-mg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}∑F=T−mg=rmv2​Then, the tension of the rope\hspace{2em}T=mv2r+mgT=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mgT=rmv2​+mgand\hspace{2em}mg=700Nmg=700 \ Nmg=700NThe kinetic energy at positionB\hspace{2em}Ek=12mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2Ek​=21​mv2Rearranging the formula giving the tension we can find an expression forv2v^2v2:\hspace{2em}v2=r(T−mg)mv^2=\dfrac{r\left(T-mg\right)}{m}v2=mr(T−mg)​\hspace{2em}v2=L(T−700)mv^2=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}v2=mL(T−700)​Then\hspace{2em}Ek=12m(L(T−700)m)=L(T−700)2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}m\left(\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}\right)=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}Ek​=21​m(mL(T−700)​)=2L(T−700)​

list.title: Question 221
list.content:
A car is moving on a horizontal road. The variation of velocityvvvof a car with timetttcan be seen in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/c128ba6b-fdba-4393-b947-d9b089714c52/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.07.04%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following graphs shows the variation of displacementsssof the car with timettt?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/4a90d0a0-0eaa-4639-98c7-dde170216fcc/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.10.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/0f9b7151-16b9-4f2b-a529-96bdb88085f2/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.07.12%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/704ccb98-6f84-43b6-9758-5f21a22ae139/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.08.10%E2%80%AFPM.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/d646c383-d001-464e-b653-e56ae8ccaf24/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.08.15%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The velocity-time graph shows that the car moves in the positive direction for half of the time, and then in the negative direction for the second half of the motion. The gradient of a displacement-time graph at any point is the velocity. Therefore, the displacement-time graph that matches this motion will have a positive gradient for the first half of the motion and a negative gradient for the second half of the motion. The only graph correctly shows this is C.

list.title: Question 222
list.content:
A roller coaster goes around the inside of a loop of radiusRRR, shown in the diagram. The combined mass of a car and the passengers isMMM.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f95051c-3ef4-47b5-9d9c-d0de481dc43b/images/9e4d25ea-942a-4007-a457-e0e798b79f1f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.33.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the car is at its highest point, the normal reaction force of the track on the car is equal to half of the weight of the car and passengers.Which expression gives the kinetic energy at the top of the loop?A.\hspace{1em}0B.\hspace{1em}RMg4\dfrac{RMg}{4}4RMg​C.\hspace{1em}3RMg4\dfrac{3RMg}{4}43RMg​D.\hspace{1em}RMgRMgRMg
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top of the loop, the centripetal force is the vector sum of the combined weight of the car and the passengers, and the normal force of the track on the car.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f95051c-3ef4-47b5-9d9c-d0de481dc43b/images/16199394-207d-4ae6-a977-c0b888e9baa8/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.35.25%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{2em}Mv2R=Mg+0.5Mg=32Mg\dfrac{Mv^2}{R}=Mg+0.5Mg=\dfrac{3}{2}MgRMv2​=Mg+0.5Mg=23​Mg\hspace{2em}Mv2=32RMgMv^2=\dfrac{3}{2}RMgMv2=23​RMgSince the kinetic energy\hspace{2em}Ek=12Mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}Mv^2Ek​=21​Mv2Then\hspace{2em}Ek=32RMg2=3RMG4E_k=\dfrac{\frac{3}{2}RMg}{2}=\dfrac{3RMG}{4}Ek​=223​RMg​=43RMG​

list.title: Question 223
list.content:
An object is released from rest from a very high building. Air resistance is not negligible. Which of the following graphs shows the variation of the gravitational potential energyEpE_pEp​of the object with timettt?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/efd95959-c022-47ea-8cca-dde93d398cef/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.55.50%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/cccdb404-3c1c-47e0-b2a4-f0f329339ed1/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.55.55%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/565b9e0b-6bad-43b8-a252-bf149f1421fc/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.56.02%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/32dde9de-5839-4f64-957f-be1660271073/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.56.07%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:ΔEp=mgΔh\Delta E_p = mg\Delta hΔEp​=mgΔhDue to downward acceleration due to gravity, the rate of decrease of gravitational potential energy with time must increase – slope must become steeper as it speeds up. For slow speeds and low air resistance, the height follows the functionΔh=12at2\Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}at^2Δh=21​at2After the object reaches terminal velocity, the rate of decrease of gravitational potential energy is constant with time.

list.title: Question 224
list.content:
Three identical masses,AAA,BBB, andCCCare connected in a straight line by two identical rods of negligible mass and lengthlll. A forceFFFis applied atCCC, perpendicular to the lineABCABCABC. There is no gravitational field, and the masses are considered point masses.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/751acc25-812a-40f8-b82f-02034a2a6ace/images/2e1920d5-56f2-4018-a3fa-1ece2da99379/PH1793q.JPEG)

When the system is pivoted atAAAits angular acceleration isαA\alpha_AαA​. When the system is pivoted atBBB, its angular acceleration isαB\alpha_BαB​.What is the ratioαAαB\dfrac{\alpha_A}{\alpha_B}αB​αA​​?A.\hspace{1em}25\dfrac{2}{5}52​B.\hspace{1em}45\dfrac{4}{5}54​C.\hspace{1em}54\dfrac{5}{4}45​D.\hspace{1em}52\dfrac{5}{2}25​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Angular accelerationα\alphaαis given by:τ=Iα\tau=I\alphaτ=IαWhereτ\tauτis torque andIIIis moment of inertia.Torque  is given by:τ=Fr\tau=Frτ=FrWhereFFFis force andrrris the perpendicular distance between the force and the pivot.Moment of inertia is given by:I=Σmr2I=\Sigma mr^2I=Σmr2Wheremmmis mass andrrris the distance between the mass and the pivot.Let the mass ofAAA,BBB, andCCCbemmm. When the system is pivoted atAAAwe have:τ=F(2l)=2Fl\tau=F(2l)=2Flτ=F(2l)=2FlI=ml2+m(2l)2=5ml2I=ml^2+m(2l)^2=5ml^2I=ml2+m(2l)2=5ml2αA=τAIA=2Fl5ml2=2F5ml\alpha_A=\dfrac{\tau_A}{I_A}=\dfrac{2Fl}{5ml^2}=\dfrac{2F}{5ml}αA​=IA​τA​​=5ml22Fl​=5ml2F​When the system is pivoted atBBBwe have:τ=Fl\tau=Flτ=FlI=ml2+ml2=2ml2I=ml^2+ml^2=2ml^2I=ml2+ml2=2ml2αB=τBIB=Flml2=F2ml\alpha_B=\dfrac{\tau_B}{I_B}=\dfrac{Fl}{ml^2}=\dfrac{F}{2ml}αB​=IB​τB​​=ml2Fl​=2mlF​αAαB=2F5mlF2ml=2512=45\dfrac{\alpha_A}{\alpha_B}=\dfrac{\dfrac{2F}{5ml}}{\dfrac{F}{2ml}}=\dfrac{\dfrac{2}{5}}{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{4}{5}αB​αA​​=2mlF​5ml2F​​=21​52​​=54​

list.title: Question 225
list.content:
A 200 g ball is moving in a horizontal circle shown with the dotted path in the diagram. The diameter of the bowl is 40 cm and the angular speed is4π4\pi4πrad s−1^{-1}−1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7a344575-2f87-453a-9f77-83741c73fc95/images/606c350c-ec49-41a6-a2c6-1c0319094817/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.56.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

What is the magnitude of the ball's centripetal acceleration?A.\hspace{1em}0.64π0.64\pi0.64πrad s−2^{-2}−2B.\hspace{1em}3.2π3.2\pi3.2πrad s−2^{-2}−2C.\hspace{1em}6.4π6.4\pi6.4πrad s−2^{-2}−2D.\hspace{1em}Cannot be determined with the given information.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The equation for the centripetal acceleration isac=ω2ra_c=\omega^2rac​=ω2r.Althoughω\omegaωis given in the question, the radius of the circular path is smaller than the radius of the bowl and no information is given to calculate it, therefore answer is D.

list.title: Question 226
list.content:
An inextensible string with negligible mass is wound around a fixed pulley of radiusrrrand moment of inertiaIII. The free end of the string is connected to a block of massMMMas shown in the figure.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8b31e2ba-87a7-474b-b2ec-2a8a84573086/images/cf66f4fa-875a-432a-84ee-234b98c86a2c/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.35.26%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The system is released from rest. Which of the following correctly describes the magnitude of the acceleration of the block?A.\hspace{1em}MgM+Ir2\dfrac{Mg}{M+\frac{I}{r^2}}M+r2I​Mg​B.\hspace{1em}MgMr2+I\dfrac{Mg}{Mr^2+I}Mr2+IMg​C.\hspace{1em}MgrM+Ir2\dfrac{Mgr}{M+\frac{I}{r^2}}M+r2I​Mgr​D.\hspace{1em}MgrMr2+I\dfrac{Mgr}{Mr^2+I}Mr2+IMgr​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The block is acted upon two forces: weight (downwards) and tension (upwards). Newton's second law can be written as:Mg−T=MaMg-T=MaMg−T=Ma(1)WhereMMMis the mass of the block,TTTthe magnitude of the tension on the string and a the acceleration of the block.The tension exerts a torque on the pulley with magnitudeTrTrTr, whererrris the radius of the pulley.The angular accelerationα\alphaαof the pulley is related to the tension on the string by the following equation:Tr=IαTr=I\alphaTr=Iα(2)Given that the magnitude of the linear acceleration of the block is the same as the one on any point on the circumference of the pulley, it can be stated that:a=αra=\alpha ra=αr(3)Solving equation (3) forα\alphaαleads to:α=ar\alpha=\dfrac{a}{r}α=ra​This expression can be substituted in equation (2) leading to:Tr=IarTr=\dfrac{Ia}{r}Tr=rIa​Which can be solved forTTTleading toT=Iar2T=\dfrac{Ia}{r^2}T=r2Ia​This expression forTTTcan be substituted in equation (1).Mg−Iar2=MaMg-\dfrac{Ia}{r^2} = MaMg−r2Ia​=MaMg=Ma+Ir2aMg=Ma+\dfrac{I}{r^2}aMg=Ma+r2I​aSolving for a leads to:a=MgM+Ir2a=\dfrac{Mg}{M+\frac{I}{r^2}}a=M+r2I​Mg​

list.title: Question 227
list.content:
An object starts to move in a straight line under the effect of two opposite forces of121212N and161616N.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a815778-979e-489e-a9c5-299ceadae515/images/7eb3ac5e-250f-4986-a252-cdd3b70d9724/PH0548.png)

After555s, the displacement of the object is252525m. What is the mass of the object?A.1\hspace{1em}  11kgB.2\hspace{1em}  22kgC.3\hspace{1em}  33kgD.4\hspace{1em}  44kg
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From the equations of motion, the following expression can be written:s=ut+12at2s=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=ut+21​at2The object starts to move from rest, therefore u=0:25=12(a)(5)225=\dfrac{1}{2}(a{)(5)}^225=21​(a)(5)2a=2a=2a=2m s−2^{-2}−2By applying Newton’s Second Law to the object,F=ma16−12=(m)(2)m=2kg\begin{aligned}
F&=ma\\
\hspace{1.5em}16-12&=(m)(2)\\
m&=2\textrm{ kg}\\
\end{aligned}F16−12m​=ma=(m)(2)=2kg​

list.title: Question 228
list.content:
A student sits on a chair that is free to move. The student holds a rotating wheel as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a8dc27e-5ed3-4eb7-97c4-7129f270b9ef/images/84d2afd6-4239-4c5a-a9ab-a34edb03b51b/PH0740a.png)

[Source: Image created using Images by BedexpStock and OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by BedexpStock and OpenClipart-Vectors  from Pixabay]}}[Source: Image created using Images by BedexpStock and OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay]From the student's perspective, the wheel rotates clockwise. Both the student and the chair are at rest.The student inverted the direction of rotation of the wheel such that it is now turning anti-clockwise according to their perspective.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a8dc27e-5ed3-4eb7-97c4-7129f270b9ef/images/cd5530d6-06c2-4269-bc06-31dc8b3bf218/PH0740b.png)

[Source: Image created using Images by BedexpStock and OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by BedexpStock and OpenClipart-Vectors  from Pixabay]}}[Source: Image created using Images by BedexpStock and OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay]Which of the following is correct about both the student and the chair system?A.\hspace{1em}It remains at rest to keep the total momentum zero.B.\hspace{1em}It rotates clockwise such that the total momentum is clockwise.C.\hspace{1em}It rotates counterclockwise such that the total momentum is clockwise.D.\hspace{1em}It rotates clockwise such that the total momentum is anticlockwise.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The initial total angular momentum is only that of the rotating wheel which is in the clockwise direction.Due to conservation of angular momentum, the total initial momentum must be equal to the total final momentum.Because the rotation of the wheel changes to anticlockwise and the total momentum of the system must still be clockwise, this means that the student and the chair rotate clockwise such that clockwise angular momentum of the student and chair is larger than the anticlockwise momentum of the wheel.

list.title: Question 229
list.content:
A block with a massm1m_1m1​is placed on a frictionless inclined plane. The plane is at an angleθ\thetaθabove the horizontal.An inextensible string attached to his block is wound around a frictionless pulley with a radiusrrr.A second pulley with a radius2r2r2rrotates together with the first one. A block with a massm2m_2m2​hangs from this pulley, attached to a different string.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a0d6f744-58db-4b40-956d-5e71052e0f25/images/c563e171-8d54-45c9-904f-778778fe34ce/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.33.09%E2%80%AFPM.png)

If the system is in equilibrium, which of the following correctly expresses ratiom1m2\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}m2​m1​​?A.\hspace{1em}sin⁡θ2\dfrac{\sin{\theta}}{2}2sinθ​B.\hspace{1em}2sin⁡θ\dfrac{2}{\sin{\theta}}sinθ2​C.\hspace{1em}2sin⁡θ2\sin{\theta}2sinθD.\hspace{1em}12sin⁡θ\dfrac{1}{2\sin{\theta}}2sinθ1​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The block which is placed on the inclined plane, according to Newton's first law, will be in (translational) equilibrium if:T1=m1gsin⁡θT_1=m_1  g\sin{\theta}T1​=m1​gsinθWhereT1T_1T1​represents the tension on the string which runs over the pulley with a radiusrrr.The block with a massm2m_2m2​will be in (translational) equilibrium if:T2=m2gT_2=m_2 gT2​=m2​gWhereT2T_2T2​is the magnitude of the tension on the string which runs over the pulley with a radius2r2r2r.Finally, the pulley will be in (rotational) equilibrium if the torques that the strings are exerting, are balanced:rT1=2rT2r T_1=2r T_2rT1​=2rT2​Substituting the expressions forT1T_1T1​andT2T_2T2​in this equation leads to:rm1gsin⁡θ=2rm2gr m_1 g\sin{\theta} = 2rm_2 grm1​gsinθ=2rm2​gWhich simplifies tom1sin⁡θ=2m2m_1 \sin{\theta} = 2 m_2m1​sinθ=2m2​and can then be re-arranged into:m1m2=2sin⁡θ\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}=\dfrac{2}{\sin{\theta}}m2​m1​​=sinθ2​

list.title: Question 230
list.content: A spacecraft travelling at a0.40c0.40c0.40c, away from the earth launches  a probe forward  also in the direction away from earth, at0.30c0.30c0.30crelative to the spaceship.Which of the following best describes the speed of the probe relative to earth?A.\hspace{1em}0.58c0.58c0.58cB.\hspace{1em}0.63c0.63c0.63cC.\hspace{1em}0.70c0.70c0.70cD.\hspace{1em}0.75c0.75c0.75c
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The reference frame of the spacecraft (S′S'S′) is moving with respect to the reference frame of the earth (SSS) at a speed0.40c0.40c0.40c.The given speed of the probe, is the one that corresponds to the reference frameS′S'S′. This means that which means thatu′=0.3cu'=0.3cu′=0.3c.We can use the expression foru′u'u′:u′=u−v1−uvc2u'=\dfrac{u-v}{1-\frac{uv}{c^2}}u′=1−c2uv​u−v​and solve foruuu.We start by multiplying by1−uvc21-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}1−c2uv​, leading to:u′(1−uvc2)=u−vu' \Bigl(1-\dfrac{uv}{c^2}\Bigr)=u-vu′(1−c2uv​)=u−vNow we can distribute and collect terms withuuuon the same side:u′−u′uvc2=u−vu'-\dfrac{u' uv}{c^2} = u-vu′−c2u′uv​=u−vu′+v=u+u′uvc2u'+v = u+\dfrac{u' uv}{c^2}u′+v=u+c2u′uv​We can now takeuuuas a common factor:u′+v=u(1+u′vc2)u'+v = u \Bigl(1+\dfrac{u' v}{c^2}\Bigr)u′+v=u(1+c2u′v​)And finally divide by1+u′vc21+\dfrac{u' v}{c^2}1+c2u′v​leading to:u=u′+v1+u′vc2u = \dfrac{u'+v}{1+\frac{u' v}{c^2}}u=1+c2u′v​u′+v​u=0.3c+0.4c1+(0.3c)(0.4c)c2u=\dfrac{0.3c+0.4c}{1+\frac{(0.3c)(0.4c)}{c^2}}u=1+c2(0.3c)(0.4c)​0.3c+0.4c​u≈0.625cu \approx 0.625cu≈0.625c

list.title: Question 231
list.content:
Two masses of222kg and444kg are connected with a string that passes over a pulley. They are released from rest. Energy is lost in the pulley due to friction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a3935bc0-26a9-423f-98b1-8976d18dc4d7/images/ba606c7f-40fe-40a9-9904-adf078fef49f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.43.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the222kg mass has gained a gravitational potential energy ofEEE, the444kg mass has a kinetic energy of12E\dfrac{1}{2}E21​E. How much energy has been lost to friction up to that point in time?A.E4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{4}4E​B.E2\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{2}2E​C.E\hspace{1em}  	EED.2E\hspace{1em}  	2E2E
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since both of the masses are connected by the string, they should have the same speed and vertical displacement.Because bothEpE_pEp​andEkE_kEk​are proportional to the mass of the object,Gravitational potential energy loss of the mass of444kg will be twice the gain of the small mass, which would be2E2E2ESimilarly, the kinetic energy of the mass of2kg2\, kg2kgwill be half of that of the4kg4\,kg4kgwhich givesE4\dfrac{E}{4}4E​Due to the principle of energy conservation;The potential energy lost by the mass of444kg is equal to the sum ofThe potential energy gained by the mass of222kg(2E)(2E)(2E)energy lost due to friction(U)(U)(U)kinetic energy of the mass of222kg(E4)\bigg(\dfrac{E}{4}\bigg)(4E​)and444kg(E2)\bigg(\dfrac{E}{2}\bigg)(2E​)2E=E+U+E4+E22E\ =E+U+\dfrac{E}{4}+\dfrac{E}{2}2E=E+U+4E​+2E​U=E4U=\dfrac{E}{4}U=4E​

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/67a19126-12d9-4478-afd2-f45c35ba5e95/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.46.01%E2%80%AFAM.png)

[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]\small{\textrm{[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]Show that the direction of the motion of the box is down the slope.[3]Draw and label a free-body diagram for the forces acting on the block.[2]

If air resistance were taken into account for this constant speed scenario, discuss how the calculated value would be affected.[2]

list.title: Question 233
list.content:
A metal ball of massmmmis released from a height ofhhhabove a massless platform attached to a vertical spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b5cb7aae-5a20-4225-b7e7-576050644152/images/83f09acf-9277-45e6-9188-189b131b1bb6/PH0565.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]The spring constant of the spring is given bymgh\dfrac{mg}{h}hmg​. The ball hits the spring and compresses it. When the spring is compressed by a distancehhh, what is the speed of the ball?(Energy transfer only happens between spring and ball and the kinetic energy of the spring can be ignored)A.2h\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2h}2h​B.2gh\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2gh}2gh​C.3h\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{3h}3h​D.3gh\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{3gh}3gh​
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the initial position and final position of the ball are compared in terms of energy, it can be realized that the decrease in gravitational potential energyEpE_pEp​of the ball equals to increase in kinetic energyEkE_{k}Ek​of the ball and the increase in elastic potential energyEHE_HEH​of the spring. Additionally, the total decrease in height of the ball is2h2h2h.ΔEp=Ek+EHmg(2h)=12mv2+12mghh212mv2=mg(2h)−12mghmv2=4mgh−mghmv2=3mghv=3gh\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_p&=E_k +E_H\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mg(2h)&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2+\frac{1}{2}\frac{mg}{h}h^2 \\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\frac{1}{2}mv^2&=mg(2h)-\frac{1}{2}mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=4mgh-mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=3mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
v&=\sqrt{3gh}\\
\end{aligned}ΔEp​mg(2h)21​mv2mv2mv2v​=Ek​+EH​=21​mv2+21​hmg​h2=mg(2h)−21​mgh=4mgh−mgh=3mgh=3gh​​Therefore, the answer is D.

list.title: Question 234
list.content:
A person pulls a rope with a forceFFFat an angle of60°60\degree60°to the horizontal. The rope is connected to a load over a frictionless pulley as shown in the diagram below. The load is stationary.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/ea5d85f8-2a4b-407d-bde2-c01902d8451b/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.20.21%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Which of the following is correct about the weight of the load and the net force exerted on the pulley by the rope?\hspace{1.5em}Weight of the load\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}Net force exerted on the pulley by the rope\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Less thanFFFLess than  2FFF\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Less thanFFFEqual to 2FFF\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Equal toFFFLess than  2FFF\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Equal toFFFEqual to 2FFF
list.markScheme:
CFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The tension in the rope isFFF. Therefore, the box experiences an upward force ofFFF. The downward force acting on the box is its weight. The box is travelling at a constant speed - Newton's first law tells us that the net force must be zero. Therefore: weight=F= F=F.The rope exerted a forceFFFdownwards and a forceFFFat angle60°60\degree60°below the horizontal on the pulley. This is illustrated below

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/6b2ae24d-3208-4882-a9ef-53e12033d495/image.png)

The vector sum of these forces is the total force exerted by the rope on the pulley. This is illustrated below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/e1534455-65cc-48b2-83e0-f7906e3e0e1f/image.png)

This vector sum must be less than 2FFF. The greatest possible vector sum of two vectors magnitudeFFFwill be when they are pointing in the same direction.

list.title: Question 235
list.content:
A washing machine contains a cylinder that carries clothes and rotates in a circular motion about a horizontal axis as shown in the diagram. Frictional forces act between the clothes and the inner surface of the cylinder.

The radius of the cylinder is0.270.270.27m and its linear speed of rotation of the outside of the cylinder is1.601.601.60m s−1^{-1}−1.Draw the free body diagram for the piece of clothing at the position shown.[3]The laundry machine cylinder is designed to make the piece of clothing lose contact with the cylinder at an angleθ\thetaθabove the horizontal as shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/a3196421-cf22-4499-a5ba-d1c29429d5da/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.12.44%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The free body diagram for the piece of clothing at this position is given below.

Give an expression for the centripetal force at the position shown.[1]Calculate the angular speed, expressing your answer to the correct number of significant figures.[3]Show thatθ=75°\theta=75\degreeθ=75°when the piece of clothing loses contact with the cylinder.[2]Determine the time taken for a piece of clothing to move from the lowest point of the cylinder (pointA) to the point where it loses contact.[3]

list.title: Question 236
list.content:
A rocket is moving in the absence of a gravitational field with constant speed. It starts to accelerate by burning fuel. At the start, the fuel contributes to most of the mass of the rocket. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed ofvvvrelative to the rocket and a constant rate ofσkgs−1\sigma\ {kg\,s}^{-1}σkgs−1. Which graph shows the variation of accelerationaaaof the rocket with timetttas most of the fuel is used?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/d73b21e2-e1fb-4bf9-92cf-9ac8121ccc18/PH0583a.png)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/abf76f2f-87c3-412a-a029-1b61180b8190/PH0583b.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/8216d464-f854-405c-85a8-1ea9ebe0d6df/PH0583c.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/926c08c6-953b-475d-a760-ecf65928e706/PH0583d.png)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​acting on the space rocket:Fnet=maF_{net}=ma \hspace{2em}Fnet​=maWheremmmis the mass of the rocket at any given time.When fuel is ejected from the rocket, it experiences a change in momentum in the frame of reference of the rocket.A given massmmmof fuel has its velocity change from 0 relative to the rocket to its ejected speed ofvvv.Therefore the change of momentum of this mass of fuel isp2−p1=mv−0=mvp_2 - p_1 = mv - 0 = mvp2​−p1​=mv−0=mvThe force on the fuel causing this change in momentum is given by the equationFnet=ΔpΔt=mvΔt\hspace{2em}F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{mv}{\Delta t}Fnet​=ΔtΔp​=Δtmv​And we know that the rate of fuel ejected isσ\sigmaσwhich equal tomΔt\dfrac{m}{\Delta t}Δtm​Therefore the net force on the ejected fuel isFnet=vσF_{net}=v\sigmaFnet​=vσThereforea=FnetM=vσMa=\dfrac{F_{net}}{M}=\dfrac{v\sigma}{M}a=MFnet​​=Mvσ​whereMMMis the total initial mass of the rocket andvvvis the velocity of the ejected fuel relative to the rocket.The massmfm_fmf​of the burned fuel after the timettt:mf=σtm_f=\sigma tmf​=σtThe total mass of the rocket decreases over time due to burned fuel ejection, the acceleration of the rocket after the timettt:a=vσ(M−σt)a=\dfrac{v\sigma}{\left(M-\sigma t\right)}a=(M−σt)vσ​According to this relationship, acceleration increases at an increasing rate. So the answer is D.Qualitatively, the total mass of the rocket is constantly decreasing due to the ejected fuel. As the fuel is ejected at a constant rate, there is a constant net force on the rocket. With a constant net force and decreasing mass, there will be an increasing acceleration. At the start, the change in mass will have little effect on the acceleration, but over time the effect of the decrease in mass will become more and more significant and result in greater and greater acceleration.

list.title: Question 237
list.content:
Define potential energy.[1]A body of mass 2.0 kg is pushed with an initial speed of 1.2 m s−1^{-1}−1down the slope of a frictionless 30°\degree°incline from a height ofhhh. As soon as it reaches the bottom of the incline, it begins to move on a rough horizontal table where it comes to rest momentarily after colliding with a spring of spring constant 32 N m−1^{-1}−1. (Air friction is ignored)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8235c2b-58f5-4ef1-b323-f3a1908362b0/images/f4457c50-c03d-4ce6-8c85-95822296a5f5/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.38.19%E2%80%AFPM.png)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]The speed of the body is 3.06 m s−1^{-1}−1when it reaches the bottom of the incline. Calculatehhh.[2]The distance between the bottom of the slope and the body's position isxxx. On the graph, sketch the variation of the square of the speedv2v^2v2of the body with distancexxxfrom the bottom of the slope.[2](no need to add values to the axes)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8235c2b-58f5-4ef1-b323-f3a1908362b0/images/259e6e21-40a1-43ae-a7ea-d3ed5221df9d/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.21.26%E2%80%AFPM.png)

At the instant that the body stops momentarily, the spring is compressed as 0.43 m. The coefficient of friction between the body and the rough surface is 0.40. Determine the distance that the body covered on the horizontal rough surface between the point of leaving the ramp and stopping momentarily.[4]The incline is replaced with one of a steeper gradient. The body is pushed at the same speed from the same height. Explain the effect of the increase in gradient on the maximum compression of the spring in comparison to the maximum compression in the original situation.[2]
list.markScheme:

3.0 = \gg - 6.4≪21​(2.0)(3.06)2−3.0=≫−6.4J✓\checkmark✓Work done =≪\ll≪Friction =μmgcos⁡θd=(0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(−1)≫−7.8d✓\mu mg\cos\theta d = (0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(-1) \gg - 7.8\,d\,\checkmarkμmgcosθd=(0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(−1)≫−7.8d✓d=d=d=0.820.820.82m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The change in energy between the time at which the body starts to move on the rough surface and stops momentarily is the difference between the kinetic energyEKiE_{Ki}EKi​of the body and the elastic potential energy of the springEpiE_{pi}Epi​;ΔE=EKi−EPi\Delta E = E_{Ki} - list.title: Question 238
list.content: A jet of water with a cross sectional area ofAAAstrikes perpendicular to a wall at a speed ofvvv. After the collision, the water loses all of its horizontal speed and falls to the ground. The magnitude of the force created on the wall due to the water isFFF.Which expression give the density of the water?A.FAv2\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{F}{Av^2}Av2F​B.FAv\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{F}{Av}AvF​C.FAv\hspace{1em} 	FAvFAvD.FAv2\hspace{1em}  	FAv^2FAv2
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Considering the mass of water that strikes the wall in 1 second:m=ρVm=\rho V \hspace{2em}m=ρVwhereρ\rhoρis the density of the water andVVVis the volume of the water.Assigning the length of the column of water to bellland cross sectional areaAAAm=ρV=ρAlm=\rho V=\rho Alm=ρV=ρAlButl=vtl = vtl=vtandt=1t=1t=1, thereforel=vl\ =vl=vGivingm=ρAvm=\rho Avm=ρAvAfter the impact, the horizontal velocity of the jet is zero.F=ΔpΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\hspace{2em}F=ΔtΔp​andΔt=1\hspace{2em}\Delta t = 1Δt=1F=Δ(mv)1=mΔvF=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{1}=m\Delta vF=1Δ(mv)​=mΔv=(ρAv)v=ρAv2= (\rho Av)v\ =\ \rho Av^2=(ρAv)v=ρAv2Rearranging givesρ=FAv2\rho=\dfrac{F}{Av^2}ρ=Av2F​

list.title: Question 239
list.content:
A stone is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance. Which of the following graphs best shows the variation of velocityvvvof the stone with timetttuntil it reaches the maximum height above the ground?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/1372cf34-9ff4-41eb-8e1b-409b309a48d5/PH0533aa.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/7a0b7787-0fec-4f49-8e31-29ea318dae6d/PH0533bb.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/42a7ebb7-983c-4564-8c3c-7e51b7981ded/PH0533cc.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/f92baaf5-5218-4036-bc1c-47f423955d9d/PH0533dd.png)
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:While the stone is ascending, its speed decreases due to gravitational attraction and air resistance. Although gravitational attraction is constant, air resistance decreases with speed. Therefore, the total force opposing the motion decreases. This results in a decrease in deceleration.When the acceleration decreases, the change in velocity gets lower for a constant change in time. Thus the gradient should decrease. Additionally, the velocity of the stone must be zero when it reaches maximum height. These two conditions are satisfied in choice C.

list.title: Question 240
list.content:
In a landing zone designed for spaceships that can move at relativistic speeds, a sequence of warning lights A, B, C, and D are used to guide landings. The spacetime diagram of this system shows the events of switching on the lights  in the landing zone reference framectctctand the worldlinect′ct'ct′of a spaceship approaching the landing zone.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/082ae0ab-75dc-4e22-bebf-86bf1e56e79f/images/b4a39676-080a-4775-8e0e-a25b041af942/Screenshot%202025-03-22%20at%202.17.26%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Which of the following is the order of the lights reaching an observer on the spaceship from warning lights?A.A,D,C,B\hspace{1em}  	A,\ D,\ C,\ BA,D,C,BB.D,C,B,A\hspace{1em}  	D,\ C,\ B,\ AD,C,B,AC.B,C,A,D\hspace{1em}  	B,\ C,\ A,\ DB,C,A,DD.A,C,B,D\hspace{1em}  	A,\ C,\ B,\ DA,C,B,D
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Photon worldlines should be added to the diagram to determine the order of the lights' arrival. These lines can be drawn from the position of each warning light as straight lines that are45°45°45°to the axis.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/082ae0ab-75dc-4e22-bebf-86bf1e56e79f/images/aa4c0ff7-bba5-4ef3-bba8-37a4c820cfab/Screenshot%202025-03-22%20at%202.26.02%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The intersection of the worldlines of the photons withct′ct^\primect′shows the time of arrival of the light coming from related lights. Therefore, the order isA,C,B,DA, C, B, DA,C,B,D.

list.title: Question 241
list.content:
A box of mass333kg is placed on a box of mass777kg. The coefficient of static friction between the surfaces of the boxes is 0.5. A horizontal forceFFFis applied to the777kg box which sits on a frictionless surface.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/19ee0e9b-367f-408b-871c-526728275c32/images/452f270b-6451-4959-b170-f51f3cf61e4b/PH0549.png)

What is the maximum value ofFFFthat can move the boxes without the333kg box slipping?A.\hspace{1em}1 NB.\hspace{1em}5 NC.\hspace{1em}10 ND.\hspace{1em}50 N
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The free-body diagrams of the boxes:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/19ee0e9b-367f-408b-871c-526728275c32/images/9d860ecd-59e5-4504-b19f-2b1efaf7504f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.51.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Note that it is friction from the bottom box that provides the net force that accelerates the333kg box, and this same force of friction pulls backwards on the777kg box.The maximum value of the force of frictionFfF_fFf​can be calculated as follows;Ff=μsFN=μsmg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g=15F_f=\mu_s F_N=\mu_s mg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g = 15Ff​=μs​FN​=μs​mg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g=15NWhen Newton's Second Law is applied to the mass of333kg;Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma1.5g=3a1.5g=3a1.5g=3a0.5g=a0.5g=a0.5g=aTo move without slipping, both of the masses must have the same acceleration. Treating both boxes as one systemFnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=maFnet=(10)(0.5g)F_{net}=(10)(0.5g)Fnet​=(10)(0.5g)F=5(10)=50F=5(10)=50F=5(10)=50NHence, the correct answer is D.

list.title: Question 242
list.content: A spacecraft leaves the earth travelling at a speed0.5c0.5c0.5crelative to the earth.One year after departure from the earth (as measured by a clock inside the spacecraft), a radio signal is sent back to earth.According to an Earth observer, which of the following best describes the time after the departure of the spacecraft in which the radio signal is received?A.\hspace{1em}1.161.161.16yrB.\hspace{1em}1.451.451.45yrC.\hspace{1em}1.581.581.58yrD.\hspace{1em}1.731.731.73yr
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​There are two events that are relevant for the situation:Spacecraft's departure.Radio signal sent.Both events happen in the same place for an observer inside the spacecraft and are separated by a time interval of 1 year.For an observer on earth, the time interval between these two events is given by:Δt=γΔt0=Δt01−(0.5c)2c2=1yr1−(0.5c)2c2=1.155\Delta t=\gamma \Delta t_0=\dfrac{\Delta t_0}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.5c)^2}{c^2}}} = \dfrac{1\textrm{ yr}}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.5c)^2}{c^2}}} = 1.155Δt=γΔt0​=1−c2(0.5c)2​​Δt0​​=1−c2(0.5c)2​​1yr​=1.155yrDuring this time, the spacecraft was constantly moving at a speed0.5c0.5c0.5cas observed from the earth. The distance travelled is then given by:distance =vt=(0.5c)(1.155yr)=0.577vt = (0.5c)(1.155\textrm{ yr})=0.577vt=(0.5c)(1.155yr)=0.577lyAfter the radio signal is emitted, it must then travel for a distance of0.5770.5770.577ly back to earth. Given that the radio signal travels at the speed of light, the trip takes0.5770.5770.577yr.The radio signal will then be received back on earth after:1.155yr+0.577yr=1.7321.155\,yr+0.577\,yr=1.7321.155yr+0.577yr=1.732yr

list.title: Question 243
list.content:
Two objects of massesmmmandMMMcollide and stick together. Both objects have the same initial speed and follow paths illustrated below. The line on the diagram shows the line of symmetry between the paths of the two objects before the collision.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/ec016aeb-9f8f-41a8-b4b3-e167e4537ee0/image.png)

After the collision the combined mass moves away from the origin making an angleθ\thetaθabove the original line of symmetry.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/5f938649-a4ed-49cc-83d0-4bec94b329c9/image.png)

What istan⁡θ\tan{\theta}tanθ?A.\hspace{1em}(M−m)tan⁡αM+m\dfrac{(M-m)\tan{\alpha}}{M+m}M+m(M−m)tanα​B.\hspace{1em}(M−m)(M+m)tan⁡α\dfrac{(M-m)}{(M+m)\tan{\alpha}}(M+m)tanα(M−m)​C.\hspace{1em}(M+m)tan⁡αM−m\dfrac{(M+m)\tan{\alpha}}{M-m}M−m(M+m)tanα​D.\hspace{1em}(M+m)(M−m)tan⁡α\dfrac{(M+m)}{(M-m)\tan{\alpha}}(M−m)tanα(M+m)​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Letvvvbe the speed of the objects before the collision andxxxandyyyrefer to the horizontal and vertical directions respectively.We can resolve forxxxandyyycomponents of velocity. This is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/a12b58e6-4ea7-4a8a-a264-fc6269dc5123/image.png)

Using the diagram aboveTotalyyymomentum=Mvsin⁡α−mvsin⁡α=(M−m)vsin⁡α= Mv\sin{\alpha}-mv\sin{\alpha}=(M-m)v\sin{\alpha}=Mvsinα−mvsinα=(M−m)vsinα(yyyvelocity ofmmmis negative as it points in the negativeyyydirection)Totalxxxmomentum=Mvcos⁡α+mvcos⁡α=(M+m)vcos⁡α= Mv\cos{\alpha}+mv\cos{\alpha}=(M+m)v\cos{\alpha}=Mvcosα+mvcosα=(M+m)vcosαBoth totalxxxandyyymomenta will be unchanged after collision. Soyyymomentum of combined mass=(M−m)vsin⁡α= (M-m)v\sin{\alpha}=(M−m)vsinαxxxmomentum of combined mass=(M+m)vcos⁡α= (M+m)v\cos{\alpha}=(M+m)vcosα

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/fe66386b-9c31-4c76-9d6e-6fc8ab26a704/image.png)

tan⁡θ=oppositeadjacent=(M−m)vsin⁡α(M+m)vcos⁡α=(M−m)sin⁡α(M+m)cos⁡α\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}=\dfrac{(M-m)v\sin{\alpha}}{(M+m)v\cos{\alpha}}=\dfrac{(M-m)\sin{\alpha}}{(M+m)\cos{\alpha}}tanθ=adjacentopposite​=(M+m)vcosα(M−m)vsinα​=(M+m)cosα(M−m)sinα​Alsosin⁡αcos⁡α=tan⁡α\dfrac{\sin{\alpha}}{\cos{\alpha}}=\tan{\alpha}cosαsinα​=tanαThereforetan⁡θ=(M−m)sin⁡α(M+m)cos⁡α=(M−m)tan⁡α(M+m)\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{(M-m)\sin{\alpha}}{(M+m)\cos{\alpha}}= \dfrac{(M-m)\tan{\alpha}}{(M+m)}tanθ=(M+m)cosα(M−m)sinα​=(M+m)(M−m)tanα​

list.title: Question 244
list.content: A stationary observer sees a spacecraft of initial total massMMMthat is moving through a vacuum at a speedvvv. A satellite of massmmmis released with a velocityuuusideways relative to the spacecraft with use of a force that acts perpendicular to the side of the spacecraft. What is the final speed of the spacecraft relative to the stationary observer?Assume speeds are not relativistic.A.\hspace{1em}v2+u2\sqrt{v^2+u^2}v2+u2​B.\hspace{1em}v2+(muM−m)2\sqrt{v^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}v2+(M−mmu​)2​C.\hspace{1em}(MvM−m)2+(muM−m)2\sqrt{\Bigl(\dfrac{Mv}{M-m}\Bigr)^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}(M−mMv​)2+(M−mmu​)2​D.\hspace{1em}(mvM−m)2+(muM−m)2\sqrt{\Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{M-m}\Bigr)^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}(M−mmv​)2+(M−mmu​)2​
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Letvvvpoint in the positivexxxdirection anduuupoint in the positiveyyydirection (as this is a convenient choice of coordinates to work with).Below is a diagram showing thexxxandyyyvelocities of the object and the spacecraft after they are separated.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95f40ff2-d6ca-4ac6-ab32-a5f8ccd9bec4/images/f0790782-dc71-4390-b303-ac36a13a2d64/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.27.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Conservationofmomentuminthexdirection\textbf{Conservation of momentum in the}\,x\,\textbf{direction}Conservation of momentum in thexdirectionxxxvelocity of object and spacecraft after release isvvv- we know this because the object is released perpendicular tovvv(totalxxxmomentum is unchanged).Conservationofmomentumintheydirection\textbf{Conservation of momentum in the}\,y\,\textbf{direction}Conservation of momentum in theydirectionThe mass of the spacecraft after the object is released isM−mM-mM−m0=(M−m)(yvelocity of spacecraft)+mu0=(M-m)(y\,\text{velocity of spacecraft})+mu0=(M−m)(yvelocity of spacecraft)+muyvelocity of spacecraft=−muM−my\,\text{velocity of spacecraft}= -\dfrac{mu}{M-m}yvelocity of spacecraft=−M−mmu​(minus sign because this velocity points in the opposite direction touuu)Using Pythagoras to find speed (magnitude of velocity)speed=v2+(−muM−m)2=v2+(muM−m)2= \sqrt{v^2+\Bigl(-\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}=\sqrt{v^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}=v2+(−M−mmu​)2​=v2+(M−mmu​)2​

list.title: Question 245
list.content:
An object is launched horizontally from a height in a vacuum.  Which of the following graphs correctly shows how the square of the velocityv2v^2v2of the object varies with the square of timet2t^2t2?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4c4e42f-c035-485d-b3a8-bcbdbedeb104/images/475bb84e-ab46-4d7a-937e-8c60b8a80937/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.04.00%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4c4e42f-c035-485d-b3a8-bcbdbedeb104/images/16ba1b65-7e4a-47b8-ac92-f2a55fede1f4/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.04.09%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4c4e42f-c035-485d-b3a8-bcbdbedeb104/images/e975de10-89c1-480e-ae03-446d06401b58/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.04.13%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The object will undergo projectile motion. The velocity of the object has two components horizontalvxv_xvx​and verticalvyv_yvy​. Therefore, it is given byv=(vx)2+(vy)2v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + (v_y)^2}v=(vx​)2+(vy​)2​Onlyvyv_yvy​changes by the following equation;vy=atv_y=at \hspace{3em}vy​=atwherea=g\hspace{3em}a=ga=gBy substitutinga=ga=ga=gin the equation;vy=gtv_y = gtvy​=gtReplacevyv_yvy​withgtgtgtin the previous equation;v=(vx)2+g2t2v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + g^2t^2}v=(vx​)2+g2t2​By taking the square of both sides to find a relationship betweenv2v^2v2andt2t^2t2;v2=vx2+g2t2v^2=v_x^2 + g^2t^2v2=vx2​+g2t2Sincevx2v_x^2vx2​andg2g^2g2is constant, this relationship can be summarized as;y=c+mxy=c+mx \hspace{3em}y=c+mxwherevx2=c=y\hspace{1em}v_x^2=c=yvx2​=c=y-intercept\hspace{3em}\hspace{8em}andg2=m=slope\hspace{2.4em}g^2=m=slopeg2=m=slopeBoth of the values are positive. Therefore; the graph should be a straight line with a positive gradient and positive y-intercept. The answer is B.

list.title: Question 246
list.content:
State Newton's Third Law.[2]A block of mass 2.0 kg is placed on another block of mass 5.0 kg. The blocks sit on a frictionless surface, but the coefficient of static friction between the blocks is 0.50. The block at the top is pulled with a varying horizontal forceFFF.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/be6d5caa-15a5-4319-bcbe-83970ed4e5e3/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.12.55%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Calculate the magnitude of the maximum forceFmaxF_{max}Fmax​which results in both of the blocks moving together without slipping.[3]On the graph, sketch how the force of static frictionFfF_fFf​acting on the bottom block varies with the forceFFF.[2](no need to add values on the axis)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/8cdd5549-4070-486e-8593-4ad4bbed35bd/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.06.47%E2%80%AFPM.png)

FmaxF_{max}Fmax​is your answer to (b)(i) and draw your graph up toFmaxF_{max}Fmax​According to Newton's Third Law, there must be another force paired with the weight of the top block. Describe this force.[2]On another occasion, the blocks are moved with the help of a force of121212N acting on the block at the top. The drag forceDDDon the blocks is given byD=0.025v2D=0.025v^2D=0.025v2wherevvvis the speed of the blocks. Calculate the top speed of the blocks for this force.[2]
list.markScheme:
when two bodies A and B interact, the≪\ll≪action≫\gg≫force‾\underline{\textrm{force}}force​that A exerts on B is equal and✓\checkmark✓opposite in direction to the≪\ll≪reaction≫\gg≫force‾\underline{\textrm{force}}force​that B exerts on A✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of maximum force of friction =μsR=9.8\mu_s R =  9.8μs​R=9.8N✓\checkmark✓The acceleration of both blocks =≪Ffmax5=≫=1.96=2.0\ll \dfrac{F_{fmax}}{5} = \gg = 1.96 =2.0≪5Ffmax​​=≫=1.96=2.0m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓F=ma=≪(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=≫F = ma  = \ll(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=\ggF=ma=≪(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=≫14 N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To have the blocks moving together, the acceleration of each block must be the same. The vertical forces on each block cancel each other. Therefore, only horizontal forces create acceleration. The only horizontal force acting on the block with a mass of 5.0 kg is the force due to static friction between the blocks. The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law (Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma):

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/3af533e6-d79a-41ea-8adb-f805fc93cde4/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.32%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law (Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma):Ff=5aF_f = 5a \hspace{2em}Ff​=5a(first expression)Two horizontal forces are acting on the 2.0 kg mass asFFFand the force of static friction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/4c19e1d9-65aa-4a50-a913-d1ad7c2cc1f6/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The acceleration of 2.0 kg mass can be found by:F−Ff=2.0aF - F_f = 2.0a \hspace{2em}F−Ff​=2.0a(second expression)Since maximumFFFis investigated, the maximum value ofFfF_fFf​should be employed.Ffmax=μsRF_{fmax}=\mu_s R \hspace{1em}Ffmax​=μs​Rwhereμs=0.5\mu_s=0.5μs​=0.5andR=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20R=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20R=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20NFfmax=(0.50)(20)=9.8F_{fmax} = (0.50)(20) = 9.8Ffmax​=(0.50)(20)=9.8NThis is the net force acting on the bottom block. We can use this to find the acceleration. WhenFfmaxF_{fmax}Ffmax​is substituted to the first expression:9.8=5.0a9.8 = 5.0a9.8=5.0a1.961.961.96m s−2=a^{-2}=a−2=aAs both blocks must have the same acceleration, they can be treated as one object of mass2+5=72 + 5  = 72+5=7kgThe applied force F is also the net force for the two blocksTherefore,Fnet=ma=(7)(1.96)=13.7=14F_{net} = ma = (7)(1.96) = 13.7 =14Fnet​=ma=(7)(1.96)=13.7=14N\textrm{ }

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/bf06ade7-18bc-4506-ab6a-19bdab0c0710/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.08.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

a straight line✓\checkmark✓passing through the origin✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When both of the objects are considered as one block. There is no opposing force due to a lack of friction between the surface and bottom block. Hence, the applied force can not be balanced and the acceleration of the blocks will never be zero. The forces acting on the block at the top are the force of static frictionFfF_fFf​(It is the same as the friction force on the block at the bottom) and applied force F. The net force on the top block:F−Ff=2aa≠0F - F_f = 2a \hspace{2em} a \neq 0F−Ff​=2aa=0Due to this relationship, whenFFFis increased,FfF_fFf​is also increased. The maximum value for the force of static friction:Ff=μN=(0.5)(2.0)(9.81)=9.8NF_f = \mu N = (0.5)(2.0)(9.81) = 9.8\textrm{ N}Ff​=μN=(0.5)(2.0)(9.81)=9.8Nwhen theFmaxF_{max}Fmax​is applied.Since there is no scaling on the x and y axis, this relation can be expressed with a straight line passing through the origin at any angle.The gravitational pull of  mass at the top✓\checkmark✓on the earth✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The paired force should be on the other object and the same type of force. Since weight is the pull of the earth on the mass, paired force should be the pull of the mass on the earth.F=Dv2\hspace{2.2em} F = Dv^2F=Dv212=0.025v−2✓12 = 0.025v^{-2} \checkmark12=0.025v−2✓v=≪120.025=≫v = \ll \sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = \ggv=≪0.02512​​=≫22 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The acceleration of the blocks must be zero when they are moving at top speed. The resultant force should be zero to have no acceleration. Since two forces acting on the blocks are drag force and 12 N, they must be balanced by each other;F=Dv2F = D v^2F=Dv212=(2.5×10−2)(v2)12=(2.5 \times 10^{-2})(v^2)12=(2.5×10−2)(v2)120.025=v2\dfrac{12}{0.025} = v^20.02512​=v2120.025=v\sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = v0.02512​​=vv=22v = 22v=22m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 247
list.content:
A 74 kg boy starts to ride a 6.0 kg bicycle from rest. The graph shows how the accelerationaaaof the bicycle varies with the distance travelledxxx.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d4d2c1c2-6eda-4118-be39-9118e7b4d664/images/66c0c029-7c83-49ce-91c5-fb1a477bf51b/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%208.49.04%E2%80%AFAM.png)

What is the total work done by the boy?A.\hspace{1em}0.3 kJB.\hspace{1em}3.7 kJC.\hspace{1em}4.0 kJD.\hspace{1em}6.0 kJ
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Work Done = (Force×\times×Distance) = (Mass×\times×Acceleration×\times×Distance)(Acceleration×\times×Distance) is the area under the graph.Work done is (Mass×\times×Graph Area) = (74+6)(50) = 4000 J = 4 kJ

list.title: Question 248
list.content:
An object of mass1.01.01.0kg rests on a rough surface. Another object of mass2.02.02.0kg is connected to it with a string.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/5ad23e85-206e-4711-b2ed-20c0481d45a3/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.53.49%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the objects are released, the masses accelerate atg2\dfrac{g}{2}2g​. The work done by the tension of the string on the1.01.01.0kg mass is404040J. Which of the following is correct for the1.01.01.0kg mass during this period?Magnitude of the force of friction / NDistance travelled / m\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}104.04.04.0\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}54.04.04.0\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}102.02.02.0\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}52.02.02.0

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/60248a9f-84bf-4dfd-b06e-48f3db63eec5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.51%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
