According to Newton's second law, the relationship between TensionTTT, the force of friction on the objectFfF_fFf​and the acceleration of the objectT−Ff=(1.0)(5)T-F_f=(1.0)(5)T−Ff​=(1.0)(5)When the magnitude ofTTTis substituted in the equation;10−Ff=(1.0)(5)10-F_f=(1.0)(5)10−Ff​=(1.0)(5)Ff=5\hspace{2em}F_f=5Ff​=5NThe work doneWWWbyTTTcan be found by the product ofTTTand the distancedddtravelled by the object.W1=TdW_1=TdW1​=Td40=10d40=10d40=10dd=4.0d=4.0d=4.0m

list.title: Question 249
list.content:
An object is swung at the end of a rigid rod in a vertical circle at a constant speedvvvsuch that there is an outward tension on the rod at all times. The radius of the circle isrrr. This is illustrated in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/509a7eb6-1250-45e2-b3d2-4474aebbfe64/PH0946.png)

The tension in the rod when the object is at its lowest point in the circle is 50% greater than the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point.
Which of the following expressions is equivalent to the acceleration of freefall on Earth,ggg?A.\hspace{1em}v25r\dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}5rv2​B.\hspace{1em}2v23r\dfrac{2v{^2}}{3r}3r2v2​C.\hspace{1em}v2r\dfrac{v{^2}}{r}rv2​D.\hspace{1em}3v22r\dfrac{3v{^2}}{2r}2r3v2​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Below shows a free body diagram for the object at its highest and lowest points.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/cb338b09-6560-4e28-87e1-f9046c093a52/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.54.38%E2%80%AFAM.png)

In both scenarios the object is moving in a circle therefore the net force is a centripetal force. Beccause the speed and radius are constant, the centrepetal acceleration is the same at both locations.Fnet=ma=mv2rF_{net}=ma = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}Fnet​=ma=rmv2​Wheremmmis the mass of the object.(Acceleration is always towards the centre of the circle so at highest point acceleration points downwards and at highest point acceleration points upwards)Let the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point beTTT. We are told that the tension at the lowest point is 50% higher, therefore at the lowest point the tension is1.5T1.5T1.5T.Highest point:T+mg=mv2rT + mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}T+mg=rmv2​Lowest point:1.5T−mg=mv2r1.5T - mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}1.5T−mg=rmv2​Now solving these to eliminateTTT:3T+3mg=3mv2r3T + 3mg = \dfrac{3mv{^2}}{r}3T+3mg=r3mv2​3T−2mg=2mv2r3T - 2mg = \dfrac{2mv{^2}}{r}3T−2mg=r2mv2​Subtracting the equations gives5mg=mv2r5mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}5mg=rmv2​g=v25rg = \dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}g=5rv2​

list.title: Question 250
list.content:
A bullet of massmmmis fired horizontally at a speedvvvinto a block of massMMM. The bullet remains inside the block upon collision. The block is connected to a light inextensible string so that the collision of the bullet causes the block to move from position 1 to a maximum height at position 2 as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61bc0b12-8828-424b-bc0f-78b36fb6313d/images/abad9cd7-7f2a-4a42-a4c2-87c5213fdda8/image.png)

If air resistance is negligible, which of the following expressions is gives the value ofhhh, the vertical distance moved by the center of mass?A.\hspace{1em}mv22gM\dfrac{mv^2}{2gM}2gMmv2​B.\hspace{1em}m2v22gM2\dfrac{m^2v^2}{2gM^2}2gM2m2v2​C.\hspace{1em}mv22g(m+M)\dfrac{mv^2}{2g(m+M)}2g(m+M)mv2​D.\hspace{1em}m2v22g(m+M)2\dfrac{m^2v^2}{2g(m+M)^2}2g(m+M)2m2v2​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Work is done as the bullet travels through the block and comes to a stop. So, this is not an elastic collision - (translational) kinetic energy is not conserved.We must use conservation of momentum to determine the velocity and from that the kinetic energy of the block and bullet after the collision.mv=(M+m)v′mv=(M+m)v'mv=(M+m)v′Wherev′v'v′is the velocity of the block and bullet immediately after the collision.v′=mvm+Mv'=\dfrac{mv}{m+M}v′=m+Mmv​EKafter=12(m+M)v′2=12(m+M)(mvm+M)2E_{K_{after}} = \dfrac{1}{2} (m+M) v'^2 = \dfrac{1}{2} (m+M) \Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{m+M}\Bigr)^2EKafter​​=21​(m+M)v′2=21​(m+M)(m+Mmv​)2Kinetic energy of block and bullet is transferred to gravitational potential energy.hhhis the maximum height reached by the block + bullet so we may say12(m+M)(mvm+M)2=(m+M)gh\dfrac{1}{2} (m+M) \Bigl( \dfrac{mv}{m+M} \Bigr)^2=(m+M)gh21​(m+M)(m+Mmv​)2=(m+M)ghCanceling out a factor of(m+M)(m+M)(m+M)on both sides12(mvm+M)2=gh\dfrac{1}{2} \Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{m+M}\Bigr)^2 = gh21​(m+Mmv​)2=gh12g(mvm+M)2=h\dfrac{1}{2g} \Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{m+M}\Bigr)^2 = h2g1​(m+Mmv​)2=hh=m2v22g(m+M)2h=\dfrac{m^2v^2}{2g(m+M)^2}h=2g(m+M)2m2v2​

list.title: Question 251
list.content:
A piece of metal of weightWWWis suspended by two identical strings. Each string passes through a pulley and is attached to a block of massmmm. The system is in equilibrium

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0d519955-6a40-4506-8274-69c20c98f6a3/images/81305a51-e6a0-44a0-be2b-bb613ea8d76b/Sc%CF%88reenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.06.05%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]What must be true formmmsuch that the two strings attached to the piece of metal are almost horizontal?A.\hspace{1em}m<Wgm < \dfrac{W}{g}m<gW​B.\hspace{1em}W2g<m<Wg\dfrac{W}{2g} < m < \dfrac{W}{g}2gW​<m<gW​C.\hspace{1em}m>Wgm > \dfrac{W}{g}m>gW​D.\hspace{1em}m<W2gm < \dfrac{W}{2g}m<2gW​
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For a string to be almost horizontal, the angle of inclination of the stringθ\thetaθwill be very small

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0d519955-6a40-4506-8274-69c20c98f6a3/images/034ebe4c-40fd-44b9-b867-12650cee1d1d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.05.05%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]The piece of metal is stationary, soW=2Tsin⁡θW=2T\sin\thetaW=2TsinθFor very small inclination angleθ\thetaθ,sin⁡θ\sin\thetasinθwill be very smallFor the above equation to be valid; the value of the tension T in the string must be very high. T >> WT=mgT = mgT=mgWhich means that the mass of the block must be higher than the mass of the metal. Som>Wgm > \frac{W}{g}m>gW​

list.title: Question 252
list.content:
A ball of mass0.40.40.4kg is attached to a string of length0.20.20.2m and is moving in a vertical circular path with tangential speed of3\sqrt33​m s−1^{-1}−1at the instant shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f5614af-5167-4bb5-9a52-95fd7da2e05a/images/ad595940-00d7-4646-b95f-3a474d1c2590/PH0635.png)

Given thatsin⁡(60°)=32\sin(60\degree)=\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}sin(60°)=23​​andcos⁡(60°)=12\cos(60\degree)=\dfrac{1}{2}cos(60°)=21​, what is the tension in the string at the shown position?A.\hspace{1em}(6+23)(6+2\sqrt3)(6+23​)NB.\hspace{1em}8 NC.\hspace{1em}4 ND.\hspace{1em}(6−23)(6-2\sqrt3)(6−23​)N
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The ball is rotating in a vertical circular path, then the forces acting on it is the tension of the string and the weight.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f5614af-5167-4bb5-9a52-95fd7da2e05a/images/f8dd71e5-0c6c-4fd6-ada2-f88ed05e3b06/PH0635a.png)

The centripetal force acting on the ball is the vector sum of the tension of the string and the component of the weight that is the same direction as the string\hspace{2em}Fc=T−mgcos⁡(60°)F_c=T-mg\cos(60\degree)Fc​=T−mgcos(60°)The centripetal force\hspace{2em}Fc=mv2rF_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Fc​=rmv2​Then\hspace{2em}T=mv2r+mgcos⁡(60°)T=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mg\cos(60\degree)T=rmv2​+mgcos(60°)\hspace{2em}T=(0.4)(3)20.2+(0.4)(10)(12)T=\dfrac{(0.4){(\sqrt3)}^2}{0.2}+\left(0.4\right)\left(10\right)\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)T=0.2(0.4)(3​)2​+(0.4)(10)(21​)\hspace{2.9em}=888N

list.title: Question 253
list.content:
A train with a proper length of500500500m  is moving at a speedv=0.76cv=0.76cv=0.76cwith respect to an external stationary observerXXX.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/212f2581-bbe3-4530-99ef-33fcb93ee8ae/images/18eafed2-6eca-4fbf-8d4c-5a651623a1e0/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.14.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When exactly half the train has passed next to the observer, two light bulbs placed at opposite ends of the train are turned on simultaneously, according to the frame reference of the train.According to observerXXX, which light bulb is turned on first and what is the time interval,Δt\Delta tΔtbetween the two lights turning on?\hspace{1.5em}Turns on first\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}Δt\Delta tΔt\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}A1.95μ1.95\,\mu1.95μs\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}B1.95μ1.95\,\mu1.95μs\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}A3.90μ3.90\,\mu3.90μs\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}B3.90μ3.90\,\mu3.90μs
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​There two independent events which correspond to both light bulbs turning on.The coordinates of these events, according to the reference frameS′S'S′(moving train) are as follows:tA′=0;xA′=−250t_A'=0;\ x_A'=-250tA′​=0;xA′​=−250m\hspace{5em}tB′=0;xB′=250t_B'=0;\ x_B'=250tB′​=0;xB′​=250mIn order to find the time coordinates of these events in the frame of the observer we can use Lorentz transformation:t=γ(t′+vxc2)t=\gamma \Bigl(t'+\dfrac{vx}{c^2}\Bigl)t=γ(t′+c2vx​)tA=11−(0.76c)2c2(0+(0.76c)(−250m)c2)t_A=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.76c)^2}{c^2}}}\Bigl(0+\dfrac{(0.76 c)(-250\,\ce{m})}{c^2}\Bigr)tA​=1−c2(0.76c)2​​1​(0+c2(0.76c)(−250m)​)=−9.74×10−7\hspace{1.2em}=-9.74\times10^{-7}=−9.74×10−7stB=11−(0.76c)2c2(0+(0.76c)(250m)c2)=9.74×10−7t_B=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.76c)^2}{c^2}}} \Bigl(0+\dfrac{(0.76c)(250\,\ce{m})}{c^2}\Bigr)=9.74\times10^{-7}tB​=1−c2(0.76c)2​​1​(0+c2(0.76c)(250m)​)=9.74×10−7sThese times represent the instants in which the lights are turned on according to the reference frame of the observer. For the observer to see the lights turned on, light would have to travel to the observer. Due to the symmetry of the situation, both signals would have to travel through the same distance up to the observer's eyes, this means that the time differencetB−tAt_B-t_AtB​−tA​is the same as the time difference received by the observer.It is then:Δt=tB−tA=1.95×10−6s=1.95μ\Delta t=t_B-t_A=1.95\times10^{-6}\,\ce{s}=1.95\,\muΔt=tB​−tA​=1.95×10−6s=1.95μs

list.title: Question 254
list.content:
At timeT=0T=0T=0object A is launched from the top of a cliff of heighthhhat a velocityvvvand an angle of30°30\text{\textdegree}30°below the horizontal. At the same time Object B is launched from the bottom of the cliff at an angle of 30°\text{\textdegree}°above the horizontal with the same velocityvvv. The objects collide at timeT=tT=tT=t.The trajectories of the objects are shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5d099398-5385-4122-9781-2f400d31ce34/images/d833a6da-55dc-44ff-8aa2-fc53d935bf1f/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.56.33%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Air resistance is negligible. What isttt?A.\hspace{1em}t=h2vcos⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\cos(30\text{\textdegree})}t=2vcos(30°)h​B.\hspace{1em}t=h2vsin⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}t=2vsin(30°)h​C.\hspace{1em}t=hvcos⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{v\cos(30\text{\textdegree})}t=vcos(30°)h​D.\hspace{1em}t=hvsin⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{v\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}t=vsin(30°)h​
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Both have the same horizontal velocity (vH=vcos⁡(30°)v_H=v \cos(30\text{\textdegree})vH​=vcos(30°)) so we may ignore the horizontal direction(A person travelling in a car with the same horizontal velocity as the objects would only see vertical motion)So, we must consider only the vertical equations of motion of the objects.s=ut+12at2+initialpositions=u\,t+\dfrac{1}{2}\,a\,t^2+initial\ positions=ut+21​at2+initialpositionLet us treat the upward direction as positive and the ground to be at positions=0s=0s=0. (These choices are arbitrary – but we must be consistent)The initial vertical velocity of object A is−vsin⁡(30°)-v\,\sin(\,30\text{\textdegree})−vsin(30°)and the initial velocity of object B isvsin⁡(30°)v\,\sin( 30\text{\textdegree})vsin(30°). This is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5d099398-5385-4122-9781-2f400d31ce34/images/68c635f9-cf33-448b-b01e-eb23c6ad08d1/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.00.26%E2%80%AFAM.png)

The position object AsAs_AsA​is given bysA=−vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2+hs_A=-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2+hsA​=−vsin(30°)t−21​gt2+h(acceleration vector points downwards soa=−ga=-ga=−g)The position of object BsBs_BsB​is given bys=vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2s=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2s=vsin(30°)t−21​gt2We want to know when the objects collide (where the vertical positions are the same) so equatingsAs_AsA​andsBs_BsB​gives.−vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2+h=vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}gt^2+h=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2−vsin(30°)t−21​gt2+h=vsin(30°)t−21​gt2Notice we have−12gt2-\dfrac{1}{2}gt^2−21​gt2on both sides so these cancel. There is a frame of reference in which the objects are not accelerating so acceleration is irrelevant to time of collision! (A person in freefall beside the objects would see no acceleration - they would measuresA=−vsin⁡(30°)+hs_A=-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})+hsA​=−vsin(30°)+handsB=vsin⁡(30°)s_B=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})sB​=vsin(30°)−vsin⁡(30°)t+h=vsin⁡(30°)t-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t+h=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t−vsin(30°)t+h=vsin(30°)th=2vsin⁡(30°)th=2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})th=2vsin(30°)tt=h2vsin⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}t=2vsin(30°)h​

list.title: Question 255
list.content: According to an observer in an inertial reference frame, two flashes of light are separated by a distanceΔx=2\Delta x=2Δx=2km and a timeΔt\Delta tΔtwherect=3ct=3ct=3km.Below are three statements about the eventsI.An inertial reference frame in which the light flashes occur at the same time existsII.An inertial reference frame in which the light flashes occur at the same position existsIII.An inertial reference frame in which the light beams travel at different speeds existsWhich of the statements are correct?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The quantityΔs\Delta sΔsis the spacetime interval. It classifies the separation between two events:Timelike (Δs2>0\Delta s^2\gt0Δs2>0): Events can be connected by a signal moving slower than light; there is a frame where they occur at the same position but not at the same time.Spacelike (Δs2<0\Delta s^2\lt0Δs2<0): Events cannot influence each other; there is a frame where they occur at the same time but at different positions.Lightlike (Δs2=0\Delta s^2=0Δs2=0): Events connected exactly by light.Here, the spacetime interval is given by:Δs2=(cΔt)2−(Δx)2=32−22=5>0\Delta s^2=(c\Delta t)^2-(\Delta x)^2=3^2-2^2=5\gt0Δs2=(cΔt)2−(Δx)2=32−22=5>0This is timelike, so the events can occur at the same position in some inertial frame (Statement II true), but they cannot be simultaneous (Statement I false).Statement III is false because the speed of light is alwayscccin all inertial frames.Note: it is not clear whether the concepts of spaceline and timelike are elements of the new syllabus. This can be considered an enrichment question.

list.title: Question 256
list.content:
A mass ofmmmkg is hung on the end of the spring. When the system is in equilibrium, the elastic potential energy stored in the spring isEEE.A downward force is then applied to the system causing the total elastic potential energy stored to double. This is shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/994b69a7-9232-4ddf-af1a-8fc88644a46e/images/f5d4dd36-540a-481c-9368-870249a86090/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.50.30%E2%80%AFAM.png)

[© Revision Village 2022. Created with https://chemix.org/]The downward force is then removed, and the system oscillates about the equilibrium position.What is the magnitude of the downward force and the kinetic energy of the mass as it passes the equilibrium position?You may assume friction and air resistance are negligible.Magnitude of downward forceKinetic energy of mass as it passes equilibrium\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}(2\sqrt {2}2​- 1)mgmgmgEEE\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}(2\sqrt {2}2​- 1)mgmgmg(3−-−22)E\sqrt {2}) E2​)E\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}2mg\sqrt {2}\,mg2​mgEEE\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}2mg\sqrt {2}\,mg2​mg(3−-−22)E\sqrt {2}) E2​)E
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:LetE=12kx2E = \dfrac {1}{2} kx{^2}E=21​kx2Wherekkkis the spring constant andxxxis that extension of the spring when it is in the equilibrium position. (This is the length of the spring with massmmmattached - natural length of the spring).LetW=mgW = mgW=mgbe the (weight) force of the mass hanging on the spring.W=kxW = kxW=kxSubstitutingx=Wkx = \dfrac {W}{k}x=kW​intoE=12kx2E = \dfrac {1}{2} kx{^2}E=21​kx2givesE=W22kE = \dfrac {W{^2}}{2k}E=2kW2​kkkis constant so we may say thatEEEα\alphaαW2W{^2}W2EW2\dfrac {E}{W{^2}}W2E​= constantSo, we may writeW2E=(Ft)22E\dfrac {W{^2}}{E} = \dfrac{(F_{t})^2}{2E}EW2​=2E(Ft​)2​whereFtF_{t}Ft​is the total force acting on the spring when it is being pulled down.W2=(Ft)22W{^2} = \dfrac{(F_{t})^2}{2}W2=2(Ft​)2​2W2=(Ft)22W{^2} = {(F_{t})^2}2W2=(Ft​)22W=Ft\sqrt {2} W = F_{t}2​W=Ft​Finding the extra force givesFextra=Ft−W=2W−W=(2−1)W=(2−1)mgF_{extra}=F_{t} - W = \sqrt {2} W - W = (\sqrt {2} - 1) W = (\sqrt {2} - 1)mgFextra​=Ft​−W=2​W−W=(2​−1)W=(2​−1)mgFor kinetic energy:EkE_{k}Ek​is not equal to2E−E=E2E - E = E2E−E=EbecauseGPEGPEGPEis involved as well asEkE_{k}Ek​andEPEEPEEPE.The simplest way to treat this scenario is to consider the ‘extra force’,FextraF_{extra}Fextra​and ‘extra extension from equilibrium’,xextrax_{extra}xextra​.FextraF_{extra}Fextra​=kxextrakx_{extra}kxextra​Andk=mgxk = \dfrac{mg}{x}k=xmg​So(2−1)mg=mgx(xextra)(\sqrt {2} - 1)mg = \dfrac{mg}{x}(x_{extra})(2​−1)mg=xmg​(xextra​)(2−1)=1x(xextra)(\sqrt {2} - 1) = \dfrac{1}{x} (x_{extra})(2​−1)=x1​(xextra​)(xextra)=(2−1)x(x_{extra})= (\sqrt {2} - 1)x(xextra​)=(2​−1)xEk=12k((2−1)x)2E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k((\sqrt {2} - 1)x){^2}Ek​=21​k((2​−1)x)2Ek=12kx2((2−1))2E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2}((\sqrt {2} - 1)){^2}Ek​=21​kx2((2​−1))2Ek=E((2)2−2−2+1)E_{k} = E ((\sqrt {2}){^2} - \sqrt {2} - \sqrt {2} + 1)Ek​=E((2​)2−2​−2​+1)Ek=(3−22)EE_{k} = (3 - 2 \sqrt {2})EEk​=(3−22​)EFurther intuition‾\underline{\textrm{Further intuition}}Further intuition​:It may seem strange thatEk=12k(xextra)2E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x_{extra})^2Ek​=21​k(xextra​)2because:1)1)1)EPEEPEEPE≠Ek\not= E_{k}=Ek​becauseGPEGPEGPEis also involved2)2)2)AAA∝\propto∝B2B{^2}B2does not imply that (Extra A)∝\propto∝(Extra B)2{^2}2\hspace{1em}For example: IfA=B2A = B{^2}A=B2,1=121 = 1{^2}1=12and4=224 = 2{^2}4=22but(4−1)≠(2−1)2(4 - 1) \not= (2 - 1){^2}(4−1)=(2−1)2But it turns out that these facts taken together produce the result thatEk=12k(xextra)2E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x_{extra})^2Ek​=21​k(xextra​)2. Here is proof:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/994b69a7-9232-4ddf-af1a-8fc88644a46e/images/2ed1869c-46b6-41fc-bb1d-862f99f222a5/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.49.31%E2%80%AFAM.png)

If the spring is in position 3 and the extra force is released, the mass will move upwards (past position 2) and oscillate in simple harmonic motion with position 2 as the equilibrium.Let us takeGPEGPEGPEto be zero in position 3.Total energy in position3=12k(x+y)2=12k(x2+2xy+y2)3 = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x + y){^2} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x{^2} + 2xy + y{^2})3=21​k(x+y)2=21​k(x2+2xy+y2)Total energy in position2=Ek+mgy+12kx22 = E_{k} + mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2}2=Ek​+mgy+21​kx2Energy is conserved soEk+mgy+12kx2=12k(x2+2xy+y2)E_{k} + mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x{^2} + 2xy + y{^2})Ek​+mgy+21​kx2=21​k(x2+2xy+y2)Ek+mgy+12kx2=12kx2+kxy+12ky2E_{k} + mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2} + kxy+ \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}Ek​+mgy+21​kx2=21​kx2+kxy+21​ky2Ek+mgy=kxy+12ky2E_{k} + mgy = kxy + \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}Ek​+mgy=kxy+21​ky2Nowk=mgxk = mgxk=mgxsoEk+mgy=(mgx)xy+12ky2E_{k} + mgy = (\dfrac{mg}{x})xy + \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}Ek​+mgy=(xmg​)xy+21​ky2Ek+mgy=mgy+12ky2E_{k} + mgy = mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}Ek​+mgy=mgy+21​ky2Ek=12ky2E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}Ek​=21​ky2Ek=12k(xextra)2E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x_{extra})^2Ek​=21​k(xextra​)2

list.title: Question 257
list.content:
DiscAAArotates around a vertical frictionless axle with angular speedωA\omega_AωA​and moment of inertiaIAI_AIA​. DiscBBBwith moment of inertiaIBI_BIB​is dropped from rest on discAAA. The ratioIBIA=14\dfrac{I_B}{I_A} =\dfrac{1}{4}IA​IB​​=41​

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a22bd7dc-181e-4b49-8bbb-3c5e95b3c65b/images/cf0c322f-91c7-4225-91be-c94aa69209c6/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.54.41%E2%80%AFAM.png)

The two discs have the same final angular speedω\omegaω.What is the ratio(Final kinetic energy)(Initial kinetic energy)\dfrac{\textrm{(Final\ kinetic\ energy)}}{\textrm{(Initial\ kinetic\ energy)}}(Initial kinetic energy)(Final kinetic energy)​?A.14\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{4}41​B.12\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{2}21​C.45\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{4}{5}54​D.54\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{5}{4}45​
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From the given information,IB=14IAI_B=\dfrac{1}{4} I_AIB​=41​IA​ThereforeIA+IB=54IAI_A+I_B=\dfrac{5}{4} I_AIA​+IB​=45​IA​Due to conservation of angular momentumLi=LfL_i=L_fLi​=Lf​IAωA=(IA+IB)ωI_A \omega_A=(I_A+I_B)\omegaIA​ωA​=(IA​+IB​)ωsinceIBIA=14\dfrac{I_B}{I_A} =\dfrac{1}{4}IA​IB​​=41​Then4IBωA=5IBω4I_B \omega_A=5I_B \omega4IB​ωA​=5IB​ωω=45ωA\omega=\dfrac{4}{5} \omega_Aω=54​ωA​The initial kinetic energy is given byEKi=12IAωA2E_{Ki}=\dfrac{1}{2} I_A \omega_A^2EKi​=21​IA​ωA2​The final kinetic energy is given byEKf=12(IA+IB)ω2E_{Kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}(I_A+I_B)\omega^2EKf​=21​(IA​+IB​)ω2The ratio between final and initial kinetic energy is given byFinalkineticenergyinitialkineticenergy=(12(IA+IB)ω2)(14IAωA2)=(54(IA)ω2)(IAωA2)=(5ω2)(4ωA2)=(5(45ωA)2)(4ωA2)=(54)(1625)=45\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\hspace{1.3cm}\dfrac{Final\ kinetic\ energy}{initial\ kinetic\ energy}&=\dfrac{(\frac{1}{2}(I_A+I_B)\omega^2)}{(\frac{1}{4} I_A \omega_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{(\frac{5}{4}(I_A)\omega^2)}{(I_A \omega_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{(5ω^2)}{(4ω_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{(5(\frac{4}{5} ω_A)^2)}{(4ω_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\bigg(\dfrac{5}{4}\bigg)\bigg(\dfrac{16}{25}\bigg)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{4}{5}\\
\end{aligned}initialkineticenergyFinalkineticenergy​​=(41​IA​ωA2​)(21​(IA​+IB​)ω2)​=(IA​ωA2​)(45​(IA​)ω2)​=(4ωA2​)(5ω2)​=(4ωA2​)(5(54​ωA​)2)​=(45​)(2516​)=54​​

list.title: Question 258
list.content:
A uniform rod of massMMMand lengthLLLis pivoted at one of its ends. The rod is released from rest from the horizontal position.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b15f8f84-049c-456a-8829-8d8d12d78b52/images/8282415c-e1e7-4549-9c16-2d058ed04f1d/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.50.21%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The moment of inertia of the rod when rotating about its end is13ML2\dfrac{1}{3}ML^231​ML2.What is the linear speed of the bottom end of the rod as it swings past the vertical position?A.3gL\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{\dfrac{3g}{L}}L3g​​B.3gL\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{3gL}3gL​C.6gL\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{6gL}6gL​D.3g2L\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{3g}{2L}2L3g​
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The center of mass of the rod at the horizontal position is higher than that at the vertical position byL2\dfrac{L}{2}2L​.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b15f8f84-049c-456a-8829-8d8d12d78b52/images/f7a199ca-a6be-4073-8541-12a68af8fbe6/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.52.25%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Then change in the gravitational potential energy between the horizontal position and the vertical position isEP=MgL2E_P=Mg \dfrac{L}{2}EP​=Mg2L​The rotational kinetic energy at the vertical position is given byEK=12Iω2E_K=\dfrac{1}{2} I\omega^2EK​=21​Iω2EK=12(13ML2)ω2=16ML2ω2E_K= \dfrac{1}{2} ( \dfrac{1}{3} ML^2 ) \omega^2=\dfrac{1}{6} ML^2 \omega^2EK​=21​(31​ML2)ω2=61​ML2ω2According to the conservation of energy, the change in gravitational potential energy is equal to the kinetic energy at the vertical position.EP=EKE_P=E_KEP​=EK​MgL2=16ML2ω2Mg \dfrac{L}{2}=\dfrac{1}{6} ML^2 ω^2Mg2L​=61​ML2ω2Simplifying givesω=3gL\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{3g}{L}}ω=L3g​​The linear speed is given byv=rωv=r \omegav=rωFor the other end of the rodr=Lr=Lr=LThenv=L3gLv=L\sqrt{\dfrac{3g}{L}}v=LL3g​​v=3gLv=\sqrt{3gL}v=3gL​

list.title: Question 259
list.content:
A solid spherical ball bearing of massmmmand radiusrrris initially at rest on an inclined plane. It begins rolling down from a vertical heighthhhand reaches pointXXXhaving lost no energy to friction. Along the horizontal portion between pointsXXXandYYY, the ball encounters a constant resistive forceFFFopposing its motion.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bf679858-9917-49c6-baa6-7c7554de9322/images/bbba8d6d-db3b-44b9-8c85-ffada59b2af6/ph1849qa.png)
